questions.text: A 28-year-old G2P1 patient at 17 weeks of gestation comes for a routine antenatal visit. Her blood pressure is 142/90 mm Hg. A repeat blood pressure after 6 hours measures 148/92 mm Hg. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
In this scenario of hypertension in a patient with a gestational age <20 weeks, the diagnosis is chronic hypertension. 

Chronic hypertension is diagnosed when the patient is a known hypertensive (or) BP > 140/90 mmHg before 20 weeks of gestation.

Chronic hypertension with superimposed pre-eclampsia or eclampsia is diagnosed with the following presentation: aggravation of hypertension, new onset of proteinuria after 20 weeks, development of headache, scotoma, epigastric pain, and HELLP syndrome. (Option A)

Gestational hypertension: BP≥ 140/90 mm of hg for the first time in pregnancy after 20 weeks of gestation in a previously normotensive woman without proteinuria. (Option D) 

Pre-eclampsia (Option C): Gestational hypertension along with any of the following features:

  • Proteinuria
  • Thrombocytopenia
  • Renal insufficiency
  • Liver involvement
  • Cerebral symptoms
  • Pulmonary edema
  • Eclampsia: Pre-eclampsia + seizures and or coma
Gestational Hypertension Pre-Eclampsia Chronic Hypertension in pregnancy
Rise in BP >140/90 mmHg after 20 weeks of pregnancy Rise in BP >140/90 mmHg after 20 weeks of pregnancy Previously known hypertensive or BP >140/90 mmHg before 20 weeks of gestation
No Proteinuria Proteinuria present (>300 mg in 24 hrs urine or >30 mg/dl in the random urine sample or urine dipstick 1+) No proteinuria
BP returns to normal within 12 weeks of delivery BP returns to normal within 12 weeks of delivery BP does not come to normal within 12 weeks of delivery

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is associated with normal bone age compared to chronologic age?
questions.solution:
Children with familial short stature have normal bone age compared to chronological age.

Familial short stature refers to short stature that is inherited within families. The parents are also shorter in stature, and there is usually no underlying pathology affecting growth and development. Therefore, bone age assessments are typically consistent with chronologic age in children with familial short stature.

Short stature can be defined as growth below the expected genetic potential or below -2 SD for age and sex. If a child's stature is less than -3 SD below the average for their age and gender it is more likely to indicate pathological short stature. A child's height between -2 and -3 SD is more likely due to physiological, i.e. familial or constitutional short stature.

The 2 types of normal variants of short stature are as follows:

  • Constitutional delay: Bone age < Chronological age
  • Familial short stature: Bone age = Chronological age

Bone age is more than chronological age in precocious puberty. Bone age is less than chronological age in constitutional delay, undernutrition, endocrinologic short stature, and systemic illness.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is not associated with elevated brain natriuretic peptide (BNP)?
questions.solution:
Out of the given conditions, the elevation of BNP is not seen in asthma.

Atrial natriuretic peptide (ANP) and B-type natriuretic peptide (BNP) are stored in the atrial and the ventricular myocytes respectively. They are released from these cells when there is distension of the respective chambers because of fluid overload. These peptides cause the excretion of sodium and water by preventing their reabsorption in the renal tubules, and by inhibiting the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system (RAAS). They also cause vasodilation of the systemic arteries.

ANP and BNP thus oppose sodium and water retention in hypervolemic states. However, their actions are not sufficient to prevent edema. Elevated levels of ANP and BNP will be seen in any case when there is fluid overload, such as heart failure (option D) and cirrhosis with ascites (option C).

COPD is characterized by the destruction of the alveolar septa and airway inflammation. Improper gas exchange causes pulmonary vasoconstriction, and over a period of time, there is development of pulmonary hypertension. The right ventricle now has to pump against increased resistance. This leads to decompensation and eventually right heart failure, termed cor pulmonale. Levels of BNP correlate with the severity of right heart dysfunction. 

Other conditions that might be associated with elevated BNP:

  • Myocarditis and cardiomyopathy
  • Valvular heart disease
  • Acute pulmonary embolism (due to right heart failure)
  • Renal insufficiency
  • Hyperaldosteronism

questions.text: A 26-year-old nulligravid patient came to the clinic complaining of irregular bleeding for the past month. What is the next best investigation you would perform?
questions.solution:
The next best investigation for a nulligravid patient presenting with irregular bleeding is a urine pregnancy test.

The first investigation to be done in a case of abnormal uterine bleeding (AUB) in the reproductive age group (15-49 years) is urine β-hCG estimation. This is done to rule out pregnancy.

A urine pregnancy test detects pregnancy by identifying the presence of the hormone human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG), which is produced by the developing placenta shortly after a fertilized egg implants in the uterine wall. The test contains antibodies that specifically bind to hCG, typically providing a visible result when the hormone is detected. hCG levels rise rapidly in early pregnancy, allowing the test to indicate pregnancy as early as one to two weeks after conception. This sensitivity makes urine hCG tests a reliable early indicator of pregnancy.

In the reproductive age group, anovulatory uterine bleeding is encountered less often. Therefore, pregnancy must be excluded. Pregnancy complications such as miscarriage, ectopic pregnancies, and molar pregnancies may present with AUB, hence, these need to be ruled out by urine β-hCG levels. This is done for all women in the reproductive age group. 

The urine pregnancy test is non-invasive, cost-effective, and provides rapid results, making it an essential initial step in the diagnostic workup.

Other investigations to be done for AUB are:

  • Pap smear: to rule out cervical cancer and preinvasive lesions (CIN). Cervical cancer screening should start at age 21. Women aged 21–29 should have a Pap smear every 3 years, while women aged 30-65 should have both HPV and Pap co-test every 5 years.
  • Transabdominal ultrasound: to visualise the pelvic organs and lesions such as endometrial hyperplasia, polyps, fibroids, etc.
  • Transvaginal ultrasound: to visualise the pelvic organs. It is done after evaluating β-hCG. This is more comfortable for a patient than a transabdominal ultrasound, as it doesn't require a full bladder.  is the first-line investigation in a patient with post-menopausal bleeding. All postmenopausal women with abnormal uterine bleeding should be evaluated for endometrial malignancy since age is a significant risk factor for this.

questions.text: During a laparoscopic cholecystectomy, the surgeon is attempting to identify the Calot’s triangle. Identify the marked structure.
questions.solution:
In the given intra-op image during laparoscopic cholecystectomy the structure marked is a cystic artery.

During Laparoscopic cholecystectomy, the importance of achieving a critical view of safety is paramount for safe ligation and division of cystic duct and artery.

A critical view of safety can be achieved by following these 3 principles:

Three criteria are required to achieve the critical view of safety:

  • The hepatocystic triangle is cleared of fat and fibrous tissue. The hepatocystic triangle is defined as the triangle formed by the cystic duct, the common hepatic duct, and the inferior edge of the liver. The common bile duct and common hepatic duct do not have to be exposed.
  • The lower one-third of the gallbladder is separated from the liver to expose the cystic plate. The cystic plate is also known as liver bed of the gallbladder and lies in the gallbladder fossa.
  • Two and only two structures should be seen entering the gallbladder.

The inferior surface of the liver does not form the boundary of Calot’s triangle. It forms the superior boundary of the hepatobiliary triangle.

The boundaries of Calot’s triangle are: 3C's

  • Medially – Common hepatic duct
  • Inferiorly – Cystic duct
  • Superior – Cystic artery

Related Pearl: Calot's triangle and hepatobiliary triangle

Boundaries Calot's Triangle Hepatobiliary Triangle

Superiorly

 Superior border of the Cystic artery Inferior surface of the Liver

Medially

 Common Hepatic Duct

Inferiorly

 Cystic duct

Importance: 

Contents of Calot’s triangle:

  • The cystic artery—artery supplying the gallbladder
  • Lymph node of Lund—sentinel lymph node for the gallbladder

questions.text: What ratio of chest compressions to rescue breaths is given during CPR in an adult if 2 rescuers are present?
questions.solution:
During cardiopulmonary resuscitation of adults, the ratio of chest compression to rescue breaths is 30:2 irrespective of the number of rescuers.

In infants and children, the ratio is 30:2 for a single rescuer and 15:2 if 2 or more rescuers are present.

Related Pearl: High quality CPR for adults

  • Push hard: 5-6cm depth
  • Push fast: 100-120/min frequency
  • Allow for complete chest recoil
  • Minimize interruptions in compressions <10 seconds
  • Avoid excessive ventilation
  • Rotate compressor every 2 min or earlier if fatigued
  • If no advanced airway, 30:2 compression-ventilation ratio

Attempt to improve CPR quality if :

  • Quantitative waveform capnography - PETCO2 <10mmHg, 
  • Intra-arterial pressure - If relaxation phase (diastolic) pressure <20mmHg

Related Pearl: Basic Life Support (BLS) Algorithm

Related Pearl: Adult cardiac arrest algorithm (Updated as per 2020 guidelines)

questions.text: The World health organisation(WHO) definition of blindness is ________.

choices.text: Best corrected visual acuity of less than 1/60 in the better eye
Best corrected visual acuity of less than 3/60 in the better eye
Presenting visual acuity of worse than 3/60 in the better eye
Presenting visual acuity of worse than 6/60 in the better eye

questions.solution:
WHO has recently revised its definition for blindness. As per the new definition, blindness is defined as presenting visual acuity of worse than 3/60 or a corresponding visual field loss to less than 10° in the better eye.

Refractive error is the main cause of visual impairment in ages 0-49 years, followed by cataracts, amblyopia, and corneal opacity. However, in the age group >50 years, cataract is the major cause, followed by refractive errors and surgical complications of cataract. 

Definitions of blindness and visual impairment as per WHO: 

 

Blindness



 Presenting visual acuity <3/60 
Mild visual impairment 


 Presenting visual acuity <6/12 – 6/18
Moderate visual impairment (MVI) Presenting visual acuity <6/18 – 6/60 
Severe visual impairment (SVI) Presenting visual acuity <6/60 – 3/60

questions.text: According to Caldwell and Moloy's classification of the pelvis, convergent sidewalls are associated with:
questions.solution:
According to Caldwell and Moloy's classification of the pelvis, convergent sidewalls are associated with the android pelvis.

The female pelvis can be divided into 4 types based on the pelvic inlet's shape as follows:

  • Gynecoid
  • Anthropoid
  • Android
  • Platypelloid

questions.text: Which of the following anaesthetic agents act on NMDA receptors?
questions.solution:
Ketamine is a phencyclidine derivative that inhibits NMDA (N-methyl-D-aspartate) receptors resulting in a decrease in excitatory stimulation by glutamate in the brain. It is a strong analgesic and amnestic agent. 

On the cardiovascular system, it directly has a cardio-depressive effect and indirectly stimulates it by activating the sympathetic system and inhibiting the vagus nerve. It predominantly shows a stimulatory effect hence causing tachycardia, increased cardiac output, and increased systemic and pulmonary hypertension.

On the respiratory system, it has a bronchodilator effect on bronchial smooth muscles. It increases salivary secretion and bronchial secretion. It also acts on other systems and increases the intracranial and intraocular pressures.

Uses:

  • Ketamine is the intravenous agent of choice for patients with shock, low cardiac output states, and reactive airway diseases.
  • It is also used in patients with congenital heart diseases, especially with right-to-left shunts
  • Perioperative analgesia

Ketamine should be avoided in patients with a history of seizures, psychiatric illness, or vascular aneurysms. It is also contraindicated in open-eye injuries and eye surgeries.

Adverse effects:

  • Hallucination is the most common side effect of ketamine.
  • Emergence reaction (vivid dreaming, illusion, etc)
  • Increases brain oxygen consumption and metabolic rate leading to increased intracranial tension.

Other options:

Option A: Propofol facilitates the inhibitory neurotransmission by action on GABA-A receptors. It has a rapid onset of action (within 15 sec). Induction dose is usually 1-2 mg/ kg and the maintenance dose is 100-200 µg/ kg/ min. Propofol is formulated as a lipid emulsion and appears as a milky white liquid. It has antiemetic properties which help reduce post-operative nausea and vomiting.

Option C: Midazolam is a benzodiazepine that facilitates GABA-A receptors' action by increasing the frequency of opening of GABA-mediated chloride channels. It is used in treating seizures and is used in daycare surgeries as an induction agent due to its short half-life. 

Option D: Thiopentone sodium belongs to the barbiturate group which acts on the GABA-A receptors. This site is separate from the GABA-A site to which benzodiazepines bind. They potentiate the action of GABA in increasing the duration of openings of chloride-specific ion channels.

questions.text: Identify the condition shown in the image below.
questions.solution:
The given radiograph shows a triple bubble sign which is seen in jejunal atresia. 

Jejunal atresia is a congenital anomaly which presents with bilious vomiting and abdominal distension soon after birth. A small amount of meconium may be passed despite the atresia. Plain X-ray abdomen shows multiple air-fluid levels, known as the triple bubble sign. Contrast study is the next best investigation to exclude other large bowel anomalies. In most cases, the distal end of the dilated proximal small bowel is resected and a primary end-to-end anastomosis is done. If the proximal bowel is extremely dilated, it may need to be tapered to the distal bowel before anastomosis

Other options:

Option A: Duodenal atresia occurs due to failure of vacuolization of the solid duodenum. Neonates with duodenal atresia usually present with bilious vomiting and abdominal distention. Plain X-ray shows two foci of gas, one in the stomach and the other in the duodenum, known as the double bubble sign.

Option C: Small bowel obstruction shows dilated bowel loops with multiple air fluid levels. Supine X-ray shows a row of gas bubbles trapped between the valvulae coniventes, within fluid-filled dilated small bowels, resembling a string of beads.
 
Option D: Congenital hypertrophic pyloric stenosis presents between 2 and 6 weeks of age with projectile, non-bilious vomiting, and abdominal distension. The hypertrophied pylorus may present as an olive-shaped mass. The diagnostic criteria for pyloric stenosis are a muscle thickness of ≥4 mm and a pyloric length of ≥16 mm in ultrasound.

Related Pearl: Radiological findings in various GI disorders

Duodenal atresia: Double bubble sign

 

Jejunal and ileal atresia: Multiple air-fluid levels (plain erect X-ray abdomen) presenting as triple bubble sign. 

 

Congenital hypertrophic pyloric stenosis: Single enlarged gastric gas bubble - single bubble sign

 

Sigmoid volvulus: Coffee bean sign 

 

Achalasia cardia: Bird-beak sign

questions.text:
A 45-year-old male patient came with pain in the left loin. An intravenous urogram was done and the image is shown below. There is non-visualisation of the right kidney. Which of the following is a true statement?

DMSA- Dimercaptosuccinic acid

choices.text: Visualized kidney has a remnant function of 10%.
This abnormality can be due to compression of ureter by artery/vein on the same side
The best test to evaluate the functioning of a kidney is through a Tc99 DMSA scan

questions.solution:
The given intravenous urogram (IVU) shows a dilated pelvicalyceal system and ureter on the left side suggesting a left-sided hydroureteronephrosis which occurs secondary to compression of distal ureter by a vessel- artery/vein.

Hydroureteronephrosis is a pathological condition which occurs due to dilatation of the renal pelvis and ureter secondary to a distal obstruction. The extramural causes of hydroureteronephrosis include tumours from adjacent structures (e.g., cervix, prostate, rectum, colon, or cecum), retrocaval ureter, aberrant renal vessels, idiopathic retroperitoneal fibrosis (Ormond’s disease). (See pearl attached). If the obstruction is not relieved, it can lead to kidney scarring and permanent kidney damage with the compromise of glomerular and tubular function.

Other options:

Option A: Renal function cannot be predicted using IVU alone. 

Option C:  Renal function is best assessed by the Tc-99m MAG3 (mercaptoacetyltriglycine) scan. It is eliminated through the kidney through both glomeruli filtration and tubular excretion and is a measure of both. Tc-99m DMSA (dimercaptosuccinic acid) is used to evaluate renal structure and morphology, particularly in pediatric imaging for detecting scarring and pyelonephritis. It is an ideal agent for the assessment of the renal cortex. Tc-99m DTPA (diethylene-triamine-pentaacetate) is cleared only via glomeruli with no tubular excretion. Hence, it is used for direct measurement of GFR.

Option D: The characteristic sign in the given IVP depicts cobra head/ adder head deformity seen in the ureterocele.

Related Pearl: IVU signs and associated conditions

Medullary sponge kidney 

  • Bouquet of flowers/ paintbrush appearance
  • It refers to the cystic dilatation of the distal collecting tubules

Duplex kidney

  • Drooping lily sign
  • It refers to the inferolateral displacement of the lower pole due to an obstructed upper pole in a duplicated collecting system

Horseshoe kidney

  • Handshake sign - due to the position of the lower poles closer to the spine, and the lower calyces closer to each other
  • Flower vase sign - due to medially rotated calyces

Retroperitoneal fibrosis

  • Maiden waist deformity 
  • It refers to the medially drawn ureters caused by fibrosis at the lumbosacral junction

Retrocaval ureter 

  • Fish hook / Reverse J deformity 
  • Right ureter hooks behind the IVC as it passes posterior to it

Ureterocele

  • Cobra/ Adder head appearance
  • It refers to the dilation of the distal ureter

Transitional cell carcinoma of the ureter

  • Goblet sign
  • It is due to the focal dilation of the ureter by an intraluminal mass

Related Pearl: Causes of Hydronephrosis

Unilateral hydronephrosis

Extramural obstruction

  • Tumor from adjacent structures, e.g., cervix, prostate, rectum, colon, or cecum
  • Retrocaval ureter
  • Aberrant renal vessels
  • Idiopathic retroperitoneal fibrosis (Ormond’s disease)

Intramural obstruction

  • Congenital PUJ obstruction - most common congenital cause
  • Congenital stenosis
  • Ureterocele
  • Ureteric stricture - iatrogenic/ inflammatory
  • Neoplasm of the ureter or bladder involving the ureteric orifice

Intraluminal obstruction

  • Renal stones - most common acquired unilateral cause
  • Sloughed papilla in papillary necrosis (especially, in patients with diabetes, analgesic abuse, or sickle cell disease)

Bilateral hydronephrosis

Congenital

  • Posterior urethral valves (associated with pulmonary hypoplasia)
  • Urethral atresia
  • PUJ obstruction

Acquired     

  • Benign prostatic hypertrophy or carcinoma of the prostate
  • Idiopathic retroperitoneal fibrosis (Ormond's disease)
  • Postoperative bladder neck scarring
  • Urethral stricture
  • Phimosis

questions.text: A 33-year-old male patient was brought to the trauma centre following a road traffic accident. He was walking on the street when a car hit him from the side and severely injured his left knee.  An  X-ray of the knee joint showing distal femur and proximal tibia-fibula was done. Identify the given fracture:
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette and the x-ray evidence a Bumper fracture.

Bumper fracture is the fracture of the tibial plateau resulting from impact with a car bumper. It is due to a forced valgus injury of the knee when the car hits from the side. 

Other options:

Option A: Patellar Sleeve Fractures are rare injuries seen in children between 8 and 12 years of age characterized by separation of the cartilage "sleeve" from the ossified patella. 

Option C: Pilon fracture refers to a comminuted intra-articular fracture of the distal tibia. These fractures are most often due to high-energy trauma such as a motor vehicle accident or a fall from a height

option D Chauffeur fracture:  The image shows a fracture of the radial styloid process, i.e., Chauffeur fracture. It is caused either by direct trauma to the wrist or traumatic radial deviation of the wrist

Related Pearl: Named fractures of the upper limb

Colle's fracture: Extra-articular fracture of the distal radius with dorsal angulation of the distal bone fragment.

 

Galeazzi fracture-dislocation: Fracture of the lower third of the radius and subluxation of the distal radio-ulnar joint.

 

Monteggia fracture-dislocation: Fracture of the shaft of the ulna with dislocation of a proximal radio-ulnar joint.

 

Barton’s fracture: Intra-articular fracture of the distal radius.

 

Rolando's fracture: Intra-articular comminuted fracture of the base of the first metacarpal with a T or Y configuration.

 

Smith's fracture: Reverse Colles' fracture. Extra-articular fracture of the distal one-third of the radius with palmar or ventral displacement (Image below).

 

Chauffeur's fracture or the Hutchinson fracture: Fracture of the radial styloid.

Essex–Lopresti lesion: Fracture of the radial head with disruption of the interosseous membrane and distal radial ulnar joint ligaments.

Nightstick fracture: Isolated fracture of radial or ulnar bone.  

Related Pearl: Named fractures of the lower limb

Bumper fracture  Comminuted fracture of lateral condyle of tibia 
Pilon fracture  Comminuted intra-articular fracture of the distal end of the tibia 
Tillaux fracture  Avulsion fracture of tibia by the anterior tibiofibular ligament
Runner's fracture  Fracture of distal shaft of fibula 
Pott’s fracture  Bimalleolar ankle fracture
Cotton’s fracture  Trimalleolar ankle fracture
Aviator's fracture  Fracture of neck of talus
Chopart’s fracture  Between talonavicular and calcaneocuboid joints 
Lisfranc’s fracture-dislocation  Fracture of metatarsal bases with associated tarsometatarsal dislocation
March fracture  Neck of 2nd or 3rd metatarsal
Jone's fracture

 Extra-articular fracture at the base of the 5th metatarsal
Dancer’s fracture  Fracture of distal shaft of the fifth metatarsal

questions.text: A male patient aged 68 years comes to the emergency room with a feeling of impending doom and palpitations. The emergency physician orders an ECG. What is your diagnosis based on this ECG?
questions.solution:
The given ECG shows ST elevation in leads V1-V4 which is suggestive of acute anteroseptal myocardial infarction (MI). ST depression in the leads III and aVF signifies an old inferior wall infarction.

Related Pearl: Localisation of MI based on ST elevations in different leads

Extensive anterior - I, aVL, V1-V6

Lateral - I, aVL

Inferior - II, III, aVF

Anteroseptal - V1-V4

Anterolateral - I, aVL, V3-V6

Posterior - ST depression and tall R in V1-V4

questions.text: At what CD4 count is Kaposi sarcoma likely to occur?
questions.solution:
The likelihood of developing Kaposi sarcoma increases when absolute CD4 lymphocyte count is <500/ μL.

Kaposi sarcoma (KS) is a vascular neoplasm caused by human herpesvirus 8 (HHV8) and is very common in patients suffering from acquired immunodeficiency syndrome (AIDS). KS is considered to be an AIDS-defining disease. 

AIDS-associated KS is an AIDS-defining illness and is the most common malignancy associated with HIV infection. Involvement of the oral cavity is most common in AIDS-related KS, but it can be seen in other variants also. Oral KS (OKS) most often involves the hard and soft palate, gingiva, and dorsal tongue with plaques or tumors. The color of the lesions may range from non-pigmented to brownish-red or violaceous.

Other forms of KS include

  • Classic Kaposi sarcoma: It has the following three clinical stages patches, plaques, and nodules.
  • Endemic African KS
  • Transplant-associated KS is more common after solid organ transplant patients receive immunosuppression as compared to marrow or stem-cell transplant patients.

The given images show coalescent red-purple macules and plaques of the skin.

There is no definitive cure but KS is highly radiosensitive and achieves complete response in most cases. In AIDS‐associated KS, instituting highly active antiretroviral therapy (HAART) often (but not always) results in regression of KS. In localized cutaneous KS, excision and cryotherapy can be used. Intra-lesional administration of vinblastine, interferon‐α2b, and imiquimod is also effective.

The image given below shows the absolute CD4 count for various diseases:

Related Pearl: AIDS-defining opportunistic infections and neoplasms found in patients with HIV infection

Infections

  • Protozoal and Helminthic Infections
    • Cryptosporidiosis or Isosporiasis (cystoisosporiasis) - Chronic intestinal
    • Toxoplasmosis (pneumonia or CNS infection)
  • Fungal Infections
    • Candidiasis (esophageal, tracheal, or pulmonary)
    • Cryptococcosis (CNS infection)
    • Coccidioidomycosis (disseminated)
    • Pneumocystosis (pneumonia or disseminated infection)
    • Histoplasmosis (disseminated)
  • Bacterial Infections
    • Mycobacteriosis (“atypical,” e.g., Mycobacterium avium-intracellulare) disseminated or extrapulmonary
    • Mycobacterium tuberculosis (pulmonary or extrapulmonary)
    • Nocardiosis (pneumonia, meningitis, disseminated)
    • Salmonella infections, disseminated
  • Viral Infections
    • Cytomegalovirus (pulmonary, intestinal, retinitis, or CNS infections)
    • Herpes simplex virus (localized or disseminated infection)
    • Varicella-zoster virus (localized or disseminated infection)
    • Progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy

Neoplasms

  • Kaposi sarcoma
  • Primary lymphoma of brain
  • Invasive cancer of uterine cervix 

 

One-liners about HIV

  • Sexual contact is the least efficacious yet most common mode of spread of HIV infection
  • ELISA is used for the detection of antibodies against viral proteins. This is the most sensitive and the best screening test for the diagnosis of AIDS.
  • Western blot is the most specific or the confirmatory test for HIV.
  • Candidiasis is the most common fungal infection in patients with AIDS.
  • Cytomegalovirus (CMV) chorioretinitis exclusively in patients with CD4+ T cell counts less than 50 per microliter.
  • Toxoplasma gondii causes encephalitis and is responsible for 50% of all mass lesions in the central nervous system.
  • John Cunningham virus (JC virus) is a human papovavirus that causes progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy.
  • Persistent diarrhea in AIDS is caused by Cryptosporidium, Isospora belli, or microsporidia.
  • AIDS-dementia complex is the most common neurological manifestation of HIV infection.
  • Inflammatory myopathy is the commonest skeletal muscle disorder in HIV.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male came to OPD with a complaint of midline neck swelling which has been persistent for many years. Recently, it has become painful and inflamed. There has been a clear watery discharge from the wound since last week. On examination, the swelling moves with protrusion of the tongue and also on deglutition.  Which of the following statements is true about this condition?

choices.text: Untreated condition may lead to squamous cell carcinoma
They are remnants of thyroid tissue
Acid fast bacilli (AFB) staining should be done to come to a diagnosis

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of a thyroglossal cyst which has been complicated by a sinus fistula. These are the remnants of thyroid tissue. 

A thyroglossal duct cyst is a congenital midline neck swelling that typically presents during childhood. It represents the persistence of the thyroglossal tract. It can occur anywhere along the migratory course of the duct: 

Beneath foramen cecum → Floor of mouth → Suprahyoid → Region of thyroid cartilage → Subhyoid (most common site)

Clinically, the cyst moves upwards on swallowing and on tongue protrusion. This indicates attachment to the hyoid bone. Swelling is smooth, soft, fluctuant (cystic), non-tender, mobile, and often transilluminate.

The most common complication is infection. Thyroglossal fistula is an acquired condition that either follows infection of the cyst which bursts open or due to inadequate removal of the cyst.

Option A: An untreated thyroglossal duct cyst can rarely lead to malignant transformation, with papillary thyroid carcinoma (85%) being the most common type. It is not associated with squamous cell carcinoma.

Option B: Sistrunk’s operation is performed to excise the cyst. It involves the excision of the whole thyroglossal tract, involving removal of the body of the hyoid bone, and the suprahyoid tract.

Option D: AFB staining is required when a suspicion of cervical lymph node tuberculosis. They present with the associated systemic signs and symptoms of TB. Swellings are laterally located and don't move with protrusion of the tongue or deglutition.

questions.text: The following image depicts a particular type of cataract. What history should be elicited from the patient to come to a diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above image characteristically depicts a rosette cataract. It typically follows closed globe injuries (blunt trauma), and hence is also known as the concussion cataract.

Concussion cataract

  1. Early rosette cataract - either in posterior or anterior cortex; feathery lines of opacities along the star-shaped suture lines.
  2. Late rosette cataract - in posterior cortex; 1-2 years after trauma; smaller and compact than early rosette.

Other options:

Option A: Penetrating trauma is associated with sunflower cataract.

Option B: Steroid use is associated with posterior subcapsular cataract.

Option C: Diabetes is associated with snowflake/ snowstorm cataract.

Related Pearl: Diseases and Their Associated Cataracts

Disease

Type of cataract

Myotonic dystrophy

Christmas tree cataract

Wilson’s disease

Copper deposition (Chalcosis)

Penetrating trauma

Sunflower cataract

Diabetes mellitus

Snowflake/ Snowstorm cataract

questions.text: A 3-year-old child presented to your OPD with genu varum and softening of skull bones. There is bony depression over the chest. What is the most likely deficiency?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario with genu varum, craniotabes and Harrison groove of the chest with the given lab parameters suggests rickets caused by vitamin D deficiency.

Rickets occurs due to a nutritional deficiency in vitamin D. Decrease in vitamin D levels leads to decreased calcium and phosphate due to reduced absorption. The decreased calcium stimulates increased parathyroid hormone(PTH) production. ALP level is increased as it is involved in bone mineralization.

Clinical features of rickets include:

  • General features include malnourishment, abdominal distension, proximal muscle weakness, etc.
  • Head: Softening of the skull bones, called craniotabes, delayed closure of fontanels.
  • Chest: Rachitic rosary, i.e. widening of the costochondral junctions that give the feeling of rosary beads on palpation. Harrison's groove, a horizontal groove in the lower chest, may appear from the inward pull of the softened ribs by the diaphragm during respiration.
  • Vertebral column abnormalities like scoliosis, kyphosis, and lordosis
  • In the distal extremities widening of the wrists and ankles, varus/ valgus deformities, windswept deformity (valgus on the side and varus on the contralateral side), anterior tibial bowing.

The laboratory findings in rickets show normal/decreased serum calcium, decreased phosphorous, elevated PTH, and increased ALP levels

Metabolic bone disorders due to nutritional deficiencies include:

  • Vitamin D deficiency leads to Rickets- in children
  • Osteomalacia- in adults
  • Secondary hyperparathyroidism 
  • Vitamin C deficiency leads to scurvy

Other options:

Option A: Vitamin A deficiency- can lead to night blindness and recurrent childhood infections- diarrhoea, and respiratory infections.

Option C: Vitamin C deficiency - can lead to scurvy which has manifestations due to poor collagen synthesis- dry skin, poor wound healing, swelling of the knee and ankle, and radiographic findings of a radiolucent band (Trümmerfeld zone) under a white line of Fränkel.

Option D: Vitamin K deficiency- can be seen in neonates due to non-colonised gut, and in adults with chronic antibiotics-lead to manifestations of clotting disorders- purpura, ecchymoses.

Related Pearl: Radiological features of rickets

Radiological features of rickets:

  • Loss of provisional zone of calcification: earliest radiological finding of rickets. 
  • Delayed appearance of the epiphysis
  • Widening of growth plate: normal width of growth is 2-4mm. It is increased in cases of rickets due to excessive accumulation of uncalcified osteoid at the growth plate.
  • Cupping of metaphysis: normally metaphysis meets epiphysis as a smooth line of sclerosis. But in rickets the line is absent and the metaphyseal ends appear irregular and the cartilage accumulating in the growth plate creates a depression in the metaphysis causing cupping.
  • Fraying: indistinct margins of the metaphysis
  • Bowing of diaphysis, with thinning of cortices
  • In healing rickets, zone of calcification becomes denser. 

The above features are prominent at the growth plates where growth is greatest:

  • Knee: distal femur, proximal tibia
  • Wrist: especially the ulna
  • Anterior rib ends: rachitic rosary

The below image shows bowing of legs in rickets.

Related Pearl: Important Clinical Features of Rickets

Related Pearl: Radiological features of scurvy

Radiological features of scurvy:

  • Generalised osteopenia
  • Pencil-point cortex: Cortical thinning
  • Periosteal reaction due to subperiosteal hemorrhage
  • Scorbutic rosary: Expansion of the costochondral junctions
  • Hemarthrosis
  • Wimberger ring: Circular, opaque radiological shadow surrounding epiphyseal centers of ossification, which may result from bleeding
  • Frenkel line: Dense zone of provisional calcification 
  • Trummerfeld zone: Lucent metaphyseal band underlying Frankel line
  • Pelken spur: Metaphyseal spurs which result in cupping of the metaphysis

questions.text: A patient is brought to the casualty following a road traffic accident.  He is tachypneic and uses accessory neck muscles for respiration. His BP is 90/60 mm Hg. On percussion, the right chest is hyper-resonant. On auscultation, breath sounds could not be heard on the right chest. An urgent chest X-ray is done. What is the next best step of management?

choices.text: Tube thoracostomy at 5th intercostal space anterior to mid-axillary line
Needle decompression at 5th intercostal space anterior to mid-axillary line
Needle decompression at 5th intercostal space in the mid-clavicular line
Needle decompression at 2nd intercostal space anterior to mid-axillary line

questions.solution:
The above patient with hemodynamic instability, tachypnea and hyper-resonant sounds on percussion with absent breath sounds on auscultation along with the radiolucency and mediastinal shift on X-ray is suggestive of tension pneumothorax. Immediate management is done with needle decompression or needle thoracostomy i.e. insertion of a wide-bore needle in the 5th ICS anterior to the midaxillary line.

Tension pneumothorax is a life-threatening emergency when air leaks from the lungs into the pleural cavity and cannot escape. This leads to compression of the lung field with mediastinal shift and collapse of lung parenchyma. This can be diagnosed clinically with high index of suspicion and immediate decompression with wide bore needle in the 5th intercostal space should be done. 

Definitive management - tube thoracostomy or chest tube insertion in the 5th ICS in the triangle of safety.

Triangle of safety:

The boundaries are 

  • Anteriorly - lateral border of the pectoralis major
  • Posteriorly- latissimus dorsi
  • Inferiorly- a line perpendicular to the nipple going to the back

For pediatric patients, needle decompression is done at the midclavicular line in the 2nd intercostal space.

The images below show the triangle of safety and technique of chest drain insertion.

questions.text: Identify the contraceptive device given below:
questions.solution:
The contraceptive device shown in the image above is a Lippe's loop.

Lippes Loop is a 1st generation IUD that comes in four sizes – A, B, C and D. It is an S-shaped device, usually made of polyethene. The tail, which is usually made of fine nylon, projects into the vagina after insertion. The larger loops, used in multiparous women, have higher rates of removal due to side effects but have greater anti-fertility effects.

The Lippes Loop has a minimal amount of barium sulphate in it to allow for X-ray observation.

IUD - Intrauterine devices are contraceptive devices inserted into the uterine cavity. The different generations of IUDs include:

  • First-generation IUDs : Inert or non-medicated devices like Lippes loop.
  • Second-generation IUDs : Medicated with metallic elements like copper eg: Cu-T-220 C, Nova T, Multi-load Cu-250, Multi-load Cu-375.
  • Third-generation IUDs: Hormone-containing IUDs like Progestasert, Mirena (LNG-20).

The various IUDs are shown in the image below:

questions.text: Which of the following features is associated with vitamin A deficiency?
questions.solution:
Bitot spots are triangular, pearly-white or yellowish, and foamy spots on the bulbar conjunctiva on either side of the cornea are associated with Vitamin A deficiency.

Option A: Pinguecula is a degenerative condition of the conjunctiva, characterized by the formation of a yellowish-white patch on the bulbar conjunctiva near the limbus. It usually presents as a triangular patch on the nasal side, with the triangle's apex commonly pointed away from the cornea. 

Option C: Pterygium is a degenerative condition of the sub-conjunctival tissue. It is a connective tissue disorder and is never inflammatory.  It is made up of three parts: a "cap" (an avascular halo-like zone at the advancing edge), a head, and a body. It occurs due to exposure to radiation: UV-B. The most common site is nasal.

Option D: Stocker's line - deposition of iron on the advancing edge is seen in Pterygium. 

Related Pearl: WHO grading of Vitamin A deficiency

The term xerophthalmia is reserved to cover all the ocular manifestations of vitamin A deficiency.

Stage Features Pathophysiology
XN Night blindness Lack of rhodopsin
X1A Conjunctival Xerosis Conjunctival epithelial alteration, loss of goblet cells
X1B Bitot’s spots Conjunctival keratinization and plaque formation
X2 Corneal xerosis Corneal epithelial alteration
X3A Corneal ulceration/ Keratomalacia affecting <1/3rd of the corneal surface Liquefaction of corneal stroma
X3B Corneal ulceration/ Keratomalacia affecting >1/3rd of the corneal surface              -
XS Corneal scar              -
XF Xerophthalmic fundus Degeneration of the retinal pigment epithelium

The first symptom of xerophthalmia is nyctalopia.

The first sign of xerophthalmia is conjunctival xerosis.

The pathognomonic feature of xerophthalmia is the appearance of Bitot's spots.

Note:

Up to the level of Stage 2, the manifestations are reversible if treated with vitamin A supplements.

However, active conjunctival xerosis and Bitot’s spots begin to resolve within 2—5 days after supplementation. Most will disappear within 2 weeks, although a significant proportion of temporal lesions may persist in shrunken form and may therefore not be completely reversible.

questions.text:
During your labor room postings, you perform a cardiotocography (CTG) on a woman who is in labor at 38 weeks of gestation. The tracing that you obtain is as shown in the image below. Which among the following may cause this finding?
  1. Placental abruption
  2. Excessive use of oxytocin
  3. Epidural anesthesia
  4. Fetal head compression
  5. Umbilical cord compression
questions.solution:
The given CTG shows late decelerations. The fetal heart rate begins to drop after the end of uterine contraction. It is mostly associated with uteroplacental insufficiency and fetal hypoxia.

Causes of late decelerations:

  • Placental pathologies like - post-maturity, hypertension, diabetes, placental abruption
  • Excessive uterine contractions
  • Excessive use of oxytocin
  • Epidural anesthesia

The CTG given below shows early decelerations. The deceleration coincides with the uterine contractions. It seen in fetal head compression.

The CTG given below shows variable decelerations as seen in umbilical cord compression.

The CTG given below shows a sinusoidal pattern. It resembles a sine wave. It is often associated with fetal anemia, fetomaternal hemorrhage, and fetal acidosis.

questions.text: An alcoholic male patient diagnosed with hollow viscus perforation is taken up for laparotomy. Intraoperatively, a 2 cm-sized perforation is seen in the gastric region as shown below. How can this patient be managed?
questions.solution:
The given scenario of an alcoholic male patient of gastric perforation showing intra-op large 2 cm size perforation can be managed by an Omental pedicle repair.

Gastroduodenal perforations are a common surgical emergency in developing countries. Causes: Peptic ulcer disease (PUD), Smoking, alcohol, chronic analgesic use. Patients present with hypotension and signs and symptoms of peritonitis- tenderness, guarding and rigidity. Management: Multiple surgical options exist depending on the perforation's location and size. Larger perforations and ulcers with fibrotic edges can be managed by an omental pedicle flap repair. A tongue of omentum is brought up to cover the ulcer defect and secured with a series of interrupted sutures. (Modified Graham's patch)

Option A: Small subcentric perforations with healthy margins can undergo primary repair and buttressed with an omental patch. (Graham's repair)

Option C: Removal of gastric antrum (antrectomy) with gastroduodenostomy is Billroth I reconstruction. It was done historically and avoided now due to higher morbidity with high rates of post-gastrectomy syndromes. In PUD, the duodenum may be scarred as well.

Option D: In Billroth II, two-thirds of the stomach is removed, the duodenal stump is closed and the stomach is anastomosed to the jejunum. It is now reserved for gastric malignancy and perforations associated with malignancy. It has higher rates of post-gastrectomy syndromes.

questions.text: Which of the following signs suggests magnesium sulfate toxicity?
questions.solution:
Loss of deep tendon reflexes like knee jerk reflex is a sign of magnesium toxicity.

Repeat injections of MgSO4 are given only if knee jerks are present, urine output exceeds 30 ml/hr, and the and respiratory rate is more than 12/min.

Monitoring of magnesium toxicity:

  • Loss of deep tendon reflexes
  • Urine output (<30 ml/h) (Option B)
  • Decreased respiratory rate (<12 per minute) (Option C)
  • Chest pain, heart block

Management of magnesium toxicity:

  • Stop magnesium therapy
  • Estimation of serum magnesium and creatinine levels
  • Injection of calcium gluconate 10 ml (10% solution) IV

Side effects of MgSO4:

  • Anuria
  • Pulmonary edema

Other options:

Option D: Superficial reflexes like plantar reflex are not used to assess magnesium toxicity.

questions.text: A 65-year-old  female patient presented with sudden painless loss of vision. She has been a known diabetic for 12 years. Ophthalmoscopy shows evidence of loss of fundal features, floating debris and a dark red glow. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient with long-standing diabetes with sudden, painless vision loss, floating debris and a dark red glow on fundoscopic examination is most likely suffering from vitreous haemorrhage. 

Proliferative diabetic retinopathy, which can arise in people with long-term diabetes mellitus, is a common risk factor for vitreous haemorrhage caused by the breakage of the fragile blood vessels on the retina's surface. Intravitreal blood blocks light from reaching the retina, resulting in patients experiencing sudden onset cloudy vision, sometimes with a red tint, or vision loss. 

Vitreous haemorrhage has a variable presentation depending on the severity of the haemorrhage. The mild haemorrhage causes sudden onset floaters and diffuse blurring of vision, but may not affect visual acuity, whilst a dense bleed may result in sudden painless loss of vision.

Causes: Acute posterior vitreous detachment is associated either with a retinal tear or avulsion of a peripheral vessel. Proliferative diabetic retinopathy, retinal vein occlusion and sickle cell disease.

The investigation of choice for vitreous haemorrhage is an ultrasound B-scan.

Treatment: Patients with vitreous haemorrhage can be adequately managed with bed rest to prevent additional bleeding and elevation of the head to promote blood settling away from the visual axis and correcting the underlying cause of the bleeding. (eg. photocoagulation for proliferative retinopathy). Vitreoretinal surgery with photocoagulation is indicated in patients with persistent vitreal haemorrhage.

Other options

Option A: Patients with retinal detachment can develop floaters and have acute vision loss. However, photopsia is common and fundoscopy reveals an elevated retina with folds or tears. An image showing retinal detachment at the fovea and the macula is shown below.

Option C:  Patients with macular degeneration typically have painless central blurring of vision which is progressive as opposed to vitreous hemorrhage which is acute in its presentation. An image depicting age-related macular degeneration with the presence of drusens is shown below.

Option D: Patients with central retinal vein occlusion can also present with sudden, painless loss of vision but would have scattered, diffuse hemorrhages, disc swelling and cotton wool spots. Image showing central retinal vein occlusion is as follows.

questions.text: A 33-year-old male met with a road traffic accident. There is persistent watery discharge mixed with blood from his nose for 3 days which cannot be sniffed back. Which of the following should not be done in this condition?

choices.text: Plan surgical treatment with functional endoscopic sinus surgery
Bed rest and avoiding strenuous activity

questions.solution:
In the given scenario of a male presenting with watery nasal discharge mixed with blood that cannot be sniffed back following a road traffic accident is suggestive of CSF rhinorrhea. Surgical treatment with functional endoscopic sinus surgery should not be done in this patient.

CSF rhinorrhea refers to the leakage of cerebrospinal fluid into the nose. It can occur as clear fluid or be mixed with blood, particularly in cases of acute head injuries. Fracture of the cribriform plate of the ethmoid is the most common cause of this. Other causes include accidental or surgical trauma, infection and inflammation of the sinuses, neoplasms, and congenital lesions associated with skull base defects or may occur spontaneously.

When CSF rhinorrhea occurs after head trauma, it often contains a mixture of blood, leading to a characteristic appearance known as the double-target sign when collected on a piece of filter paper. This sign presents as a central red spot (indicating blood) surrounded by a lighter peripheral halo.

CSF fluid gushes down on straining and bending forward. It cannot be sniffed back. CSF doesn’t stiffen a handkerchief, but nasal secretions do because of their mucus content.

High-resolution computerized tomography (HRCT) is the investigation of choice for localizing the site of the leak.(Option A)

Beta-2 transferrin protein detection by electrophoresis is a sensitive and specific test for detecting CSF rhinorrhea. Beta trace protein is another protein that is secreted by meninges and choroid plexus and is specific to CSF.

Treatment of CSF rhinorrhea:

  • Bed rest with head elevation.
  • Avoid blowing the nose, sneezing, and straining. (Option C)
  • Prophylactic antibiotics can be administered to prevent meningitis. (Option D)
  • Early cases of post-traumatic CSF rhinorrhea are managed conservatively by placing the patient in a semi-sitting position.
  • Persistent cases may be treated surgically by intracranial or nasal endoscopic approach.(option B)
Feature CSF fluid Nasal secretion
History

Nasal or sinus surgery, Sneezing, nasal stuffiness, head injury, or intracranial tumor

Sneezing, nasal stuffiness, head injury, or itching in the nose, or lacrimation
Flow of discharge

A few drops or a stream of fluid gushes down when bending forward or straining and cannot be sniffed back

 Continuous. No effect on bending forward or straining. Can be sniffed back
Character of discharge

Thin, watery, and clear

Slimy (mucous) or clear (tears)
Sugar content

More than 30 mg/dl

 Less than 10 mg/dl
The presence of beta-2 transferrin and beta-trace proteins

Always present. It is specific to CSF

  Always absent

 

Related Pearl: Features of CSF rhinorrhea

  • Reservoir sign - In CSF rhinorrhea, the fluid which had collected in the sinuses, particularly sphenoid, empties into the nose.
  • Double ring sign or halo sign or target sign - CSF is mixed with blood and collected on a piece of filter paper. It shows a central red spot (blood) and a peripheral lighter halo.

The image below shows the double ring sign in CSF rhinorrhoea:

  • CSF can’t be sniffed back.
  • CSF doesn’t stiffen the handkerchief.

 

Note: The repeated reappearance of pus immediately after cleaning, in the external auditory canal of patients with acute mastoiditis/coalescent mastoiditis is also referred to as Reservoir sign.

questions.text: Which of the following vitamin deficiencies can cause laryngismus stridulus?
questions.solution:
Laryngismus stridulus is primarily associated with a deficiency in vitamin D.

Laryngismus stridulus can be defined as laryngeal spasm caused by the sudden contraction of laryngeal muscles due to a reduced level of calcium. It is likely to be caused by vitamin D deficiency. Vitamin D, also known as cholecalciferol, plays a significant role in calcium and phosphate levels homeostasis. Its active form, calcitriol or  1,25 dihydroxycholecalciferol is produced by sequential hydroxylation in the liver and kidneys. It primarily increases the serum calcium and phosphate levels. Deficiency of vitamin D leads to rickets.

Causes of vitamin D deficiency  :

  • Inadequate sunlight exposure.
  • Poor dietary intake.
  • Malabsorption disorders such as celiac disease.
  • Liver or kidney disorders affecting vitamin D metabolism.
  • Calcium Deficiency: Even with sufficient vitamin D, a diet low in calcium can lead to rickets.
  • Phosphate Deficiency: Rarely, genetic disorders like hypophosphatemic rickets, which affect phosphate metabolism, can cause rickets.

Clinical features include bone pain and tenderness, delayed growth, skeletal deformities -bowed legs (genu varum) or knock knees (genu valgum), thickened wrists and ankles, and a protruding breastbone (pectus carinatum), dental problems muscle spasms, including those affecting the larynx, can occur due to hypocalcemia, and delay in motor milestones. There is increased risk of .

Radiological features show cupping at metaphyses, fraying, and widening of the growth plate.

Daily treatment with oral Vitamin D preparations is recommended, as daily supplementation is more physiological. The duration of treatment is at least 12 weeks. Vitamin D dosage is 2000 I.U in infants and 3000 I.U in children over one year of age. Stoss therapy was earlier used for treating Vitamin D deficiency. Here, 300,000-600,000 IU of vitamin D was administered orally or intramuscularly in 2 or 4 doses over 1 day.

Other options:

Option B: Vitamin K is essential for blood clotting and bone metabolism but is not typically associated with muscle spasms or laryngismus stridulus.
Option C: vitamin E deficiency is rare and primarily affects neurological and muscular systems, leading to symptoms like peripheral neuropathy and ataxia. 
Option D: Vitamin A is important for vision, immune function, and skin health. Deficiency can lead to vision problems and increased susceptibility to infections.

Related Pearl: Vitamin Deficiency States (Water-soluble Vitamins)

Vitamin

Deficiency State

Thiamine (B1)

Beriberi

Wernicke–Korsakoff’s syndrome

Riboflavin (B2)

Cheilosis, Magenta-coloured tongue, 

Glossitis, Seborrheic dermatitis

Niacin (B3)

Pellagra

Dermatitis, Diarrhea, Dementia

Pantothenic acid (B5)

Burning foot syndrome (historically called as "Nutritional melalgia")

Dermatitis, enteritis, alopecia, ataxia

Pyridoxine (B6)

Microcytic anemia, convulsions, depression

Biotin (B7)

Relatively unknown

Dermatitis, atrophic glossitis, alopecia, paraesthesia, muscle pain, anorexia, hallucinations

Cobalamin (B12)

Pernicious anemia, dementia, spinal cord degeneration, homocysteinemia

Ecchymosis, bleeding gums, poor wound healing, fatigue, joint effusion, Scorbutic rosary

questions.text: A 47-year-old man presented with a chronic non-healing painless ulcer over his scalp for 8 years. He gave a history of sustaining electric burns injury to the scalp 8 years back. The examination findings are shown below. Which of the following statements is true?

choices.text: It can progress to squamous cell cancer
Long duration antibiotics will improve the condition

questions.solution:
The given scenario and image show a long-standing ulcer with crusting and irregular borders can progress to Marjolin's ulcer which is an aggressive type of squamous cell carcinoma. 

Marjolin ulcers most commonly arise from burn scars. The most common cell type identified is squamous cell carcinoma. All suspicious lesions should be biopsied. Confirmed cases of Marjolin ulcers should be excised with clear margins. Marjolin ulcers can be prevented with early excision and grafting of burn wounds. The prognosis is poor with a high rate of recurrence. 

SCC is the second most common skin cancer. The primary risk factor and driving force for the development of this common cancer is UV exposure.

Variants : 

  • Bowen's disease
  • Erythroplasia of Queyrat

SCC initially presents as smooth nodular, verrucous, papillomatous lesions. All these lesions later ulcerate and have a characteristic everted edge and are surrounded by inflamed, indurated skin.

Treatment:  Surgical excision is the treatment of choice. Other modalities include cautery ablation, cryotherapy, drug therapy including imiquimod, Moh’s microsurgery and Radiation therapy.

Other options:

Option A: A malignancy cannot be incised. Some malignancies can have local control through wide local excision.

Option C: Squamous cell carcinomas spread lymphatogenously. 

Option D: Chronic antibiotic therapy is not recommended for SCC. It is used in the treatment of chronic osteomyelitis, actinomycosis and tuberculosis. 

Related Pearl: Marjolin’s Ulcer

  • Low-grade cutaneous squamous cell carcinoma arising from
    • Long-standing ulcer like venous ulcer
    • Post-burn scar
    • Chronic osteomyelitis
    • Post-radiation ulcer.
  • Slow progression to malignancy (SCC) since it is relatively avascular.
  • Painless due to the absence of nerves in scar tissue.
  • No secondary deposits since there are no lymphatics in scar tissue.
  • Radioresistant due to avascularity.

questions.text: A 26-year male presented to OPD with a deformity of the left hand. He had a past history of RTA in which he had injured the same limb 6 months back. There was hypothenar muscle atrophy and a fixed deformity where on opening his hand he is not able to extend the medial two fingers. Which of the following nerves is likely to be injured?
questions.solution:
The given description is of a claw hand with hypothenar muscle atrophy classically seen in case of an ulnar nerve injury.

The ulnar nerve supplies the medial two lumbricals, adductor pollicis, interossei, and hypothenar muscles in the hand. The lumbricals are primarily responsible for the extension at the interphalangeal joints. Therefore, in ulnar nerve palsy, there is clawing of the medial two fingers.

In ulnar nerve palsy, only the medial two fingers develop clawing, while in a combined median and ulnar nerve palsy, all four fingers develop clawing. 

The following tests are done to test the integrity of the ulnar nerve:

  • Egawa's test - In a positive test, due to the weakness of the dorsal interossei, side-to-side movements of the middle finger is weak.
  • Book test or Froment's sign - The patient is asked to hold a book between the thumb and index finger while the examiner attempt to pull it forcefully. In case of an ulnar nerve injury, the adductor pollicis is paralyzed and the patient attempts to hold the book with the flexor pollicis longus muscle supplied by the median nerve.
  • Card test - In the case of weak palmar interossei, the examiner can pull out the card with ease. 

Other options

Option B - In radial nerve palsy, the patient presents with a wrist drop due to paralyzed wrist extensors. In high lesions, there is sensory loss on the dorsum of the hand over the anatomical stuff box. 

Option C - In median nerve injury, paralysis of opponens pollicis muscle leads to ape thumb deformity. A pointing finger deformity can also be seen due to paralyzed flexors of the fingers.

Option D - Long thoracic nerve supplies the serratus anterior muscle. Patients with injury to this nerve present with winging of the scapula.

Related Pearl: Fractures/dislocations and associated nerve injuries

Fracture/Dislocation Nerve injured
Fracture clavicle Brachial plexus
Anterior or inferior shoulder dislocation Axillary (circumflex humeral) nerve
Proximal humerus fracture Axillary nerve
Shaft of humerus fracture Radial nerve
Supracondylar fracture humerus  Anterior interosseous nerve > Median nerve > Radial nerve
Medial condyle of humerus  Ulnar nerve
Posterior dislocation elbow Ulnar nerve >Median nerve
Monteggia fracture Posterior interosseous nerve
Volkman’s ischemic contracture Anterior interosseous nerve
Hook of hamate fracture Deep branch of the ulnar nerve
Lunate dislocation  Median nerve
Wrist injury Median nerve
Posterior hip dislocation Sciatic nerve
Anterior dislocation of hip and shaft femur fracture Femoral nerve
Knee dislocation Common peroneal nerve
Proximal tibial fractures and ankle injury Posterior tibial nerve
Fracture neck of the fibula Lateral popliteal nerve (common peroneal nerve)

Related Pearl: Seddon's classification of nerve injuries

Seddon's classification includes 3 groups

  1. Neurapraxia
  2. Axonotmesis
  3. Neurotmesis

Neurapraxia:

Reversible physiologic conduction block. Occurs due to mechanical pressure causing segmental demyelination.

E.g.,Saturday night palsy, torniquet, and crutch palsy

Axonotmesis: 

Axonal interruption. Conduction is lost but the nerve is in continuity and neural tubes are intact.

E.g.,Closed fractures and dislocations

Neurotmesis: 

Division of the nerve trunk. Endoneurial tube destruction also occurs.

E.g., Complete section of nerve in open fractures

questions.text: A pregnant woman, after undergoing a cesarean section under spinal anesthesia, had a headache that aggravated in sitting position. Which of the following is not advised for this patient?
questions.solution:
The given scenario is suggestive of post-dural puncture headache which worsens with increased water intake.

Post-dural puncture headache is believed to result from a puncture of the dura (unintentional or intentional) in the setting of neuraxial anesthesia. This causes leakage of CSF from a dural defect leading to intracranial hypotension.

The characteristic feature of a post-dural puncture headache is the frontal or occipital headache. It is associated with nausea, neck stiffness, and lower back pain. Most of the headaches resolve spontaneously within 7 days. 

An epidural blood patch is the definitive management. It is ideally performed 24 hours after dural puncture and the development of classic symptoms (Option A).

Supine position, IV fluids caffeine, stool softeners, and analgesia are other factors that help in relieving the symptoms (options B & D).

Related Pearl: PDPH- Post-Dural Puncture Headache

  • May follow lumbar puncture, spinal anesthesia, wet epidural tap (in which epidural needle pierced dura).
  • Onset 12-72hrs and last for 1-2 weeks.
  • Aggravated by sitting and relieved by lying down.
  • Incidence increases with the larger needle, cutting point (in comparison to pencil point) needle, young age, females, pregnancy.
  • Prevention by thinner needle

Management:

  • Supine position
  • IV fluids
  • Caffeine and analgesia
  • Epidural blood patch

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy is brought with complaints of headache, vomiting and neck stiffness for a few days. He had undergone a ventriculoperitoneal (VP) shunt placement for hydrocephalus a year back. Which of the following is the most common cause of shunt malfunction?
questions.solution:
Obstruction of the shunt is the most common cause of shunt malfunction.

A ventriculoperitoneal (VP) shunt is used to drain excess cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) due to an obstruction in the normal outflow or there is a decreased absorption of the fluid.

Complications of the shunting procedure include the following -

  • Shunt obstruction - most common cause for shunt malfunction
  • Shunt infection due to skin flora entering the shunt, most commonly from Staphylococcus epidermidis. 
  • Intracerebral or intraventricular haemorrhage
  • Tip migration or malposition
  • Shunt overdrainage (slit ventricle syndrome) - usually occurs after many years
  • Shunt nephritis
  • Shunt disconnection or breakage or kinking
  • Inguinal hernia
  • Seizures

Shunt obstruction -

  • It is the most common cause of shunt malfunction.
  • The most common site is the ventricular catheter.
  • Obstruction occurs due to clogging of the shunt by blood, proteinaceous material, choroid plexus, glial adhesions or secondary to infection.
  • The patient comes with features of raised intracranial pressure like headache, vomiting and eye examination showing papilloedema. 
  • Diagnosis is done by CT Brain imaging which shows ventriculomegaly. On performing a lumbar puncture, the CSF flow is found to be slow despite the raised CSF pressure.
  • Treatment is by revision of the shunt.

 

The image below shows the location of the shunt in the brain

 

The image below shows a CT scan of the brain with some proteinaceous material deposited in the ventricles and shunt insitu.

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman presented with severe pain and swelling in her right hand which is increasing in size and severity. She had a prick injury while in the garden 5 days back. On examination, she cries out in pain when you try to extend the hand and palpate the palmar aspect passively. Which of the following statements is true about this condition?

choices.text: It is more common on the dorsal aspect of the hand
X ray imaging will aid in location of the foreign body in all patients.
Oral analgesics are the mainstay of treatment

questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario is suggestive of a deep palmar abscess secondary to a foreign body and it requires incision and drainage. 

Foreign body intrusions into the hand are among the most common injuries to the upper extremity seen in the Emergency Department. They can present with pain and swelling initially. The patient also presents with partial foreign bodies after the partial removal of the object. The delayed presentation can lead to the development of deep palmar abscesses with severe pain and systemic signs (fever, tachycardia)

Diagnosis: History is useful. If a metal object is suspected, an X-ray can be used to locate the object. In patients with non-metallic objects, high-frequency ultrasound can be used. 

Treatment requires exploration under anesthesia to remove the foreign body along with incision and drainage of the abscess.

Other options: 

Option A: It is more common in the palmar space. 

Option B: X-ray imaging can detect metallic objects. In the above case of splinters/thorns- high frequency musculoskeletal ultrasound probe can be used. 

Option D: Analgesics are necessary but not the mainstay of treatment.

questions.text: Banana and lemon signs are seen in which of the following fetal anomalies?
questions.solution:
Banana and lemon signs are seen in case of neural tube defects.

Signs of neural tube defect on targeted sonography:

  • Small biparietal diameter
  • Ventriculomegaly
  • Frontal bone scalloping or the lemon sign
  • Anterior curvature of the cerebellum with effacement of the cisterna magna known as banana sign.

questions.text: During a laproscopic surgery while inserting a lateral trocar for surgery which of the following is most prone to injury ?

choices.text: Both superior and inferior epigastric artery

questions.solution:
The most common source of bleeding during laparoscopic surgery is through both superior and inferior epigastric arteries. 

These vessels run vertically in the posterior rectus sheath along the lateral border of the rectus abdominis muscle, creating a high-risk zone for trocar placement. The superior epigastric artery descends from the internal thoracic (mammary) artery, while the inferior epigastric artery ascends from the external iliac artery, and they anastomose within the rectus muscle. Their consistent anatomical location and the fact that they run in a relatively superficial plane within the anterior abdominal wall makes them particularly vulnerable during trocar insertion.

To avoid injury, surgeons must carefully identify the lateral border of the rectus muscle and place trocars either medial or significantly lateral to this zone, and transillumination of the abdominal wall can help identify these vessels.

Injury to these arteries can result in significant bleeding, making it the most common source of haemorrhage in this type of surgery. Proper identification and careful dissection are essential to avoid this complication.

questions.text: A nulligravida presents to the OPD with uterine prolapse. No cystocele or rectocele were noted. What procedure will you perform?
questions.solution:
For a nulligravid woman with uterine prolapse and no cystocele or rectocele, we will perform an abdominal sling surgery.

Abdominal sling operations are designed for women with type II or III degree prolapse and who are desirous of retaining childbearing function and menstrual function.

Abdominal sling surgeries: Young women desirous of retaining menstrual and reproductive functions are ideal candidates. These surgeries use tapes as slings to prevent organ descent. These include:

  • Abdominal wall cervicopexy (modified by Purandare and Mathre): sling attached to cervix posteriorly near uterosacral ligaments. 
  • Shirodkar's sling surgery: the sling fixes the cervix to the lumbosacral fascia.
  • Khanna's sling surgery: - sling fixed to the anterior superior iliac spine, strengthening the Mackenrodt's ligament. 

Other options :

Option A: Le fort's repair - is done in patients who satisfy the following criteria:

  • Very elderly menopausal patient with an advanced prolapse
  • Do not wish to retain sexual function
  • Medically unfit for major surgeries

Option B: Fothergill surgery - Also known as Manchester's operation is suitable for women under 40 years who are desirous of retaining their menstrual and reproductive functions. It involves anterior colporrhaphy with amputation of the cervix. The mackenrodt ligaments are sutured in the front of the cervix and colpoperineorrhaphy is done. It increases the risk of cervical incompetence leading to recurrent abortions and preterm deliveries. Shirodkar's modification of Fothergill's repair avoids cervical amputation, hence subsequent pregnancy complications are avoided.  

Option D: Shirodkar sling surgery - the sling fixes the cervix to the lumbosacral fascia.

Related Pearl: Management of Uterine prolapse

Congenital/ Nulliparous (young) uterine prolapse: Sling/ cervicopexy

Uterovaginal uterine prolapse:

>40 No No  Ward Mayo's vaginal hysterectomy

Related Pearl: Degrees of vault prolapse

  • First degree: The vaginal apex is visible at the introitus
  • Second degree: The vault protrudes through the introitus
  • Third degree: The entire vagina is outside the introitus

questions.text: A middle-aged woman with a history of renal calculi complaints of bone pain and abdominal cramps. X-ray shows subperiosteal resorption of 2nd and 3rd metacarpals and phalanges. On investigation, serum calcium and PTH were raised and phosphate levels were decreased. Which of the following investigations will help localise the primary pathology?
questions.solution:
The given clinical picture is highly suggestive of primary hyperparathyroidism. The most common cause of primary hyperparathyroidism is a solitary parathyroid adenoma arising sporadically. It is best localised using a 99Tc- Radiolabelled sestamibi scan.

Hyperparathyroidism is caused by elevated parathyroid hormone and is classified into primary, secondary, and tertiary types.

Primary hyperparathyroidism Secondary hyperparathyroidism Tertiary hyperparathyroidism

an autonomous overproduction of parathyroid hormone (PTH)

 compensatory hypersecretion of PTH in response to prolonged hypocalcemia persistent hypersecretion of PTH even after the cause of prolonged hypocalcemia is corrected
Parathyroid  adenoma or hyperplasia chronic renal failure  after renal transplant.

Primary hyperparathyroidism is one of the most common endocrine disorders, and it is an important cause of hypercalcemia. Tumours of the parathyroid glands usually come to attention because of excessive secretion of PTH rather than mass effects. It can also be associated with MEN1 and MEN 2A syndromes. 

The clinical manifestations of hyperparathyroidism can be summarized as “painful bones, renal stones, abdominal groans, and psychic moans.” Skeletal manifestations of hyperparathyroidism include bone resorption, osteitis fibrosa cystica, and brown tumours. Renal changes include nephrolithiasis (stones) and nephrocalcinosis.

Localisation of parathyroid is difficult. Nuclear medicine scanning with radiolabeled Sestamibi is a widely used technique. Sestamibi accumulates in parathyroid adenomas. This radionuclide is concentrated in the thyroid and parathyroid tissue but usually washes out of normal thyroid tissue in under an hour. It persists in abnormal parathyroid tissue. It is now regarded as the most accurate and reliable method for imaging the parathyroid glands.

Other options:

Option B: Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) is not commonly used to image the parathyroid glands

Option C: Ultrasonography of the neck is a safe and widely used technique for the localization of abnormal parathyroid glands. However, ultrasonography is operator, lesion size and location dependent. Ectopic locations are difficult to locate. 

Option D: Multiphase CT imaging has become widely utilized to localize the disease. It gives both anatomical as well as functional information about the parathyroid glands. The disadvantage is the higher radiation dose when compared to others.

questions.text: An 8-year-old child was evaluated for multiple skin tumors. The workup revealed defective nucleotide excision repair. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical history of skin tumors with defective DNA nucleotide excision repair is suggestive of xeroderma pigmentosum. 

Xeroderma pigmentosum is an example of defective DNA nucleotide excision repair where there is an inability to repair DNA pyrimidine dimers caused by UV exposure.

UV radiation leads to pyrimidine dimerization in DNA strands, preventing further replication by DNA polymerase. The nucleotide excision repair mechanism corrects the dimer formation in DNA. There is an inability to repair DNA pyrimidine dimers caused by UV exposure.

Given below is the image of a patient diagnosed with xeroderma pigmentosum.

Other options:

Option B: Bloom syndrome is a rare congenital autosomal recessive disorder associated with defective homologous repair caused by the loss of function mutations in a helicase.

Option C: Werner syndrome is associated with defective homologous repair.

Option D: Severe combined immunodeficiency disease is caused due to defective nonhomologous end-joining repair.
