questions.text: A 45 year male presented to OPD with complaints of swelling on the upper back. It has been present for nearly a year and has not increased in size. On examination, the swelling is non pulsatile, and slip sign is positive approximately measuring 5*5 cm.  Which of the following statements is likely true?

choices.text: Excision can be done if the patient makes a request

questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of a 45-year-old male presenting with a non-pulsatile swelling on the upper back, which has not increased in size for nearly a year and measures approximately 5*5 cm with a positive slip sign, suggests a benign lesion like a lipoma. If the patient requests it, excision can be performed.

Lipomas are benign tumors of adipose tissue. It can occur anywhere and at any depth. It can be encapsulated or diffuse, superficial or deep.
On examination, they are nontender and non-pulsatile. Because of the soft consistency, they may appear to be fluctuant but they are not. The slip sign is positive.
Diagnosis is mostly clinical. Biopsy is rarely indicated in case of clinical doubt of malignant transformation. All lipomas need not be excised. Lipomas can be excised on suspicion of malignant transformation and sometimes at the patient's request. 
Imaging is required in cases of deep-seated tumors only.

Other options:

Option A: Lipomas have a very low risk of malignant transformation into liposarcoma.
Option B: While FNAC (Fine Needle Aspiration Cytology) can be used to confirm the diagnosis, it is not always necessary for a typical lipoma.
Option C: PET scans are generally not needed for benign conditions like lipomas. They are used in cases where malignancy is suspected.

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy presented to the OPD with the findings. He had suffered a fall on an outstretched hand one year back. What is the diagnosis?

choices.text: An undisplaced supracondylar fracture of humerus
Malunion of a supracondylar fracture of humerus

questions.solution:
The history of falling on an outstretched hand along with the gunstock deformity as seen in the image below are suggestive of malunion of a supracondylar fracture of the humerus. 

Cubitus varus deformity or gun stock deformity is a complication of supracondylar humerus fracture that occurs due to malunion. When the distal fragment unites with an excessive backward tilt, there is hyperextension at the elbow.

Supracondylar fractures are the most common fractures in children younger than the age of 7 years. It typically occurs due to a fall on an outstretched arm. They can be of various types as listed below:

  • Posterior displacement of distal fracture fragment occurs commonly and is an extension type of fracture.
  • Anterior displacement of distal fracture fragment is less common and occurs due to a direct blow on a flexed elbow and is often unstable
  • Lateral condylar fractures are due to a varus force on an extended elbow and may extend through the unossified portion of the capitellum into the joint space.

Other options:

Option A: An undisplaced fracture may show a triangular lucency like the sail of a yacht (sail sign), also called a fat pad sign. This is due to the fat pad around the elbow being pushed forward by the hematoma. Also, it would not present with the gun stock deformity.

Option C: The dislocated radial head would present with a discontinuity in the line drawn along the shaft of the proximal radius (the line should normally pass through the capitellum). 

The image below shows an anterior dislocated radial head with calcification of the annular ligament:

Option D: Proximal humerus fractures are uncommon in children and will be pathological fractures (due to reasons such as the presence of a bone cyst)

The image below shows a radiograph showing a proximal humerus fracture with the involvement of a greater tubercle:

questions.text: A 19-year-old man presented with progressive swelling of the lower end of the femur. X-ray of this patient shows a Codman triangle. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a young patient with a tumour in the distal femur with a Codmnan's triangle on X-ray suggests a probable diagnosis of osteosarcoma. 

Osteosarcoma is the most common non-hematologic primary malignancy of bone. It occurs most commonly in the second decade of life. It is typically metaphyseal. The distal femur, proximal tibia, and proximal humerus are common sites.

In osteosarcoma, the tumour lifts the periosteum and incites an intense periosteal reaction. The periosteal reaction is irregular and it may take the form of a Codman's triangle or it may have a sunburst (sunray) appearance on x-ray.

The x-ray would show the following features.

  • Irregular destruction in the metaphysis is overshadowed by the formation of new bone
  • Lifting of the periosteum due to the formation of new bone inciting a periosteal reaction
  • Bone formation along the blood vessels within the tumour centrifugally gives rise to a sunburst (sunray) appearance on the radiograph.

Treatment: Osteosarcoma is treated by neoadjuvant chemotherapy, wide excision or radical surgery followed by adjuvant chemotherapy. Since here safe margins are difficult to achieve limb ablation is done. 

The goal of neoadjuvant and adjuvant chemotherapy is to treat micrometastasis.

T-10 protocol of chemotherapy is used in the management of osteosarcoma. It involves:

  • High-dose methotrexate and Citrovorum factor rescue
  • Adriamycin
  • BCD (bleomycin, cyclophosphamide, dactinomycin/doxorubicin)

Option A: Aneurysmal bone cysts are blood-filled spaces separated by fibrous septae. X-ray shows expansile lytic lesions in the metaphyses of the upper tibia. 

Option B: Ewing Sarcoma- lesion with poorly marginated edges in the diaphysis of the bone. The lamellated periosteal reaction in diaphysis is suggestive of Ewing’s sarcoma which is a highly radiosensitive tumour.

Option D: Osteoid osteoma is a benign tumour which occurs in the diaphyses of the femur. Classically, the pain is relieved after using NSAID. Codman's triangle is not seen.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male patient is being treated for chronic obstructive pulmonary disease and comes for follow-up. He is tachypneic with a resting oxygen saturation of 86%. Which of the following will increase the survival in this patient?
questions.solution:
Long-term oxygen therapy will increase survival in patients with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). 

Supplemental oxygen is indicated in patients with resting O2 saturation of ≤88% or ≤89% with signs of pulmonary arterial hypertension or right heart failure. It has been proven to prolong survival and the benefits are directly proportional to the duration of oxygen administration (hours per day). Studies did not show significant benefits in patients with moderate hypoxemia. 

Patients with dependent edema, P-pulmonale on ECG, or hematocrit value >56% with PaO2 value between 56-59 mm Hg or SaO2 of 89% are also eligible for oxygen therapy.

COPD is a disease state characterized by chronic airflow obstruction.  It includes emphysema, chronic bronchitis, and small airway disease. Patients present with cough, sputum production, and dyspnea on exertion. Diagnosis is based on pulmonary function tests and the severity is graded according to the global initiative for chronic obstructive lung disease (GOLD) criteria. 

Pharmacotherapy of COPD includes:

  • Muscarinic antagonists: ipratropium, tiotropium
  • Beta-agonists: salbutamol, salmeterol
  • Theophylline
  • Inhaled corticosteroids

Acute exacerbations are managed with inhaled beta-agonists, muscarinic antagonists, oxygen, mechanical ventilation in the form of noninvasive positive-pressure ventilation, and antibiotics.

Smoking cessation and lung volume reduction surgery in some emphysematous patients are the other interventions associated with reduced mortality.

Other options:

Option B: Long-term oral glucocorticoids are not recommended to treat COPD due to the significant adverse effects such as osteoporosis, weight gain, and cataracts.

Option C: Inhaled corticosteroids are mainly used to reduce exacerbations. Patients with two or more exacerbations per year or hospitalized patients with one exacerbation can be considered. 

Option D: Phosphodiesterase 4 inhibitors (PDE4) inhibitor roflumilast can be used to reduce the frequency of exacerbations in severe COPD and chronic bronchitis.

questions.text: A 45-year-old female patient who had been to a movie theatre came to the emergency room with complaints of ocular pain and blurring of vision. She gives a history of being on prophylactic medications for migraine. On examination, her intraocular pressure is elevated with a shallow anterior chamber. Which of the following drugs is the most likely cause of her presentation?
questions.solution:
Topiramate is the most likely cause of her presentation.

The given clinical scenario is suggestive of acute angle-closure glaucoma characterized by the precipitating factors i.e., female gender and movie theatre (movie in a darkened hall) and increased intraocular pressure with a shallow anterior chamber.

Topiramate causes ciliochoroidal effusion, leading to acute angle-closure glaucoma. Other sulfa-derived drugs like sulfonamides can also cause angle-closure glaucoma. The treatment would consist of reducing the intraocular pressure and stopping the causative drug.

Topiramate is an antiepileptic drug that blocks the voltage-gated Na+ channels. Apart from that, it activates hyperpolarizing K+ channels, increases GABA activity, and blocks glutamate AMPA-kainate receptors. It is also a weak carbonic anhydrase inhibitor due to which it may precipitate renal stones.

Topiramate is used in the treatment of refractory focal, refractory generalized tonic-clonic seizures, and prophylaxis of migraine. It is also effective in drop-attacks and seizures in Lennox-Gastaut syndrome. This drug can cause weight loss and renal stones.

Other options: 

Option A - Sodium valproate is an antiseizure drug that acts by prolonging the recovery of inactivated Na+ channels and decreasing T-type Ca2+ channel currents. It is used in the treatment of focal, tonic-clonic, absence, and myoclonic seizures. It is also used as a prophylaxis in migraine headaches. 

Option C - Propranolol is a non-selective β-blocker. It is the most common and most effective first-line drug for migraine prophylaxis. Some of the common adverse effects include dizziness, decreased exercise tolerance, and depression. Contraindications include severe asthma, peripheral vascular disease, severe bradycardia, and heart blocks.

Option D - Gabapentin is used in focal onset seizures, neuropathic pains like post-herpetic neuralgia, and neuropathic pain. The most common adverse effects seen with gabapentin are increased drowsiness, ataxia, and fatigue.

questions.text: A patient with rapidly progressive renal failure (RPRF) presents with crescentic glomerulonephritis which is found to be pauci-immune. Which of the following antibodies are involved in this condition?
questions.solution:
ANCA - antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibody is the most common antibody associated with pauci-immune crescentic glomerulonephritis.

There are two main types of ANCA: myeloperoxidase (MPO)-ANCA and proteinase-3 (PR3)-ANCA. MPO-ANCA is more strongly associated with renal-limited vasculitis, while PR3-ANCA is more strongly associated with systemic vasculitis.

Rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis (RPGN) is a clinical entity with features of nephritic syndrome and rapid loss of renal function. It is a syndrome associated with severe glomerular injury with necrosis and the formation of crescents, but it does not denote a specific etiologic form of glomerulonephritis.

In most cases, RPGN is immune-mediated. Circulating anti-neutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies (ANCAs) are detected in the pauci-immune type of RPGN. Serum analyses for anti-GBM antibodies, antinuclear antibodies, and ANCAs are helpful in the diagnosis of specific subtypes

Based on immunologic findings, RPGN is classified as:

Anti-GBM antibody-mediated disease (Type I) is characterized by linear GBM deposits of IgG and C3 on immunofluorescence and includes renal limited disease and Goodpasture's disease. Here, the antibodies are produced against a peptide present in the noncollagenous domain of the α3 chain of collagen IV of the GBM. This serves as the antigen which is common to the alveoli and the glomerulus.

Immune complex deposition (Type II) is characterized by granular deposits of antibodies and complement on immunofluorescence and can be a complication of any of the immune complex nephritides which include:

  • Postinfectious glomerulonephritis
  • Lupus nephritis
  • IgA nephropathy
  • Henoch-Schönlein purpura

Pauci-immune (Type III) exhibits no characteristic immunoglobulin or complement deposits on immunofluorescence. It includes

  • ANCA-associated
  • Granulomatosis with polyangiitis
  • Microscopic polyangiitis

Other options:

Option A: ANA - antinuclear antibody: ANA is a non-specific antibody seen in most autoimmune disorders; including lupus, rheumatoid arthritis, and scleroderma. ANA is not typically associated with pauci-immune crescentic glomerulonephritis.

Option C: Anti-GBM - anti-glomerular basement membrane antibody: directed against the glomerular basement membrane. Anti-GBM is associated with anti-GBM disease/Goodpasture syndrome, a type of rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis that is characterized by linear deposits of IgG along the BM.

Option D: Anti-PLA2R - anti-phospholipase A2 receptor antibody: Anti-PLA2R is an antibody that is directed against the phospholipase A2 receptor; associated with membranous nephropathy, where thickening of the glomerular basement membrane is characteristic.

questions.text: A patient with rheumatic heart disease comes with complaints of reduced urination. Urine analysis reveals proteinuria and hematuria. A renal biopsy shows crescent formation, with a few embolic and septic abscesses. Which of the following primary conditions could have led to his renal findings?
questions.solution:
This patient with rheumatic heart disease (indicating a damaged heart valve) now presents with oliguria, proteinuria, and hematuria. The biopsy findings of crescents and abscesses make septic emboli the likely cause. Subacute bacterial endocarditis is most likely associated with endocarditis-associated glomerulonephritis. 

Endocarditis-associated glomerulonephritis is mostly associated with subacute bacterial endocarditis that has gone untreated for a long time as it allows for the formation of antigen-antibody complexes. Acute bacterial endocarditis on the other hand is picked up clinically and is usually treated aggressively thus not allowing for the kidney disease to progress. 

Patients commonly present with oliguria, acute kidney injury or rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis. Grossly, the kidney will show a flea-bitten appearance with multiple abscesses. Biopsy shows crescents. Immunofluorescence shows IgM, IgG, and C3.

Treatment is treating the underlying endocarditis, and monitoring the patient for improvement in kidney function. 

Other Options:

Option A: Henoch-schonlein purpura usually has an accompanying palpable purpura with glomerulonephritis. It is also not associated with rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis.

Option C: Microangiopathic hemolytic anemia can occur in cases of valve replacements where the valve malfunctions leading to shearing and rupture of RBCs. This can present with findings of proteinuria and hematuria but the presence of crescents on biopsy and a lack of history of valve replacement makes endocrditis likely.

Option D:  Sickle cell disease causes renal papillary necrosis which presents with frank hematuria and progressively declining renal function. The additional finding of septic emboli makes an infective cause more likely.

questions.text: A patient undergoing elbow surgery was given a local anaesthetic during the procedure. Local anaesthetics acts by ___________________.
questions.solution:
Local anaesthetics primarily act by blocking the voltage-gated sodium channels bound to the membrane. 

Sodium channels have one larger α subunit and one or two smaller β subunits. These voltage-gated sodium channels exist in 3 states :

  • Resting (non-conducting)
  • Open (conducting)
  • Inactivated (non-conducting)

The local anaesthetics bind to the α subunit of sodium channels, thereby preventing their activation and inhibiting the influx of sodium. They have a higher affinity for the sodium channels in the open and inactivated state than in the resting state.

Local anaesthetic inhibition is both voltage and frequency-dependent and is higher when nerve fibres are firing rapidly than with slow, infrequent depolarizations.

Note:

Local anaesthetics may also bind and inhibit calcium, potassium, transient receptor potential vanilloid 1 (TRPV1) and many other channels and receptors, but blocking sodium channels is its primary action.

Related Pearl: Classification of local anesthetics based on chemical structure

Amino ester Amino amide
Relatively unstable in solution Relatively more stable due to the presence of di-ortho methyl (methoxy) group

questions.text: A patient developed hand-foot syndrome after 10 days of initiation of chemotherapy. Which of the following is the most likely agent to cause this adverse effect?
questions.solution:
Capecitabine is commonly associated with the side effect of hand-foot syndrome.

Capecitabine is a pyrimidine analog that is classified as an antimetabolite agent. Side effects are diarrhea, hand-foot syndrome, and myelosuppression.

Hand foot syndrome or palmar-plantar erythrodysesthesia consists of erythema, desquamation, pain, and sensitivity to touch of the palms and soles. 

Drugs commonly implicated are:

  • Capecitabine
  • 5-Fluorouracil
  • Cytarabine
  • Pemetrexed
  • Doxorubicin

Other options:

Option A: Cisplatin is a highly emetic drug . Other adverse effects include dose-dependent nephrotoxicity, ototoxicity, and peripheral neuropathy.

Option B: Vincristine is a vinca alkaloid that acts during the M phase of the cell cycle. It causes microtubule disruptions, thereby preventing cellular replication. Side effects are neuropathy and SIADH.

Option D: Bleomycin causes cutaneous toxicities like erythema, ulceration, and flagellate dermatitis. The most serious adverse reaction to bleomycin is pulmonary toxicity, which may progress to life-threatening pulmonary fibrosis.

questions.text: A 47-year-old female comes with complaints of severe chest pain since last night. She had gone to a party where she remembers binge drinking following which she had multiple episodes of vomiting which was also mixed with blood. On examination, she appeared sick and had fast breathing. Her BP-90/50 mg Hg, HR-112/min and crepitus can be palpated. An X-ray was done and is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with a history of recurrent episodes of vomiting mixed with blood, and now presenting with chest pain, hypotension, and palpable crepitus with a given X-ray showing pneumomediastinum is suggestive of esophageal perforation.

Oesophageal perforation is a potentially life-threatening condition that occurs through the transmural perforation of the esophageal wall. It can occur secondary to trauma, endoscopic instrumentation, corrosive ingestion, or severe repetitive vomiting against a closed GE junction. It presents with retrosternal chest pain and other symptoms depending on the size of the perforation and contamination of the mediastinum. Late signs may include mediastinitis as well as surgical emphysema. The initial investigation that is performed in this condition is a contrast esophagogram (gastrograffin) which will show the extravasation of the contrast. Water-soluble contrast (iohexol) should be used instead of barium contrast to prevent barium-related inflammation of the mediastinum if there is perforation. If the esophagogram is normal, contrast-enhanced CT is useful in identifying the injury. If the suspicion of esophageal perforation is high and the radiological investigations are normal, then the endoscopy can be performed to confirm the diagnosis.

Other options
Options A: Mallory-Weiss tear is characterized by mucosal lacerations at the gastroesophageal junction, typically following forceful vomiting. It usually presents with hematemesis and epigastric pain but does not typically cause severe chest pain or crepitus.

Option C: Pulsion Diverticulum (e.g., Zenker's Diverticulum) is an outpouching of the esophageal mucosa due to increased intraluminal pressure.
Patients may have dysphagia, regurgitation, and possibly halitosis. However, it does not typically present with acute severe chest pain or crepitus.

Option D: Acute pericarditis is inflammation of the pericardium, often presenting with sharp chest pain that may worsen with deep breaths or when lying down. Acute pericarditis is unlikely given the history of vomiting, hematemesis, and crepitus.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male presented to a surgical emergency with complaints of severe epigastric pain for 1 day. On examination, HR was 120/min and BP was 100/60 mm Hg. On palpation, there is tenderness, guarding and rigidity. What is the probable cause of the condition shown in the X-ray below?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of hypotension and tachycardia with abdominal tenderness, guarding and rigidity with free air under the diaphragm in X-ray is indicative of hollow viscus perforation. 

Acute abdomen is a common surgical emergency. Common causes include appendicitis, hollow viscus perforation, cholecystitis, and pancreatitis. An erect abdominal X-ray is commonly done as the first investigation. Free air under the diaphragm can result from hollow viscus perforation including Gastric, duodenal, small bowel and large bowel perforations.

Causes of hollow viscus perforation are blunt or penetrating injury, bowel obstruction, peptic ulcer disease, infections(TB, typhoid, Crohn's), corrosive agents etc.

Clinical features include abdominal pain and distension, nausea, vomiting, tachycardia, tenderness, rebound tenderness, decreased or absent bowel sounds, and guarding on palpation. Fever may be present. Features of septic shock can be seen at later stages.

Investigations include estimation of the white blood cell count, urea, serum electrolytes, and an erect abdominal radiograph showing free gas under the diaphragm. A supine radiograph may show dilated gas-filled loops of the bowel suggestive of paralytic ileus. However, CECT is the most sensitive investigation to detect minimal/ suspected pneumoperitoneum.

Management of a hollow viscous perforation mainly includes resuscitation, analgesics, intravenous broad-spectrum antibiotics, and emergency exploratory laparotomy. 

Management - Initial management includes intravenous (IV) fluid therapy, cessation of oral intake, and broad-spectrum antibiotics. This is followed by immediate surgical exploration.

Other options: None of the other options have free air under the diaphragm.

Option A: Acute cholecystitis presents with pain in the right upper quadrant with fever and nausea. They may have tenderness and guarding. Rigidity is uncommon. Additionally, free air under the diaphragm may be seen in cases of gall bladder perforation only. 

Option B: Sigmoid volvulus shows a large, dilated loop of the colon, often with a few air-fluid levels. Specific signs include the coffee bean sign and the absence of rectal gas. On the x-ray abdomen, the apex of the sigmoid volvulus extends towards the right upper quadrant and the haustrations are usually lost.

Option D: In small bowel obstruction, the obstructed bowel loops are centrally located and lie transversely. In cases of jejunal obstruction, valvulae conniventes, which are mucosal folds that span the entire diameter of the bowel, create a ladder effect. Additionally, a distended cecum may exhibit a gas shadow in the right iliac fossa.

questions.text: Which of the following biochemical parameters are consistent with osteoporosis?

choices.text: Calcium and PTH increase, phosphate is normal and ALP decreases
Calcium and phosphate decrease, PTH increases, and ALP is normal
Calcium and phosphate are normal, PTH increases and ALP decreases
Calcium, phosphate, PTH, ALP all are normal

questions.solution:
Serum calcium, phosphorus, alkaline phosphatase, and parathyroid hormone levels are usually normal in osteoporosis.

Biochemical Investigations in Osteoporosis:

  • Serum calcium, phosphorus, alkaline phosphatase, and parathyroid hormone levels are usually normal.
  • Total plasma proteins and plasma albumin may be low.
  • Biochemical markers of bone formation and bone resorption in blood and urine are helpful in diagnosis as well as monitoring the response to treatment.

questions.text:
A 24-year-old female patient presents with a 3-day history of fever, headache, ataxia, nausea, and vomiting. On examination neck rigidity is present and there is hip and knee flexion on passive flexion of the neck. A lumbar puncture was done and CSF findings are as shown below. What is your diagnosis?

Opening pressure - Increased 

Colour- Cloudy white

PMN- 85%

Sugar- 30 mg/dl

CSF/serum glucose ratio - 0.2 

Protein - 200 mg/dl
questions.solution:
The given clinical picture of fever, headache, ataxia, nausea, vomiting with neck rigidity, hip, and knee flexion on passive flexion of the neck (Brudzinsky's sign), and CSF examination findings are suggestive of bacterial meningitis. 

The most common organism causing bacterial meningitis in adults is Streptococcus pneumoniae. Other less common causes are Neisseria meningitidis, Staphylococcus aureus, Listeria monocytogenes, Haemophilus sp., and Enterobacteriaceae, etc.

The classic clinical triad of fever, headache, and neck rigidity is suggestive of meningitis. Other common complaints are nausea, vomiting, and photophobia, nuchal rigidity (“stiff neck”) is the pathognomonic sign of meningitis. Hip and knee flexion on passive flexion of the neck is called Brudzinsky's sign

Following are the classical CSF examination features suggestive of bacterial meningitis.

Opening pressure  >180 mmH2O
WBC

10/μL to 10,000/μL; neutrophils predominate
RBC Absent in non-traumatic tap
Glucose

<2.2 mmol/L (<40 mg/dL)
CSF/serum glucose <0.4
Protein

>0.45 g/L (>45 mg/dL)
Latex agglutination

May be positive in 

Streptococcus pneumoniae, Neisseria meningitidis, Haemophilus influenzae type b, Escherichia coli, group B streptococci
Limulus lysate Positive in gram-negative meningitis
Culture Positive in >80%

When bacterial meningitis is suspected, a blood culture should be sent and empirical antibiotics started.

questions.text: What marker is regularly monitored in the management of ectopic pregnancy?
questions.solution:
The marker used in the monitoring of ectopic pregnancy is β-hCG

Human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG) is a glycoprotein. It can be detected in the maternal serum or urine as early as 8–9 days post-fertilization. Maximum levels in blood and urine are found between 60 - 70 days of pregnancy. It disappears from circulation within 2 weeks following delivery.

Ectopic pregnancy has decreased levels of hCG as compared to normal pregnancy hCG, and it is used as a marker for medical management of ectopic pregnancy. Following conservative surgery or medical treatment, estimation of serum β-hCG level should be done weekly until the β-HCG values go down.

Medical management is indicated when the patient is asymptomatic and hemodynamically stable. It involves the systemic or local use of chemotherapeutic drugs: 

  • Drugs used: Methotrexate (50 mg/m2, single dose intramuscularly)
  • Regular monitoring of serum β-hCG

Medical management is likely to be successful when

  • Initial serum hCG level is <3,000 IU/L.
  • Ectopic mass is less than 4 cm.
  • Fetal cardiac activity is absent.
  • Intra-abdominal hemorrhage is absent.

Surgical management of ectopic pregnancy includes laparoscopic salpingostomy, salpingectomy, and microsurgical laparotomy.

questions.text: An exclusively breastfed 3-month-old baby was brought with complaints of lethargy, vomiting and diarrhoea. Further examination confirmed the presence of jaundice, hypotonia and hepatomegaly. Ocular examination revealed a bilateral cataract that resembled a drop of oil. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of an exclusively breastfed infant presenting with vomiting, diarrhea, jaundice, hypotonia, hepatomegaly and bilateral oil drop cataract is suggestive of classical galactosemia.

Classical galactosemia is an autosomal recessive disorder. The enzyme deficient here is galactose-1-phosphate uridyl transferase (GALT). Normally, newborns receive up to 40% of their calorie intake as lactose (glucose + galactose). Without GALT, the infant cannot metabolize galactose 1-phosphate, which accumulates and causes injury to the kidney, liver, and brain.

Clinical features include vomiting, hypoglycemia, hepatomegaly, jaundice, congenital cataracts, aminoaciduria, and failure to thrive. There is an increased incidence of Escherichia coli neonatal sepsis. Long-term complications include speech delays, learning impairment, motor dysfunction, and hypogonadotropic hypogonadism (in females).

Diagnosis: The presence of galactose in urine (positive Benedict's test), elevated blood galactose level, and elevated erythrocyte galactose-1-phosphate level help in confirming the diagnosis.

Treatment is a galactose-free diet. Supportive therapy and the prevention of complications are important.

questions.text: When is cord clamping ideally done?
questions.solution:
As per the AMTSL guidelines, cord clamping is practised within 1-3 minutes of the delivery of the fetus.

Delayed cord clamping is done 30 to 60 seconds after birth in all the babies. This increases the amount of blood flowing from mother to baby which decreases the risk of anaemia in later life, improves hemodynamic stability, decreases the risk of necrotizing enterocolitis,intraventricular hemorrhage in preterm infants, and also decreases the need for transfusions and inotropic support.

AMTSL guidelines recommended by WHO :

  • Immediate administration of prophylactic uterotonics (Oxytocin). Oxytocin (10 IU) is given IM or IV.
  • Controlled cord traction during placental delivery (in cesarean section and in vaginal birth where skilled birth attendants are present)
  • Delayed cord clamping
  • Postpartum abdominal uterine tonus assessment for early identification of uterine atony is recommended for all women. Continuous monitoring of uterine tone is done every 15 minutes for 2 hours. If uterine atony is detected, a fundal massage is performed.

Recent update: Uterine massage is not recommended routinely.

The goal of this is to prevent postpartum haemorrhage (PPH). Hence, uterotonics are the most important factor in decreasing PPH. Delayed cord clamping is a less important component in this direction and similarly, cord traction is not as critical. Uterine massage does not form the main component of AMTSL.

questions.text:
An 8-year-old girl presented with frequent episodes of staring spells in school. On further evaluation, she was diagnosed with absence seizures and started on ethosuximide. What is the mechanism of action of this drug?

GABA: gamma-Aminobutyric acid

choices.text: Inhibition of the T-type calcium channels

questions.solution:
Ethosuximide, commonly used in children suffering from absence seizures acts by inhibiting T-type calcium channels.

Absence seizures originate in the thalamus and produce the pathognomonic 3 Hz spike and wave pattern on EEG. This pattern is produced due to the intrinsic properties of the low threshold T-type calcium channels of the thalamus. These channels are activated at a much lower threshold and produce larger currents as compared to most other calcium channels in the brain. Hence, inhibition of these T-type calcium currents in the neurons of the thalamus by ethosuximide is effective for the management of absence seizures.

The condition is most often initially treated with ethosuximide, which is as effective as, but less toxic than, valproate. EEG is helpful in monitoring the response to therapy and often normalizes when complete seizure control is achieved. Childhood absence epilepsy is associated with a good prognosis, and most patients outgrow it before adulthood.

Other options:

Option A: Valproate acts by blockage of both sodium and calcium channels. It is effective in the treatment of absence, myoclonic, focal, and tonic-clonic seizures.

Option B: Vigabatrin inhibits GABA metabolism and thus increases GABA concentration in the brain. It is the drug of choice for infantile spasms seen in tuberous sclerosis.

Option C: Benzodiazepines enhance GABA-mediated synaptic inhibition resulting in GABA potentiation. Benzodiazepines act at GABAA receptors and increase the frequency, but not duration, of openings at GABA-activated Cl− channels.

questions.text: A 19-year-old patient is brought to the emergency room with complaints of altered sensorium and abdominal pain. She appears dehydrated. Investigations revealed pH - 7.00, blood sugar level- 500 mg/dL, and ketonuria. She is started on IV insulin with potassium infusion. Which of the following parameters can be used to assess the recovery of the patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with severe dehydration, hyperglycemia, ketonuria, and metabolic acidosis(pH-7.00) suggests diabetic ketoacidosis(DKA) likely due to undiagnosed Type 1 Diabetes Mellitus. The serum anion gap is a test that can be used to measure the recovery of the patient.

 

In DKA, due to the absence of insulin, there is a decrease in glucose uptake in cells in the body leading to a state of starvation. This leads to an increase in levels of glucagon and ketone bodies in order to provide a constant source of energy to the cells including the myocardial and neural tissue. An increase in the serum ketones widens the anion gap which is why DKA is an Anion gap metabolic acidosis.  Serum anion gap can be used to measure the response to treatment and also helps in planning further management. As the patient receives insulin, there is a cessation of production of ketoacids and this in turn leads to the normalization of the serum anion gap.

In DKA, the insulin-to-glucagon ratio is decreased which promotes gluconeogenesis, glycogenolysis, and ketone body formation in the liver. Ketone bodies exist as ketoacids at physiologic pH which are neutralized by bicarbonate. As bicarbonate stores are depleted, metabolic acidosis ensues. Increased lactic acid production also contributes to acidosis.

The diagnostic biochemical criteria for DKA includes:

  • Hyperglycemia (>200 mg/dL)
  • Venous pH <7.3 or plasma/serum bicarbonate <15 mmol/L 
  • Ketonemia (beta-hydroxybutyrate [BOHB] >3 mmol/L) and ketonuria

Signs of ketoacidosis: 

  • Kussmaul breathing (deep, heavy, non-labored rapid breathing)
  • Fruity breath odor (acetone)
  • Prolonged Q-T interval
  • Diminished neurocognitive function
  • Coma

Management: Based on the ISPAD guidelines, the initial management includes management of the airway, breathing, and circulation and fluid replacement with an IV bolus of 10 mL/kg normal saline over 1 hour. This is followed by an IV insulin infusion of 0.1 U/kg/hour.

questions.text: Which of the following helps manage nausea and vomiting during pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Taking small and frequent meals during pregnancy can help alleviate nausea and vomiting, commonly known as morning sickness.

Pregnancy can affect glucose metabolism, causing fluctuations in blood sugar levels, which may trigger nausea. Eating small, frequent meals helps maintain more stable blood sugar levels, reducing the likelihood of nausea associated with hypoglycemia.

The growing uterus exerts pressure on the stomach, reducing its capacity and increasing the sensation of fullness. Large meals can cause significant gastric distension, which may exacerbate nausea and discomfort. Smaller meals are easier to digest and are less likely to cause these symptoms.

During pregnancy, the hormone progesterone relaxes smooth muscle, including the gastrointestinal tract, which can slow gastric emptying and contribute to nausea. Smaller, more frequent meals may help by ensuring that food moves more consistently through the digestive system, reducing the likelihood of stomach contents lingering and causing nausea.

Pregnancy hormones, such as human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG) and estrogen, are associated with nausea and vomiting. While the exact mechanism is not fully understood, frequent, small meals may help modulate the body's response to these hormones by preventing an empty stomach, which can sometimes worsen nausea.

questions.text:
A 65-year-old man with a history of chronic smoking came with complaints of ulcerative lesions on his lower lip for a year. On examination, there is a presence of a palpable ipsilateral submental node approximately 5*5 cm. Biopsy from the lesion was suggestive of squamous cell cancer. What is the next step in the management of this patient?

MRND-Modified radical neck dissection

choices.text: Resection of primary lesion with lip reconstruction and MRND

questions.solution:
The given patient has a squamous cell carcinoma of the lip with a primary lesion on the lower lip with ipsilateral lymph node metastasis to the submental node. This patient will need resection of the primary lesion with reconstruction and modified radical neck dissection (MRND). 

Lip cancer most commonly occurs in men from 50 to 70 years old but can be seen in younger patients. Risk factors include sunlight exposure, smoking, and tobacco use. Squamous cell carcinoma is the most common type of lip cancer. But commonly occurring cancer in the upper lip is basal cell carcinoma.

Most lip cancers occur in the lower lip followed by the upper lip and commissure. The most common site is the vermilion border of the lower lip. Ulcerative lesion on the vermilion border of the lower lip is the most common clinical manifestation. Mass can extend and fix on the underlying bone. Loss of sensation over the chin indicates mental nerve involvement. The most frequently involved nodes are the submental and submandibular nodes.

Surgical resection (wide local excision with negative margins) is the preferred treatment modality. The typical lip length is 6 to 7 cm. For defects of <1/3rd of the lip, resection with primary closure is the preferred treatment.

For defects of more than 1/3rd of the lip, require local flaps for reconstruction after resection:

  • Johansen step technique- local flap for large central defects 
  • Lip-switch (Abbe-Estlander) flap- based on the sublabial or superior labial artery. When the defect involves only the commissure, the Estlander flap is used, and the Abbé flap is used for midline defects. Abbe-Estlander Flap is used for mixed defects. The markings of the Abbe-Estlander flap are shown below.
  • Karapandzic flap - circumoral advancement flap. It is a neuromuscular flap that includes the remaining orbicularis oris muscle with its innervation.

In the presence of neck metastasis, neck dissection is indicated. Postoperative radiation is administered to patients with positive margins, lymph node metastases, tumor thickness >4mm, or perineural invasion. If the mandible is involved, mandibulectomy and free flap reconstruction is required.

N3a Metastasis in a lymph node >6 cms and ENE‐negative
N3b

Metastasis in any lymph node(s) and clinically overt ENE +positive.


Note:
ENE is as determined by physical examination (e.g., invasion of the skin, infiltration of musculature/dense tethering to adjacent structures, or dysfunction of a cranial nerve, the brachial plexus, the sympathetic trunk, or the phrenic nerve) and supported by radiological evidence, should be present to assign a status of ENE‐positive.

questions.text: A 30-year-old presents on postpartum day 10 with high-grade fever, malaise and pain in her left breast. She has been exclusively breastfeeding her child. She had presented to the OPD a few days back with mild pain and congestion of the breast and was prescribed oral analgesics and antibiotics. On examination, the left breast appears engorged and a fluctuant swelling is present. Ultrasound showed fluid collection. What is the next most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A lactational mother with high-grade fever and fluctuant swelling which did not resolve with analgesics and antibiotics points towards a diagnosis of breast abscess. 

The most common aetiology of breast abscess is Staph. aureus and occurs commonly in lactational mothers. It occurs due to the colonisation of obstructed lactiferous ducts. It is commoner in new mothers at the beginning of lactation who are inexperienced with breastfeeding or during weaning when nipple trauma occurs due to the infant's growing teeth. 

Signs and symptoms: Fever and malaise, localized pain and tenderness, redness and swelling of the affected breast, fluctuation test positive due to pus in the abscess. It is a late sign. The initial treatment should involve providing pain relief with analgesics. The abscess should then be localized preferably under USG guidance and percutaneous aspiration carried out. The pus should be sent for microbiological examination to find the organism and antibiotic sensitivity. Repeated aspirations may be carried out under antibiotics cover if needed. In some conditions mentioned below, the breast abscess may be unresponsive to repeated aspiration and antibiotic cover. In such cases, incision and drainage are performed. The conditions include: 

  • Presence of thick pus
  • Bacteria resistant to antibiotics
  • If just a superficial part has been aspirated in the presence of a multiloculated abscess

A non-healing breast abscess due to tuberculosis of the breast inflammatory carcinoma of the breast, or an immunocompromised host. 

Other options: 

Option B: Mastitis occurs due to the growth of staphylococcus or streptococcus due to breast milk stasis. This occurs secondary to blockage of the lactiferous duct due to incomplete emptying of breast milk or due to a retracted nipple. Overgrowth of these bacteria results in the development of breast abscesses.

The below table summarises likely features to differentiate Bacterial mastitis from a Breast abscess

  Bacterial mastitis Breast abscess
Condition Localized inflammation
due to an ascending infection 
or infection due to milk stasis 		 Occurs as a complication of mastitis
Pus formation
Symptoms Dull pain Throbbing pain
Signs (if any) Tenderness
Erythema		 Point tenderness
Erythema
Induration of skin(if chronic)
Lymphadenopathy
Fluctuation test +ve
Management Analgesics
Antibiotics		 Analgesic
Aspiration of Pus
Antibiotics

 

The image below shows mastitis of the breast:

Option C: Antibioma is a chronic complication of breast abscess with a thick wall and results from inadequate antibiotics and drainage. They don't have the clinical symptoms described above.

Option D: Carcinoma breast usually presents as a painless lump. Fever and pain are unusual.

questions.text: A construction site worker is brought to emergency with complaints of excessive redness and watering in the right eye. He gave a history of some chemical that had accidentally fallen into his eye few hours back. Which of the following treatment options is best suited for this patient?
questions.solution:
The initial step in the management of a patient presenting with chemical burns is immediate and thorough irrigation with normal saline or clean water delivered through an IV tubing. This is done to prevent further damage. 

Along with irrigation, contaminant elimination through mechanical means should be done (e.g. using a swab stick to remove any visible particles)

After the initial steps, maintenance of favorable conditions for rapid and uncomplicated healing by following measures:

  • Topical antibiotic drops, for example, moxifloxacin 4-6 times a day to prevent infection. Cycloplegics, such as atropine, might enhance comfort. (option B)
  • Steroid eye drops to decrease inflammation, and neutrophil infiltration, and treat anterior uveitis. Caution is advised after 2 weeks, as steroids could disrupt collagen synthesis. (option C)

Grading of severity (Roper–Hall system) of chemical injuries is based on corneal clarity and severity of limbal ischemia:

  • Grade 1  is characterized by a clear cornea (epithelial damage only) and no limbal ischemia (excellent prognosis).
  • Grade 2 shows a hazy cornea but with visible iris detail and less than one-third of the limbus being ischemic (good prognosis).
  • Grade 3 manifests as a total loss of the corneal epithelium, stromal haze obscuring iris detail, and between one-third and half of the limbus showing ischemia (guarded prognosis).
  • Grade 4 manifests with an opaque cornea and more than 50% of the limbus showing ischemia (poor prognosis).

Temporal tarsorrhaphy is a surgical procedure in which the eyelids are stitched together. It is done for the protection of the cornea in cases of Bell's palsy or in cases of exposure keratopathy. (option D)

questions.text: A 55-year-old male with a known history of diabetes came with a wound on his foot. Identify the given condition.
questions.solution:
The given picture showing an ulcer with punched-out edges over a pressure point is most likely that of a trophic ulcer/neuropathic ulcer.

A neuropathic ulcer is one that occurs as a result of peripheral neuropathy. In peripheral neuropathy, lack of sensation over the pressure points leads to cumulative microtrauma, minor wounds, or cuts that remain unnoticed but eventually develop into ulcers.

Features of a neuropathic ulcer include

  • Painless ulcer
  • Punched out ulcer with regular margins
  • Often located on the plantar surface of the foot
  • Ulcer margins show the presence of calluses 
  Ischemic/Arterial Ulcer Venous Ulcer Neuropathic Ulcer  Tuberculous Ulcer   
Underlying condition

Peripheral vascular disease- mainly atherosclerosis, thromboangiitis obliterans, cervical rib, Raynaud's phenomenon

 Varicose veins, previous deep vein thrombosis Diabetes, peripheral neuropathy Tuberculosis lymph nodes, cold abscess from bone and joint tuberculosis
Location Toes, feet, legs, or even upper limb digits Lower limb, commonly on the medial side of the ankle, never above the middle third of the leg The plantar surface of the foot, toes Neck, axilla, and groin
Characteristics

Deep, penetrates the deep fascia exposing the tendons, muscles, and underlying bone.

The ulcer is painful, tender, and hyperaesthetic. 

 Vertically oval, and painless, the floor may have pale to no granulation tissue, induration, and tenderness at the base. Punched-out with regular calloused margins. 

Edges are thin, reddish blue, undermined; pale granulation tissue, scanty discharge on the floor, and slight induration at the base
Other features Features of ischemia in adjacent areas, like pallor, dry skin, brittle nails, loss of hair Inguinal lymph nodes are enlarged, usually, the vertical group and the ulcer is recurrent; forms again after healing Dry, cracked, insensate Regional lymph nodes are enlarged, non-tender, matted

 

Option A: The following is an image of a venous ulcer.

Option B: The following is an image of a malignant ulcer (squamous cell carcinoma).

Option C: The following is an image of an arterial ulcer.

questions.text: A 65-year-old male patient presents with a left groin swelling for a few years. The swelling increases in size on standing and decreases while lying on the bed. On examination, the swelling has a positive cough impulse. What is the most appropriate management for this patient?

choices.text: Reduction of content, repair of the defect and reinforcement with a mesh

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is an uncomplicated inguinal hernia.  An uncomplicated inguinal hernia is repaired by the reduction of the content, repair of the defect and reinforcement with mesh placement(Lichtenstein mesh repair).

A hernia is a protrusion of the contents outside the cavity containing it. Groin hernias arising lateral to the inferior epigastric artery are indirect and hernia arising medial to it are direct inguinal hernias. Hernias have two cardinal features- reducibility and cough impulse. A Lichtenstein mesh repair is currently one of the most frequently used methods for treating an inguinal hernia. It is done for the reconstruction of the inguinal floor in adults. It is an anterior tension-free mesh repair that reduces the chances of recurrence of a hernia. A piece of prosthetic nonabsorbable mesh is used to fit the canal to bridge the defect in this repair.

Other surgical methods used to repair a hernia are:

Bassini repair is done for the reconstruction of the inguinal floor in adults. In this method, a mesh is not used. It is associated with a high recurrence and is not used frequently now. It is used only in cases of hernial strangulation and peritonitis where the use of a mesh is not preferred. It is performed by suturing the transversus abdominis and internal oblique musculoaponeurotic arches/conjoined tendons to the inguinal ligament.  Shouldice repair is a multilayered repair, where the posterior wall of the inguinal canal is strengthened by continuous sutures. It involves double-breasting of the transversalis fascia. It is associated with a very low recurrence rate. These are herniorraphies (Option C)

Herniotomy is used to treat inguinal hernia in a child which occurs due to the presence of a patent processus vaginalis. Therefore in herniotomy, the repair of the inguinal ring is not done. (Option B)

McVay repair (Cooper's ligament repair) is used for the correction of direct inguinal hernia, large indirect hernia, recurrent hernia, femoral hernias (particularly suited for strangulated femoral hernias). In this method, the transversus abdominis aponeurosis is approximated to Cooper's ligament.

Stoppa-Rives repair is used for the repair of large, recurrent, or bilateral hernias. In this method, a sub-umbilical midline incision is given to place a large mesh into the preperitoneal space.

Related Pearl: Boundaries of Hesselbach’s triangle

  • Lateral - inferior epigastric artery
  • Medial - lateral border of rectus abdominis
  • Inferior - inguinal ligament

Direct inguinal hernia emerges through Hesselbach’s triangle (Hence situated medial to inferior epigastric artery)

Indirect inguinal hernia enters deep inguinal ring (Hence it is lateral to inferior epigastric artery)

Related Pearl: Types of indirect inguinal hernia

  • Bubonocele – Hernia limited to the inguinal canal.
  • Funicular – Hernia stops just above the testis.
  • Complete/scrotal – Hernia reaches bottom of scrotum.

Related Pearl: Difference between Direct and Indirect inguinal hernias:

questions.text: A 24-year-old presents with a scrotal swelling as shown in the image. The swelling is brilliantly transilluminant and the testes cannot be palpated separately. A CT scan was done which showed fluid collection in tunica vaginalis. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
In the above clinical scenario, there is a unilateral scrotal swelling in which the examiner cannot get above the swelling, and is transilluminant points towards a diagnosis of hydrocele. 

Hydrocoele is an accumulation of fluid within the tunica vaginalis. Hydrocele can be congenital or acquired. Congenital hydrocele is seen in children due to patent processes vaginalis. Acquired hydrocele can be secondary to inflammation or infection of the epididymis or testes. It is translucent on transillumination test and testes will not be separately palpable due to tense fluid collection. As it arises in the scrotum, it is possible to get above the swelling. Cough impulse is absent.

USG will show anechoic (due to fluid) reflection.

CT scan shows fluid collection within the scrotal sac.

Treatment involves Jaboulay's operation, in which the eversion of the sac upon itself is done to prevent refilling of the hydrocoele sac. The other method of treating the hydrocele is plicating the redundant tunica which can be done when the sac wall is thin. This is known as the Lord's operation.

Other options: 
Option A:  Hernia is a reducible swelling in which the examiner cannot get above the swelling and testes are palpable. 

Option B: Varicocele is a dilatation of the pampiniform plexus which feels like a dragging sensation to the patient. A scrotal swelling is not a usual presentation.

Option C: Seminoma is the most common germ cell tumour of the testes. They are hard on palpation. The CT scan will show homogenous hyperdensity and not fluid collection.

questions.text:
A patient who was in a road traffic accident and sustained an open fracture of the femur one hour ago was transfused with 3 units of PRBC. Two hours later, he develops hypotension, hypoxia, dyspnea, and bilateral interstitial infiltrates on chest X-ray. What is your diagnosis?

PRBC- Packed red blood cells
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of transfusion-related acute lung injury (TRALI).

TRALI is a sudden onset of respiratory failure resulting from the transfusion of donor fresh frozen plasma and platelets that contain high-titer of anti-HLA antibodies. These antibodies bind recipient leukocytes and aggregate in the pulmonary vasculature, releasing mediators that increase capillary permeability. 

The pathogenesis involves a two-hit hypothesis:

  • Priming event - increased sequestration and sensitization of neutrophils in the microvasculature of the lung
  • Second hit - the aggravating factor (most commonly MHC class II  antibodies) present in the transfused blood product activates the primed neutrophils

TRALI is a severe fatal complication of blood transfusion. The implicated donors are frequently multiparous women. Recipients with a history of pre-existing lung diseases, smoking, chronic alcohol use, mechanical ventilation and cancer surgeries are at increased risk of developing TRALI. 

The recipient develops symptoms of hypotension, fever, hypoxia and signs of noncardiogenic pulmonary edema, including bilateral interstitial infiltrates visible on the chest x-ray.

Treatment is supportive, and patients usually recover without sequelae. The incidence of TRALI has been reduced by choosing males and nulliparous women as donors.

Other options:

Option A: Anaphylaxis is characterized by dyspnea, hypotension, rash, and stridor due to bronchospasm, and pulmonary edema and chest infiltrate are not seen.

Option C: Transfusion-associated circulatory overload (TACO) is caused by rapid or excess transfusion of red cell preparations or plasma products. This condition is characterized by dyspnea, systolic hypertension, and cardiogenic pulmonary edema causing bilateral infiltrates on chest x-ray(elevated brain natriuretic peptide). It can be prevented by administering the transfusion slowly and treated with diuretics if necessary.

Option D: Hemolytic transfusion reaction may present with fever, chills, hypotension, tachycardia, dyspnea, chest and back pain, hemoglobinuria, and hemoglobinemia. In the most severe cases, DIC, acute renal failure, shock, and death may occur.

questions.text:
A 67-year-old patient with a history of thromboembolic stroke is currently taking aspirin and warfarin. He is complaining of a headache and appears confused after a fall in the toilet last night. NCCT of the head was done. What is the next best step in management?

NCCT-  Non contrast CT head

choices.text: Vitamin K, fresh frozen plasma and neurosurgery consultation

questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario and the plain computed tomography (CT) scan show a concave-convex-shaped hematoma on the left side suggestive of an acute subdural hematoma (SDH). Since, the patient is on anticoagulants, reversal with Vitamin K, FFP and immediate neurosurgical consultation would be the next best step. 

Acute SDH results from the accumulation of blood between the arachnoid membrane and the dura. The tearing of a bridging vein running from the cerebral cortex to the dural sinuses is the most common cause of acute SDH.

Radiographic features of subdural haemorrhages-Crescent-like distribution around the periphery of the brain. 
Crescent-shaped hypodense lesion on axial CT: Chronic subdural haemorrhage
Crescent-shaped hyperdense collections on CT: Acute subdural haemorrhage. 

On head CT scan, acute SDH appears as a hyperdense, crescent-shaped (concavo-convex) lesion (as seen in this question)

Open craniotomy for the evacuation of acute SDH is indicated for the following:

  1. Thickness >1 cm
  2. Midline shift >5 mm

Emergent decompression is also recommended for a comatose patient with an acute subdural hematoma less than 1 cm in thickness causing a midline shift of less than 5 mm if any of the following criteria are met:

  •  GCS drops by two or more points from the time of injury to the hospitalization
  •  The patient presents with fixed and dilated pupils
  • ICP is >20mm Hg

Other options:

Option A: Aspirin and Clopidogrel are given in patients with ischemic stroke. It is not required for this patient.

Option C: Mannitol is used to lower intracranial pressure. Raised features of intracranial pressure like vomiting, papilledema are not mentioned.

Option D: Only observation would be inappropriate in the case of Acute SDH.   

Related Pearl: Intracranial haemorrhage

questions.text: A young child presented to the emergency with pain in the right hand after falling from a height. An X-ray of the distal forearm and hand was done. The radiological image shows a physeal plate injury with a fracture extending to the metaphyses with the sparing of the epiphysis. What is the type of Salter-Harris physeal injury mentioned above?
questions.solution:
The type of Salter-Harris injury mentioned above is type II injury.

Type II fracture is an intraarticular fracture. In a type II Salter harris fracture, the fracture line traverses the epiphyseal plate and then into the metaphyses. This damages the growth plate and results in growth disturbance.

Salter-Harris classified epiphyseal injuries into 5 types as mentioned below.

Related Pearl: Types of Salter–Harris fractures- Mnemonic

There are nine types of Salter-Harris fractures. Among these, types I to V are more common.

The mnemonic "SALTER" can be used to help remember the first five types.

TYPE  MNEMONIC DESCRIPTION
Type I S = Slip/straight across Transverse fracture through the growth plate
Type II A = Away The fracture lies away from the joint. A fracture through the growth plate and the metaphysis, sparing the epiphysis
Type III L = Lower The fracture is below the physis in the epiphysis.
Type IV TE = Through Everything  A fracture through all three elements of the bone, the growth plate, metaphysis, and epiphysis
Type V R = Rammed (crushed)  A compression fracture of the growth plate

Rarer types VI to IX have been added subsequently.

  • Type VI - Injury to the perichondral structures
  • Type VII - Isolated injury to the epiphyseal plate
  • Type VIII - Isolated injury to the metaphysis, with a potential injury related to endochondral ossification
  • Type IX - Injury to the periosteum that may interfere with membranous growth

questions.text: On the day of delivery, a newborn baby is undergoing a screening test for hearing. Which of the following tests is likely to be performed?
questions.solution:
A newborn baby on the same day of delivery will undergo the Otoacoustic emissions (OAE) test as a screening test for hearing.

Universal Newborn Hearing Screening (UNHS) has become a standard practice in most developed countries. The identification of all newborns with hearing loss before 6 months has become an attainable and realistic goal. The goal is to screen newborn babies before 1 month of age, diagnose hearing loss before 3 months of age and start intervention as early as possible, or latest by 6 months of age.

In India, a two-stage screening protocol is followed according to which infants are screened first with otoacoustic emissions (OAE). Infants who fail the OAE are screened with auditory brainstem response (ABR) or Brainstem Evoked Response Audiometry (BERA), which is also the definitive test. All babies kept in NICU must be screened by BERA test as per the protocol.

The first screening is usually conducted at birth or before discharge. Conducting the first screening before discharge is preferred to ensure better coverage and reduce loss to follow-up. A second screening is scheduled anytime between 1–3 weeks or during the next scheduled visit at 6 weeks. 
All babies with abnormal BERA should undergo detailed ENT evaluation and hearing-aid fitting (cochlear implants) and auditory rehabilitation must be done before 6 months of age.

Related Pearl: OAEs - Otoacoustic emissions

It is an objective test that records the low-intensity sounds produced by the outer hair cells of a normal cochlea.

It is of two types:

  • Spontaneous type- it is generated spontaneously and is present in 50% of normal individuals.
  • Evoked types- also called Kemp echoes or cochlear echoes, are generated in response to sound stimulus and found in all individuals with normal hearing. The two subtypes are transient evoked and distortion product.

The applications are as follows:

  • Best audiometric test for screening in neonates, infants, and small children for deafness due to inner ear causes.
  • Helps to differentiate cochlear and retrocochlear hearing loss- normal OAE indicates normal cochlea and hence retrocochlear pathology in a patient with sensorineural deafness.
  • Early detection of noise-induced hearing loss- since it is generated by outer hair cells that are prone to damage by noise trauma.

Related Pearl: BERA (Brainstem Evoked Response Audiometry) or ABR (Auditory Brainstem Response)

It is an objective test that records electrical activity occurring in the auditory pathway.

Normally, 7 waves are produced in the first 10ms. 

  • Wave I – distal part of the cochlear nerve
  • Wave II –proximal part of the cochlear nerve
  • Wave III – cochlear nucleus
  • Wave IV – superior olivary complex
  • Wave V – lateral lemniscus
  • Wave VI – inferior colliculus
  • Wave VII - medial geniculate body

Findings:

  • Conductive or cochlear pathology- delayed wave-I but inter-peak latency of I-V is normal
  • Retrocochlear pathology- wave-I present, rest of the waves absent
  • Acoustic neuroma or vestibular schwannoma- increased inter-peak latency of wave I-V and increased inter-aural latency of wave V > 0.2ms.

Uses:

  • To objectively find hearing threshold- wave-V appears 10dB above the hearing level obtained through PTA
  • Best audiometric test for:
    • Confirming hearing loss in infants
    • Diagnosing acoustic neuroma
    • Differentiating cochlear and retro-cochlear hearing loss
    • Diagnosing non-organic hearing loss.

Related Pearl: Pure tone audiometry (PTA)

A pure tone is the sound of a single frequency. An audiometer is a device that generates pure tones and its frequency can be increased or decreased by 5Hz.

The threshold for air conduction (AC) of sound frequencies from 125-8000 Hz and the threshold for bone conduction (BC) of sound frequencies from 250-4000 Hz is measured and the result is plotted on an audiogram.

Normal thresholds:
  • For AC: 15 dB
  • For BC: 25 dB

Symbols used in pure tone audiometry:

 

Disease Findings in PTA audiogram
Conductive hearing loss AC abnormal, BC normal, air-bone gap present
Sensorineural hearing loss Both AC and BC are abnormal and no air-Bone gap
Mixed hearing loss Both AC and BC abnormal and air-bone gap present
Presbycusis, ototoxicity, noise-induced hearing loss (higher frequencies affected first) Downsloping or descending audiogram 
Early stages of Meniere's disease (lower frequencies affected first) Upsloping or ascending audiogram
Congenital hearing loss and cochlear otosclerosis (mid-frequency hearing loss) U-shaped or trough-shaped or cookie bite shaped audiogram
Early cases of noise-induced hearing loss

Acoustic dip - characteristic dip in both AC and BC at 4000 Hz
Otosclerosis  Carhart's notch- dip at 2000 Hz in BC curve

questions.text: Which of the following statements is correct regarding the device shown below?

choices.text: It is used to measure infrared rays emitted by red blood cells
It is used for the localisation of calcified plaque
It is used to measure systolic blood pressure
It is used to measure blood flow and detect blood flow abnormalities in  the blood vessel

questions.solution:
The given image is of a handheld doppler device. It is used to measure blood flow and detect blood flow abnormalities in the blood vessel.

The Doppler ultrasound device utilizes the doppler effect to assess the movement of red blood cells within blood vessels. The doppler effect is the change in frequency or wavelength of a wave in relation to an observer moving relative to the wave source. The device emits ultrasound waves that reflect off moving red blood cells. The frequency shift between the transmitted and received sound waves is used to calculate the velocity and direction of blood flow.

By analyzing these frequency shifts, the device can provide information about the speed and pattern of blood flow. This is particularly useful in detecting abnormalities such as blockages or stenosis.

Other options:

Option A: Doppler ultrasound does not measure infrared rays. Infrared measurements are typically related to thermal imaging or other specific applications unrelated to blood flow measurement.

Option B: Doppler ultrasound can help identify areas of reduced blood flow due to plaques, it is not specifically used for the localization of calcified plaque. Techniques like computed tomography (CT) or MRI are better suited for visualizing calcified plaques.

Option C: While Doppler can assist in certain vascular assessments, it is not a primary tool for measuring systolic or diastolic blood pressure.

questions.text: Ostmann fat pads are associated with which of the following structures?
questions.solution:
The Ostmann fat pads are masses of fatty tissues located inferolateral to the cartilaginous eustachian tubes.

It helps keep the tube closed, protecting it from the reflux of nasopharyngeal secretions and also prevents the transmission of nasopharyngeal pressure to the middle ear.

Failure to visualise this thin triangular fat pad on MRI is a feature of patulous tube syndrome.

questions.text: A patient came to OPD with a complaint of dilated and tortuous veins in the left leg and mild pain while walking. On palpation, the vein is pulsatile. He had a history of road traffic accident, including a left leg fracture 10 years ago. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient with a history of trauma and a recently developed pulsatile swelling of the same side has a traumatic arteriovenous fistula.
An arteriovenous fistula is an abnormal communication between an artery and a vein and tends to occur when two structures are in proximity. Traumatic AVF can occur secondary to penetrating and blunt trauma. The most common traumatic AV fistula is a carotid-cavernous fistula secondary to the base of the skull fracture.
Clinical features: pulsatile swelling and in chronic cases- limb lengthening, arterialisation of veins and heart failure. Large extremity fistula may present with skin warmth in contrast to cool extremity and signs of venous hypertension which is usually seen in varicosities. 

Diagnosis: Ultrasonography can detect flow anomalies. CT angiography can provide anatomic delineation.

Other options

Option A: Varicose veins can present with dilated tortuous veins. However, they are not pulsatile and with a history of trauma AV fistula is more likely.

Option B: Pseudoaneurysms do not present with dilated and tortuous veins. 

Option D: Atherosclerosis doesn't present with dilated veins and pulsatile swellings.

questions.text: A 5-month-old baby was brought to the hospital with fever, poor feeding and abnormal twitching of his lower limb. On examination, a bulging fontanelle was observed. CSF analysis revealed gram-stained microorganisms, neutrophilic pleocytosis, elevated protein, and reduced glucose concentrations. Which is the most common neurological sequel of this condition that can develop?
questions.solution:
The clinical features of poor feeding, fever, seizures, bulging fontanelle (due to raised ICP), and lethargy with the mentioned CSF findings are suggestive of bacterial meningitis, and sensorineural hearing loss is the most common sequelae which can develop in cases of bacterial meningitis. 

Sensory neural hearing loss is a result of cochlear infection or direct inflammation of the auditory nerve. All patients with bacterial meningitis should undergo an audiological assessment before discharge from the hospital, or immediately after. Neurological sequelae of meningitis include:

  • Hearing loss (most common)
  • Cognitive impairment & behavioral problems (Option C)
  • Recurrent seizures
  • Delay in the acquisition of language
  • Visual impairment (Option A)
  • Noncommunicating hydrocephalus (Option C)

Bacterial meningitis may be caused due to Meningococcus, Streptococcus pneumonia, or Haemophilus influenzae type b. The non-specific symptoms and signs include fever, rash, lethargy, refusal to feed, vomiting, etc. Specific symptoms and signs such as photophobia, nuchal rigidity, bulging of the fontanel, and clinical signs of meningeal irritation (Kernig and Brudzinski's sign), are not usually seen in infants. Seizures and focal neurological signs may be present.

The diagnosis of meningitis is confirmed by CSF analysis which typically shows microorganisms on Gram stain and culture, a neutrophilic pleocytosis, increased protein, and decreased glucose concentrations. Blood cultures should be done in all cases of suspected meningitis.

questions.text: Which is the most common type of anemia in a 65-year-old male?
questions.solution:
The most common type of anaemia in a 65-year-old male is iron deficiency anemia(IDA). It is also the most common type of nutritional anemia in India.

WHO recommendations for diagnosing anemia (g/dl) are:

Population Normal Mild Anemia Moderate Anemia Severe Anemia
Men ≥15 years ≥13 11 - 12.9 8 - 10.9 <8
Non-pregnant women ≥12 11 - 11.9 8 - 10.9 <8
Pregnant women ≥11 10 - 10.9 7 - 9.9 <7

IDA is an example of microcytic hypochromic anemia. The causes of IDA can be inadequate diet, impaired reabsorption, increased requirement, and increased blood loss.

The manifestations of IDA depend upon the underlying cause. In general, IDA presents with koilonychia, alopecia, atrophic changes in the tongue, gastric mucosa, malabsorption and pica (craving for consumption of non-edible materials)

Peripheral smears show small and pale red cells typically described as microcytic (reduced MCV) and hypochromic (enlarged zone of central pallor). Poikilocytosis can be seen in the form of elongated red cells, known as pencil cells. Target cells can be found in cases of severe IDA.

Diagnosis is mainly by laboratory studies. The typical findings are:

  • Low hemoglobin and hematocrit
  • Low serum iron and ferritin
  • Increased Total Iron Binding Capacity (TIBC)
  • Hepcidin is low (decreased stores of iron inhibit hepcidin synthesis)

IDA is treated by giving oral and parenteral preparations of iron or packed cell transfusion depending upon the severity of the anemia.

Other options:

Option A: In aplastic anemia, the bone marrow does not produce enough progenitor cells. It can be caused by autoimmune diseases, medications, and radiation. Aplastic anemia can lead to a decrease in all types of blood cells and is associated with a low MCV and a low hemoglobin level, not a high MCV.

Option B: Megaloblastic anemia can be caused by a deficiency of vitamin B12 or folate. Vegetarians are at increased risk of vitamin B12 deficiency because vitamin B12 is primarily found in animal products. Other conditions can also cause megaloblastic anemia, such as celiac disease, Crohn's disease, and ulcerative colitis

Option D: Anemia of chronic disease is mediated by hepcidin, a positive acute-phase reactant (APR) that increases in chronic inflammatory states.It is seen in conditions such as inflammatory bowel disease, rheumatoid arthritis, chronic infections, and malignancies.

Related Pearl: Differential Diagnosis of Microcytic Anaemia

Investigation Iron- Deficiency Anemia Thalassemia Minor Anemia of Chronic Disease
Serum Iron <50 µg/dL Normal/Increased Decreased
Serum Ferritin <30 µg/L Normal/Increased Increased
TIBC Increased Normal Decreased
Transferrin saturation <15% Normal Normal/Decreased
Transferrin Receptor-Ferritin Index High (>2) Normal Low (<2)
MCV Decreased Markedly Decreased May be low or normal
RBC count <5 million/µL >5 million/µL Normal
Mentzer Index ≥13 <13 N/A
RDW-CV(%) >15 <15 Normal/Increased

TIBC: Total iron-binding capacity

questions.text: A 21-year-old female patient underwent surgery on her middle ear and a nerve was injured intraoperatively. She came a week later to OPD with difficulty in closing her eyes on the same side. Ocular examination reveals decreased corneal sensation and dryness of the cornea.  Which of the following cranial nerves was most likely injured during the surgery?
questions.solution:
This patient with a past history of intra-op nerve injury during middle ear surgery presented with dry eye, decreased corneal sensation, and incomplete eyelid closure (lagophthalmos) due to injury to cranial nerve (CN)VII. 

Lagophthalmos can be caused by conditions such as facial nerve injury, parkinsonism (reduced muscle tone), lid scarring, and proptosis. The facial nerve runs horizontally in the medial wall and vertically in the posterior wall of the middle ear. Hence, they can be injured due to surgery of the middle ear.  Clinical features include dry eyes, decreased corneal sensation which can eventually lead to  mild punctate epithelial changes and epithelial breakdown. 

CN VII lies in proximity to the middle ear. Hence there are chances of nerve injury during middle ear surgery.
The given image shows the course of the facial nerve within the middle ear cavity. 

Treatment depends on whether the exposure is reversible or permanent. Reversible exposure can be treated with artificial tears and eye ointments. The eyelid can be taped closed at night or external barriers like bandage silicone hydrogel or scleral contact lenses can be used. Permanent exposure requires permanent tarsorrhaphy.

Other options: 

Option B - CN IV palsy leads to paralysis of superior oblique muscles.

Option C - CN VI palsy leads to lateral rectus palsy and lateral gaze palsy.

Option D - CN III injury leads to injury of levator palpebrae superioris and ptosis. 

None of these nerves pass through the middle ear.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male patient presents with a bulky scrotal swelling. On evaluation, malignancy is suspected. Orchidectomy is done and the gross section is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given cut section of testicular mass is homogenous, grey-white, and does not show haemorrhage or necrosis suggesting a diagnosis of seminoma.

Seminoma is the most common testicular tumour. In about 15% of cases, serum HCG levels are raised as these seminomas contain syncytiotrophoblasts. Lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) levels are also measured to assess tumour burden. They are bulky, homogenous, pale, and well-circumscribed masses that do not show any haemorrhage or necrosis, as shown in the image below.

 Microscopically, sheets of uniform tumour cells divided into poorly demarcated lobules by fibrous septa are seen. Each cell is large, and round, and has a distinct cell membrane, abundant clear cytoplasm, and a large central nucleus with a few nucleoli.

Therapy depends on the stage of the tumour. Seminoma has the best prognosis. Most cases of seminoma stages I and II can be cured by orchidectomy with or without chemotherapy or radiotherapy.

Other options:

Option B, C: Yolk sac tumour and endodermal sinus tumour  will not present with a homogenous appearance on gross examination. 

Option D: Teratoma has origins from ectodermal, mesodermal and endodermal germ cell layers. The gross cut section will have tissues from this origin. 

Related Pearl: Tumor Markers in Testicular Germ Cell

 

AFP

b-hCG

LDH

Seminoma

 -

+

++

Yolk sac tumor

+++

+

+

Choriocarcinoma

 -

+++

+

Embryonal carcinoma

+

+

++

Teratoma

 - 

 -

 -

 Note:

 Alpha-fetoprotein AFP:

  • Embryonal carcinoma
  • Yolk sac tumor
  • Teratocarcinoma
  • Mixed germ cell tumor
  •  AFP is never raised in pure seminomas or pure choriocarcinoma

human chorionic gonadotropin (HCG): Only the β subunit is measured by the most commonly available serum assays. Can be raised in

  • Choriocarcinoma
  • Embryonal carcinoma
  • Teratocarcinoma
  • Seminoma
  • Mixed germ-cell tumors

 Lactate dehydrogenase (LDH):

  • LDH has limited sensitivity and specificity for seminoma, but LDH levels >2000 U/L are more consistent with bulky disease, and rising levels are an accurate indicator of recurrence.
  •  In non-seminomatous germ-cell tumors (NSCGT), LDH is directly related to tumor burden.

Related Pearl: WHO 2016 classification of testicular tumors

I. Germ-cell tumors (GCTs) derived from germ-cell neoplasia in situ

  • Germ-cell neoplasia in situ
  • Seminoma
  • Non-seminomatous GCTs
    • Embryonal carcinoma
    • Yolk sac tumor, postpubertal-type
    • Choriocarcinoma
    • Teratoma, post-pubertal type
  • Mixed germ-cell tumors

II. Germ-cell tumors unrelated to germ-cell neoplasia in situ

  • Spermatocytic tumour
  • Teratoma, prepubertal type
  • Yolk sac tumor, prepubertal type

III. Sex cord stromal tumors

  • Leydig cell tumor
  • Sertoli cell tumor
  • Granulosa cell tumor
  • Fibroma–thecoma

IV. Tumor containing both germ-cell and sex cord-stromal elements

  • Gonadoblastoma

V. Hematolymphoid tumors
