questions.text: During recovery from anaesthesia, which of the following drugs is used for the reversal of neuromuscular blockade?
questions.solution:
Neostigmine is a cholinesterase inhibitor commonly used during reversal of anaesthesia.

Reversal agents commonly used in clinical practice:

Cholinesterase inhibitors - Neostigmine (most common), edrophonium, and pyridostigmine.
Sugammadex, a cyclodextrin, is the first selective relaxant binding agent for rocuronium and vecuronium.
L-cysteine causes the inactivation of gantacurium.

Other options:

Option B, C:  Anticholinergic drugs like glycopyrrolate and atropine are not used for the reversal of neuromuscular blockade. They only attenuate the undesirable muscarinic effects of anticholinesterase reversal agents. 

Option D: Propofol is a barbiturate group of drug which is used for induction of anaesthesia.

questions.text: What is the most common cause of thrombocytopenia in pregnancy?
questions.solution:
The most common cause of thrombocytopenia in pregnancy is gestational thrombocytopenia. This may be due to hemodilution and increased platelet consumption in pregnancy.

Pregnancy is a hypercoagulable state. Hematological changes in pregnancy include:

  • All clotting factors are increased (except factor 11,13) and fibrinogen levels are also increased.
  • Clotting time and bleeding time are unaffected.
  • The viscosity of blood doesn’t increase since plasma volume increases more in comparison to red cell volume, it merely decreases whole blood viscosity.
  • Anticoagulants Protein C, Protein S and antithrombin decrease during pregnancy.
  • Fibrinolytic activity remains depressed till about 15 minutes after pregnancy

Related Pearl: Cardiovascular changes in pregnancy

  • The resting pulse rate increases by 10 beats/min
  • The apex is moved laterally 
  • Cardiac output remains elevated throughout (maximum in the immediate postpartum period)
  • X-Ray shows a larger cardiac silhouette (due to benign pericardial effusion and shifted apex)
  • ECG: Slight left axis deviation

Heart sounds:

  • First heart sound: Loud with an exaggerated split
  • Second heart sound: Normal but loud
  • Third heart sound: Loud and easily heard

Murmurs:

  • A systolic murmur that was intensified during inspiration or expiration
  • A soft diastolic murmur (in 20%)
  • Continuous murmur arising from the breast vasculature (in 10%)

questions.text: You are the intern posted in the emergency department. You came across an ABG report given below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given ABG report shows decreased blood arterial pH(Normal range: 7.35-7.45), and decreased HCO3 levels(Normal: 22-28 mEq/L) indicating metabolic acidosis.

Metabolic disorders

Conditions Features Etiology
Metabolic acidosis

There is decreased blood arterial pH because of an increase in endogenous acid production (Example: Diabetic ketoacidosis, increased lactate in sepsis), loss of HCO3- (Example: diarrhea), or low excretion of net acid by kidneys (Example: chronic kidney disease). Respiratory compensation (alveolar hyperventilation) occurs causing a decrease in PaCO2.

High anionic metabolic acidosis

  • Methanol
  • Uremia
  • Diabetic ketoacidosis
  • Propylene glycol
  • Iron tablets
  • Lactic acidosis
  • Ethylene glycol
  • Salicylates (Late)

Normal anionic gap metabolic acidosis

  • Hyperalimentation
  • Addison's disease
  • Renal tubular acidosis
  • Diarrhea
  • Acetazolamide
  • Spironolactone
  • Saline infusion
Metabolic alkalosis

There is increased blood arterial pH, as a result of a net gain of HCO3- or a loss of nonvolatile acid from the extracellular fluid. Compensatory alveolar hypoventilation occurs and causes an increase in PaCO2. 

Loss of hydrogen:

  • Gastrointestinal loss
    • Removal of gastric secretions- vomiting or nasogastric suction
    • Chloride-losing diarrhea
    • Gastrocolic fistula
    • Villous adenoma
    • Antacid therapy, particularly if combined with cation exchange resin
  • Renal loss
    • Loop or thiazide diuretics
    • Mineralocorticoid excess (primary aldosteronism, Cushing's, steroids, licorice)
    • Posthypercapnic states
    • Hypercalcemia, including the milk-alkali syndrome
  • H+ movement into cells
    • Hypokalemia

Exogenous Alkali:

  • Administration of NaHCO3, sodium citrate/gluconate/acetate/antacids
  • Massive blood transfusion
  • Antacids- Milk alkali syndrome

Contraction alkalosis (loss of ECF volume):

  • Loop or thiazide-type diuretics
  • Sweat losses in cystic fibrosis
  • Gastric losses in achlorhydria

Miscellaneous:

  • Bartter's syndrome
  • Gitelman's syndrome
Respiratory acidosis

There is decreased blood arterial pH as a result of an increase in PaCO2 following alveolar hypoventilation.
  • Central: Stroke, infection
  • Airway: Obstruction, Asthma
  • Lung Parenchyma: Emphysema, Pneumoconiosis, Bronchitis
  • Neuromuscular: Muscular dystrophies, Myasthenia
  • Obesity
  • Hypoventilation
Respiratory alkalosis

There is an increase in blood arterial pH due to a decrease in PaCO2 due to alveolar hyperventilation.

Hyperventilation

  • Anxiety/panic attack
  • Hypoxemia( eg: High altitude)
  • Salicylates (Early)
  • Pulmonary embolism
  • Tumor

Related Pearl: Acid-Base Balance - Normal Values

Component Normal Range Optimal Value
pH 7.35 - 7.45 7.4
HCO3-  22 - 28 mEq/L   24 mEq/L
pCO2 35 - 45 mmHg 40 mmHg 
Anion gap 6 - 12 mEq/L <10 mEq/L
O2 saturation > 95%
pO2 75 - 100 mmHg  

Related Pearl: Interpretation of Acid-Base Disorders

pH<7.35 is acidosis

pH>7.45 is alkalosis

A primary change in HCO3- is termed metabolic

If the change in HCO3- is in keeping with the pH (i.e. if there are acidosis and HCO3- is decreased) the problem is metabolic.

If the change in HCO3- is opposite with the pH (i.e. if there is acidosis and HCO3- is increased or normal) the problem is compensatory metabolic.

A primary change in CO2 is termed as respiratory

If the change in CO2 keeping in line with the pH (if in acidosis CO2 is raised) the problem is termed respiratory

If the change in CO2 is in the opposite direction of that of the pH (i.e. if there are acidosis and CO2 is decreased or normal ) the problem is termed compensatory respiratory

Related Pearl: Expected compensation in acid-base disorders

Primary disorder Expected compensation
Metabolic acidosis

Expected PaCO2 = [1 .5 X HCO3-] + 8 ± 2; or

↓ PaCO2 = 1.25 x ΔHCO3
Metabolic alkalosis Increase in PaCO2 = 0.75 x ΔHCO3-

Respiratory acidosis
Acute

Increase in HCO3- = 0.1 x Δ PaCO2

↓ pH = 0.008 x ΔPaCO2
Chronic

Increase in HCO3- = 0.4 x Δ PaCO2

↓ pH = 0.003 x ΔPaCO2

Respiratory alkalosis

Acute

Decrease in HCO3- = 0.2 x Δ PaCO2

↑ pH = 0.008 x ΔPaCO2

Chronic

Decrease in HCO3- = 0.4 x Δ PaCO2

questions.text: According to the American Society of Anaesthesiologists (ASA) classification, what grade is given to a normal healthy individual?
questions.solution:
A normal healthy individual is given ASA I grade. 

Related Pearl: American Society of Anesthesiologists’ Physical Status Classification of Patients

American Society of Anesthesiologists’(ASA) classification is used to define relative risk prior to conscious sedation and surgical anesthesia.

It is simple, reproducible and strongly correlates to perioperative risk.

ASA PS Classification & Definition Examples, including, but not limited to:
ASA I: A normal healthy patient Healthy, non-smoking, no or minimal alcohol use
ASA II: A patient with mild systemic disease Without substantive functional limitations. Eg: current smoker, social alcohol drinker, pregnancy, obesity (30 < BMI < 40), well-controlled DM/HTN, mild lung disease
ASA III: A patient with severe systemic disease Substantive functional limitations; One or more moderate to severe diseases. Eg: poorly controlled DM or HTN, COPD, morbid obesity (BMI ≥40), active hepatitis, alcohol dependence or abuse, implanted pacemaker, moderate reduction of ejection fraction, ESRD undergoing regularly scheduled dialysis, premature infant PCA < 60 weeks, history (>3 months) of MI, CVA, TIA, or CAD/stents.
ASA IV: A patient with severe systemic disease that is a constant threat to life Eg: recent ( < 3 months) MI, CVA, TIA, or CAD/stents, ongoing cardiac ischemia or severe valve dysfunction, severe reduction of ejection fraction, sepsis, DIC, ARD or ESRD not undergoing regularly scheduled dialysis
ASA V: A moribund patient who is not expected to survive without the operation Eg: ruptured abdominal/thoracic aneurysm, massive trauma, intracranial bleed with mass effect, ischemic bowel in the face of significant cardiac pathology or multiple organ/system dysfunction
ASA VI: A declared brain-dead patient whose organs are being removed for donor purposes

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman is in labour, and during delivery, the baby's head is delivered, but the shoulders get stuck. The baby's head is at the introitus. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This clinical vignette of a 28-year-old woman in labour with the baby's head at the introitus and the shoulders being stuck is suggestive of shoulder dystocia. 

Shoulder dystocia, defined as a head-to-body delivery time >60 seconds, occurs when either the anterior or the posterior (rare) fetal shoulder impacts on the maternal symphysis or the sacral promontory respectively.  A positive turtle sign may be seen which refers to a definite recoil of the head back against the perineum.

Risk factors for the development of shoulder dystocia include maternal diabetes mellitus, obesity, post-dated pregnancy, excessive weight gain during pregnancy, etc.  Wood's corkscrew maneuver is used to deliver the impacted shoulder in this condition.

Woods corkscrew maneuver: Pro­gressive rotation of the posterior shoulder 180 degrees in a corkscrew fashion releases the impacted anterior shoulder.

Other options:

Option A: Face Presentation - In a face presentation, the baby presents with the face as the presenting part instead of the vertex. The baby’s head is typically fully extended, leading to complications during delivery. However, once the head is delivered, the body usually follows without significant issues. The scenario described involves difficulty after the head is delivered, specifically with the shoulders, which is not characteristic of face presentation.

Option B: Occipito-sacral arrest- This refers to the baby being in a persistent occiput posterior position (with the baby facing up towards the mother’s abdomen rather than down). Labor may progress more slowly or stop when the baby’s head fails to rotate and descend properly. However, like with CPD, occipito-sacral arrest typically results in difficulty before the head is delivered, not after. If the head has been delivered but the shoulders are stuck, it indicates a different issue.

Option C: Cephalopelvic disproportion(CPD) - CPD occurs when the baby's head or body is too large to fit through the mother's pelvis. This can lead to labor not progressing or being arrested before the baby’s head is fully delivered. In CPD, labor arrest or failure to descend is seen, and the baby’s head may not pass through the pelvis at all. Since in the scenario described above, the head is already delivered and the shoulders are the issue, CPD is less likely to be the cause.

questions.text: A 40-year-old lady comes with complaints of abdominal cramping and breast pain that is cyclical and occurs once a month. It is associated with headaches and difficulty concentrating at work. She notices that the pain begins a week before menstruation and resolves after menses. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of premenstrual syndrome.

Premenstrual syndrome (premenstrual tension) is a functional disorder and is recognized by cyclical changes that are associated with ovulatory cycles. It is usually seen in middle-aged women and occurs 1-2 weeks before menstruation and resolves after menses. 

The classical symptoms include abdominal cramps, increasing breast tenderness, abdominal bloating, headache, sleeplessness, fatigue, difficulty in concentrating, and mood swings. The diagnosis is made on the basis of a carefully elicited history. Asking patients to document their symptoms in the form of a menstrual diary can also aid in diagnosis. 

Treatment includes counseling and therapy for psychological symptoms, limiting salt intake, and symptomatic treatment of breast tenderness and pelvic pain. Vitamins B1, B6, and E may be used.

Other options:

Option A: Spasmodic dysmenorrhea is the cramping pain that accompanies menstruation and is most pronounced on the first and second day of menses.

Option B: Periductal mastitis is a chronic relapsing infection of the subareolar duct of the breast. It can manifest as subareolar pain and erythema. Repeated infections can lead to scarring that causes inversion or retraction of the nipple, subareolar masses, etc. 

Option C: Endometriosis is a condition characterized by ectopic benign endometrial tissue that occurs outside the uterine cavity. Patients present with dysmenorrhea, dyspareunia, menorrhagia, and infertility.

questions.text: A 65-year-old male patient presents with a direct inguinal hernia on the left side. He underwent open hernioplasty with mesh repair. Which of the following nerves is most likely to be injured?
questions.solution:
The ilioinguinal nerve is most commonly injured within open hernia repair due to traction or thermal injury. The ilioinguinal nerve provides innervation to the groin and medial aspect of the thigh, the upper part of the scrotum, and the penile root.

Other options:

Option B: The iliohypogastric nerve carries the sensory supply from the suprapubic area. Injury to this nerve in the right iliac fossa rarely causes sensory disturbances, as the suprapubic area has a rich nerve supply from other sources too. If the nerve is severed above the anterior superior iliac spine, it can lead to the weakened posterior wall of the inguinal canal resulting in a direct inguinal hernia. The iliohypogastric nerve can also get injured following appendicectomy.

Option C: Injury to the genital branch of the genitofemoral nerve results in loss of sensation in the skin of the scrotum of males, and loss of sensation of the mons pubis and labia majora in females. 

Option D: Injury to the femoral branch of the genitofemoral nerve causes hypoesthesia over the anterior thigh below the inguinal ligament.

Note: The femoral branch of the genitofemoral nerve and genital branch of the genitofemoral nerve are injured less commonly. 

Related Pearl: The triangle of pain/Electrical hazard zone:

The triangle of pain/Electrical hazard zone:

It is bounded

  • Superio-medially by gonadal vessels
  • Laterally by peritoneum
  • Inferio-laterally by the iliopubic tract

Contents:

  • Lateral femoral cutaneous nerve
  • Anterior femoral cutaneous nerve
  • Femoral branch of the genitofemoral nerve
  • Femoral nerves

Related Pearl: The triangle of doom

The triangle of doom is bounded

  • Medially by the vas deferens
  • Laterally by the vessels of the spermatic cord (gonadal vessels)
  • Inferiorly by peritoneal reflection

Apex oriented superiorly at internal ring.

The contents of the space include

  • External iliac vessels
  • Deep circumflex iliac vein
  • Femoral nerve
  • Genital branch of the genitofemoral nerve

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presented with a history of ear discharge in the left ear for the past 4 weeks, deep-seated ear pain for the past 1 week, and diplopia for the past 2 days. Her symptoms have progressed gradually over the past 4 weeks. Which of the following signs/syndrome is seen in the above condition?
questions.solution:
The given scenario is a typical presentation of Gradenigo’s Syndrome, which occurs secondary to petrositis (a complication of otitis media).

Gradenigo’s syndrome is a triad that consists of:

  • Ipsilateral abducens nerve palsy (VI nerve palsy)
  • Deep ear/facial pain (V Nerve involvement)
  • Persistent ear discharge (otitis media)

Other options:

Option A: Griesinger’s sign is mastoid tenderness and edema, which is secondary to thrombophlebitis of the mastoid emissary vein. It is seen in sigmoid sinus thrombosis.

Option C: Grisel syndrome refers to atlantoaxial joint subluxation. It is associated with the overuse of diathermy either for the removal of the adenoid or following curettage when used for hemostasis. The patient complains of neck pain and develops torticollis.

Option D: Holman-Miller sign or antral sign is the anterior bowing of the maxillary wall due to the presence of a mass in the pterygomaxillary space on a CT scan. Holman-Miller sign is a pathognomonic feature of angiofibroma.

questions.text: In the case of anterior ethmoidal neuralgia, where is the anterior ethmoidal nerve most commonly compressed?
questions.solution:
The middle meatus is the most common site of compression of the anterior ethmoidal nerve causing neuralgia.

Anterior ethmoidal neuralgia, also known as Sluder's neuralgia is caused when the anterior ethmoidal nerve, a branch of the nasociliary nerve (which is itself a branch of the ophthalmic nerve, CN V1), is compressed. The most common site of compression is at the middle meatus, where the nerve may be impinged by anatomical variations, inflammation, or other pathologies affecting the paranasal sinuses.

The anterior ethmoidal nerve enters the nasal cavity by descending through the cribriform plate near the crista galli. Once in the nasal cavity, the nerve descends along the lateral wall of the nasal cavity. It runs above the superior border of the middle meatus and provides sensory innervation to the mucosa of the anterior part of the lateral wall of the nasal cavity

The patient typically presents with severe, sharp, and stabbing pain localized to the forehead and the root of the nose, often radiating to the periocular region. The pain is usually unilateral but can occasionally be bilateral. Associated symptoms may include tenderness over the affected area and occasionally nasal congestion or discharge if there is concurrent sinusitis.

Computed Tomography (CT) or Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI) of the paranasal sinuses can be employed to identify anatomical variations, mucosal thickening, or other potential sources of nerve compression.

Management involves analgesics (such as NSAIDs or acetaminophen) and, in more severe cases, neuropathic pain medications like gabapentin or pregabalin can be used to alleviate pain.
Nasal corticosteroids or saline nasal irrigation may be prescribed to reduce inflammation and relieve associated nasal symptoms.
Surgical Intervention is considered in cases where conservative treatments are ineffective and anatomical abnormalities are identified.

questions.text: In which of the following scenarios can outlet forceps be used?
questions.solution:
Outlet forceps can be used when the head of the fetus is at the perineum.

Outlet forceps/ Wrigley's forceps is light, about a third of the weight of ordinary long-curved forceps. The instrument is short which is due to a reduction in the length of the shanks and handles. It has a marked cephalic curve with a slight pelvic curve.

Criteria for outlet forceps delivery:

  • Scalp at introitus without separating labia
  • Skull at the pelvic floor
  • Sagittal suture in anterioposterior diameter, right or left occiput anterior, occiput anterior
  • Fetal head on the perineum
  • Rotation less than 45 degrees

The image below shows Wrigley's forceps/outlet forceps:

Related Pearl: Obstetrics forceps

Commonly used forceps: 

1) Simpson forceps

  • The most commonly used types of forceps in outlet delivery.
  • Has elongated cephalic curve.
  • These are used when there is substantial molding of the fetal head.

2) Elliot forceps

  • Has an adjustable pin for regulating the lateral pressure on the handles.
  • They are used most often when there is minimal molding.
  • More suitable for outlet delivery.

3) Kielland forceps

  • Has small pelvic curve and a sliding lock.
  • Suitable for head with little molding.
  • The most common forceps used for rotational delivery.
  • Helps correct asynclitism.

4) Piper forceps

  • Distinct perineal curve.
  • Allows for application to the after-coming head in breech delivery.

5) Tucker-McLane forceps

  • Suitable for fetal head with little molding.
  • Used in rotational delivery.

6) Barton forceps and traction handle

  • Used in rotational delivery.
  • Most importantly used for delivery of occipitotransverse positions in a platypelloid pelvis.
  • It is an obsolete procedure.

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman, G2A1, presents with heavy vaginal bleeding with cramp-like abdominal pain at 18 weeks of gestation. On examination, the uterine size corresponds to the period of gestation and  active vaginal bleeding is noted with an open internal os. USG reveals absent fetal cardiac activity. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario and examination findings of active vaginal bleeding and open internal os, with the uterine size corresponding to the period of gestation, is suggestive of inevitable abortion.

Inevitable abortion is a type of abortion where the abortive process has progressed to a state where continuation of pregnancy is impossible.

Clinical features:

  • Increased vaginal bleeding as compared to threatened abortion.
  • Aggravated lower abdominal colicky pain
  • Uterine size corresponds to or may be smaller than the period of gestation
  • On examination, dilated internal os through which the products of conception are visualized and felt but has not begun to expel out ( unlike incomplete abortion )
  • USG examination shows absent fetal cardiac activity.

Risk factors:

  • Preterm premature rupture of membranes 
  • Amniocentesis
  • Prior second-trimester delivery
  • Tobacco use
  • Fetal surgery.

Management:

  • IV Methergine is indicated if there is excessive bleeding when the cervix is dilated and uterine size is. <12 weeks.
  • Before 12 weeks:
    • Dilatation and evacuation followed by curettage
    • Alternatively, suction and evacuation.
  • After 12 weeks:
    • Oxytocin drip, 10 units in 500mL of NS at 40-60 drips per minute
    • The separated placenta is removed by ovum forceps and digital separation is indicated if the placenta is not separated.

A representation of various types of abortions is given below:

questions.text: What is the location of the Bartholin cyst?
questions.solution:
Bartholin cysts are located in the posterior 1/3 of the vulva.

The Bartholin glands are known as the greater vestibular glands in females. These glands are located in the posterior part of the vestibule and open through a duct into the vaginal orifice at approximately 5 and 7 o’clock positions. They secrete mucus during sexual arousal for lubrication. They are the homologs of the male bulbourethral or Cowper glands.

Bartholin cyst is caused by obstruction of the duct due to infection, trauma, mucus changes, and congenitally narrowed ducts. If the cyst gets infected, it leads to the formation of a Bartholin abscess. Escherichia coli is the most common causative agent, however, other gram-positive and gram-negative organisms can also cause the same.

Clinical features:

  • If the size is big, it might cause abdominal and vaginal discomfort with dyspareunia. 
  • A vulval cleft of 'S' shape is usually noted on inspection.
  • It is fluctuant swelling and transillumination can be positive as the fluid collected is generally clear.

Treatment:

  • Analgesics for pain
  • Antibiotic for combating infections.
  • Specific treatment:
    1. Drainage under anesthesia: Generally conservative method, chances of re-infection and formation of granulation tissue can happen.
    2. Marsupialization Complete excision of sac and cyst along with drainage of the substance. The edges are also clearly approximated. This is the ideal management.  The advantages of marsupialization over other methods include:
      • Simple procedure
      • Can be done even under local anesthesia.
      • Shorter hospital stay (24 hours).
      • The postoperative complication is almost nil.
      • Gland function (moisture) remains intact. 
    3. Incision and drainage with word catheter placement: A deflated word catheter is used to tuck the vagina here and prevent it from damage that can happen during movement of the perineum and thus avert re-infection and granulation tissue formation. Alternatively, a 14 F foley catheter can also be used.
    4. Bartholinectomy: This is a very invasive surgery and carries a greater morbidity profile. This is also associated with loss of lubricant function. 

Notes:

In any woman above the age of forty with recurrent Bartholin cyst, a suspicion of Bartholin gland cancer should arise and the cyst wall should be sent for biopsy.

questions.text: A 25-year-old female presented with pain in her right thigh and hips for three months. She was suspected to have hip tuberculosis. On examination, discrepancy in the length of her right limb was noticed. Which of the following stages of TB presents with apparent lengthening of the limb?
questions.solution:
Apparent lengthening of the limb is seen in the stage of synovitis. 

Tuberculosis of the hip occurs in three main stages based on the clinical manifestations: 

Stages Key findings Position of the affected limb Length of the affected limb
Stage 1
(Stage of synovitis)

There is effusion in the joint.

Patient usually does not present in this early stage

 Flexion, abduction, external rotation Apparent lengthening as the pelvis tilts downwards to compensate for the abduction

Stage 2
(Stage of arthritis)

Spasm of the powerful muscles around the hip.

 

 Flexion, adduction, internal rotation Apparent shortening as the pelvis tilts upwards to compensate for the adduction
Stage 3
(Stage of erosion)

Articular cartilage is destroyed

Acetabulum is eroded

Pathological dislocation/ subluxation of the hip  

 Flexion, adduction, internal rotation (exaggerated deformities) True shortening as there is actual destruction of the bone 

Some important radiological signs occurring in established cases of TB of the hip:

  • Haziness: earliest radiological sign
  • Lytic lesion
  • Reduction of joint space and irregular outline of articular ends: because of the destruction of cartilage
  • Wandering acetabulum: head may be lying out of the acetabulum
  • Pestle and mortar appearance: sometimes, the acetabulum gets enlarged and deepened with the deformed head shifted medially.
  • Sclerosis around the hip: seen if the disease is in the healing stage

questions.text: Which is the most common cancer in Indian women?
questions.solution:
The most common cancer in Indian women is breast cancer.

Breast cancer has a prevalence of 92.6 per 100,000 population while the prevalence of Ca cervix is 72 per 100000 population.

Most common cancers:

  India World
Male Lip, Oral cavity Lung
Female Breast Breast
Both sexes Breast Breast

questions.text: A 52-year-old diabetic patient suffered from drug-induced hypoglycemia.  Which of the following drugs is most likely responsible for her hypoglycemic episode?
questions.solution:
Among the following options, Glimepiride which is a sulphonylurea is known to cause hypoglycemia. 

Glimepiride is a sulfonylurea that also stimulates insulin secretion. They bind to a specific site on the β cell K-ATP channel complex and inhibit its activity. This causes cell membrane to depolarize and leads to a cascade of events resulting in insulin secretion.

Antidiabetic Drugs that pose a risk of leading to hypoglycemia (insulin secretagogue):

  • Sulfonylureas
  • Meglitinides: Nateglinide, Repaglinide

The following drugs are not directly responsible for stimulating insulin secretion and hence do not cause hypoglycemia:

  • Metformin
  • Alpha-glucosidase inhibitor
  • Pioglitazone
  • DPP-4 inhibitor: Sitagliptin

Note:

While alpha-glucosidase inhibitors themselves do not cause hypoglycemia, the risk of hypoglycemia is increased when they are taken along with insulin or insulin secretagogues.

questions.text: A 6-year-old child with a sore throat develops skin lesions, as shown in the image. Which of the following is the most likely type of psoriasis in this patient?
questions.solution:
The picture shows scattered drop-like papules and plaques suggestive of guttate psoriasis.

Guttate psoriasis is a distinct variant of psoriasis that is classically triggered by streptococcal infection (pharyngitis or perianal) and is more common in children and adolescents than adults. 

On examination, guttate psoriasis manifests as numerous, small scattered papules and plaques. These are often referred to as “drop-like” and typically manifest as round or slightly oval 2 to 10 mm papules. They are scattered more or less evenly over the body, particularly on the trunk and proximal part of the limbs as shown below. 

 

The image below shows a typical lesion of psoriasis characterised by erythematous plaque covered with silvery scales, particularly over the extensor surfaces.

Other options:

Option B: Erythrodermic psoriasis - an uncommon type where almost the entire body is affected, and the patient is systemically ill. 

Option C: Pustular psoriasis: - Appearance of macroscopic pustules within lesions.

Option D: Flexural/inverse psoriasis - Plaques affecting intertriginous folds, and scaling may be less prominent. It is shown in the image given below

questions.text: A 14-year-old male presented with recurrent epistaxis. There is no history of trauma. He also complained of nasal obstruction and rhinorrhea. On examination, there is a firm purplish mass on the posterior nasopharynx. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A young male with recurrent epistaxis and complaints of nasal obstruction with a mass on the nasopharynx suggests a diagnosis of Juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma.

Juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma (JNA) is a highly vascular and locally aggressive tumour seen almost exclusively in adolescent males, associated with significant morbidity and occasional mortality. JNA accounts for only 0.05% of all head and neck tumours. Patients usually present with a triad of progressive nasal obstruction, recurrent epistaxis and a mass in the nasal cavity and nasopharynx.\

It has the potential to cause proptosis, affecting both the orbit and intracranial extension, eventually leading to cranial nerve palsies and loss of vision.  Angiofibroma can be diagnosed using CT, MRI, and magnetic resonance angiography. Anterior bowing of the maxillary wall due to the presence of a mass in the pterygomaxillary space on CT known as the Holman-Miller sign is a characteristic finding of JNA. Recurrence has been reported up to 35%. Management: Surgical excision is the treatment of choice. Recurrent angiofibroma is treated with revision surgery, Radiotherapy is considered where the recurrence tumour is inaccessible.

Other options:

Option A: Nasopharyngeal carcinoma presents in elderly patients of East-Asian ethnicity and smoking history. They present with hearing loss and involvement of cranial nerves.

Option B: The foreign body in the nose presents at an earlier age and doesn't have recurrent epistaxis or a mass on examination. 

Option C: Antrochoanal polyp is a type of non-neoplastic nasal polypoidal masses of edematous nasal or sinus mucosa which arises from the mucosa of the maxillary antrum near its accessory ostium. The clinical features include unilateral nasal obstruction, mucoid nasal discharge, and a hyponasal voice.

questions.text: Positron emission tomography is based on which of the following mechanisms?
questions.solution:
Positron emission tomography (PET) utilizes the mechanism of glucose metabolism.

PET imaging is based on the detection of an injected positron-emitting radioactive tracer. It relies on the coincidence detection of the annihilation photons (γ), which are released when a positron combines with an electron.

A glucose analog called fluorodeoxyglucose (FDG) is used. FDG is taken up by metabolically active cells, where it undergoes phosphorylation to form FDG-6-phosphate. Unlike glucose, FDG-6-phosphate cannot undergo further metabolism and becomes trapped within the cell. The trapped FDG-6-phosphate is detected by the PET scanner.

Before injecting FDG, the blood glucose level should be measured. It should be < 150 mg/dL. Good blood glucose control is essential as FDG uptake is competitively inhibited by glucose.

questions.text: Intravenous induction agent of choice for day care anesthesia is____
questions.solution:
Intravenous induction agent of choice for day care anesthesia is propofol.

  • It has rapid onset of action and a faster recovery.
  • It also reduces postoperative nausea and vomiting which provide yet another reason for it to be a preferred drug for outpatient anesthesia.

Note -

  • Inhalational agent of choice for day care anesthesia is sevoflurane.
  • Muscle relaxant of choice for day care anesthesia is rocuronium.

questions.text: A 10-month-old boy who is a known case of cerebral palsy, was brought to the OPD for a routine check-up. The child had a past history of weakness in both upper and lower limbs which improved with time. On examination, residual weakness is present more in the lower limbs and trunk as compared to the upper limbs. What is this condition called?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a child with cerebral palsy, who has residual weakness in his lower limbs as compared to his upper limbs is highly suggestive of spastic diplegia.

Spastic diplegia is more commonly seen in premature infants with a history of birth asphyxia due to damage to immature white matter. It is 2nd most common type of cerebral palsy in India after spastic quadriplegia. Both the lower limbs are involved. During development, characteristic commando crawling is seen. Brain MRI shows scarring and shrinkage in the periventricular white matter with compensatory enlargement of the cerebral ventricles. IQ of these children is usually normal and has a good prognosis. 

Cerebral palsy (CP) is a diagnostic term used to describe a group of permanent disorders of movement and posture causing activity limitation that is attributed to nonprogressive disturbances in the developing fetal or infant brain. It is the most common cause of motor disability in childhood. 

The subtypes of cerebral palsy and the pathology involved are given below:

Cerebral palsy subtype Pathology
Spastic diplegia Periventricular leukomalacia
Spastic quadriplegia Multi-cystic encephalomalacia
Spastic hemiplegia Middle cerebral artery territory infarction
Dyskinetic cerebral palsy Basal ganglia

In older children, a scissoring gait is characterized by the knees and thighs pressed together or crossing each other while walking, caused by high muscle tone (spasticity) in the hip adductors.

Option B: Spastic hemiplegia affects one-half of the body (upper and lower limbs on the same side). It is seen due to vascular insult leading to perinatal stroke event. Early hand preference is seen (before 1 year), where one side of the body is always preferred as the other side is weak. MRI shows focal changes and porencephalic cysts due to infarcts. 

Option C: Spastic quadriplegia is associated with ischemia of the brain and infections. MRI would reveal severe periventricular leukomalacia and multicystic cortical encephalomalacia.

Option D: Dyskinetic/ Extrapyramidal CP is more commonly seen in term infants. It is likely to be associated with birth asphyxia and kernicterus in the early neonatal period. The upper limb is affected more than the lower limb. Brain MRI reveals lesions in the basal ganglia and thalamus.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man with a past history of tuberculosis presents to the OPD  with complaints of chronic cough, occasional hemoptysis, and persistent chest pain. Chest X-ray shows the following lesion. It has been observed that when the patient's position changes, the air within the lesion changes as well. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a patient with a past history of tuberculosis with an X-ray showing Monod's sign is suggestive of aspergilloma. The gas/air surrounding a mobile fungal ball or mycetoma (usually an aspergilloma) in an already-existing lung cavity is referred to as the Monod sign.

Aspergilloma or fungal ball is a late manifestation of chronic cavitary pulmonary aspergillosis (CPA) caused by Aspergillus species. A fungal ball is formed within the pulmonary cavity of CPA by the peeled-off inner layer of the cavity. 

Patients present with chronic features of fatigue, weight loss, cough, hemoptysis, and wheezing. However, clinical features such as foul-smelling sputum and night sweats are more commonly observed in Tuberculosis which helps in differentiating the two conditions.

Chest X-ray shows a spherical or ovoid mass within a cavity. The mass is mobile. CT demonstrates a rounded mass within a cavity.

Images below show chest x-ray and CT findings in aspergilloma.

Other options:

Option A: Lung abscess typically shows a thick-walled cavity with air-fluid level as shown below.

Option B & D: Hydatid cyst and bronchogenic carcinoma can also show cavitatory lesions with air crescent but a preformed cavity from the past history of tuberculosis suggests the diagnosis of aspergilloma.

questions.text: A patient diagnosed with chronic heart failure presents with a particular breathing pattern. His depth and rate of respiration are plotted below. What type of breathing abnormality is seen here?
questions.solution:
The type of breathing abnormality shown in the image is suggestive of Cheyne-Stokes breathing. 

Cheyne-Stokes breathing is characterized by periods of waxing and waning hyperventilation separated by periods of apnea, as seen in the image. This pattern is seen at high altitudes and in patients with severe heart disease or brain injury.

 
In Cheyne-Stokes respiration, the person ventilates excessively, leading to an excessive loss of CO2 and an increased concentration of O2 in the blood. These changes in the blood are detected only after a few seconds after the pulmonary blood reaches the brain. Thus ventilation does not get inhibited immediately.
 
When the overventilated blood finally reaches the respiratory center in the brain, the center gets excessively depressed, and ventilation is inhibited. This leads to increased CO2 and decreased O2 in the alveoli. It takes the center a few more seconds to respond to these reversed changes, leading to excessive ventilation. The cycle then repeats.
 
 
In severe chronic cardiac failure, blood flow from the lungs to the brain is slow. This leads to alveolar changes in the CO2 and O2 occurring for longer than usual and excessive storage of these gases within the alveoli and pulmonary blood. After a few seconds, the periodic respiratory drive becomes extreme and Cheyne-Stokes breathing begins. 
 
Other options:
Option A: Kussmaul's breathing is a form of hyperventilation. It occurs due to an increased tidal volume with or without an increase in respiratory rate. It is seen in association with any condition that leads to acidosis.
 
Option B: Biot's breathing is characterized by regular deep respirations with periods of apnea. It occurs due to pontine damage by stroke, trauma, or uncal herniation. 
 
Option D: Hyperpnea refers to an increased volume of respiration with or without an increased rate of breathing. Blood gas concentrations are normal.
 
The different patterns of respiration are shown below.

questions.text: A 61-year-old university professor presents with a loss of vision in his left eye. He describes the sensation as a curtain being drawn over his affected eye. The patient had a history of flashing lights and floaters 7 days back. He also gives a history of having cataract surgery in the same eye 3 weeks ago. What is the likely cause of this condition?
questions.solution:
The patient with sudden painless loss of vision has been complaining of floaters and curtain falling sign with a recent history of cataract surgery suggests the diagnosis of retinal detachment.

Retinal detachment occurs due to the accumulation of fluid between the neurosensory retina(NSR) and retinal pigment epithelium (RPE) due to a retinal tear.

Types of Retinal detachment:

A. Rhegmatogenous retinal detachment- fluid accumulates after a break (tear) occurs in the retina.

Causes include High myopes, Retinoschisis-splitting of neurosensory retina plus vitreous degeneration (typical retinoschisis-split at the level of the outer plexiform layer, atypical retinoschisis-split at the level of the nerve fibre layer), trauma, pseudophakia, and aphakia.

The most dangerous type of retinal break is horseshoe tear and the most dangerous location of the retinal break is the superior-temporal retina. 

Clinical features include photopsia, floaters, and visual field defects (a black curtain/veil in front of the eye).

Signs

  • Hypotony- as the liquefied vitreous in the subretinal space is absorbed through the RPE.
  • Shafer sign-pigments in the anterior vitreous (tobacco dusting) are a feature of fresh retinal detachment.
  • The detached retina is convex in configuration. The surface is corrugated with undulations.

Treatment

  • Prophylactic laser barrage
  • Scleral buckling
  • Pneumatic retinopexy
  • Pars plana vitrectomy 

B. Tractional retinal detachment: Fibro-vascular membranes in the vitreous due to long-standing retinal neovascularization exert traction on the retina. 

Causes include proliferative diabetic retinopathy, central retinal venous occlusion, Eale's disease, retinopathy of Prematurity(ROP)

The detached retina is concave in configuration. No breaks are seen

Treatment

  • Pars plana vitrectomy with endo photocoagulation. 

C. Exudative retinal detachment: Exudative fluid from the choroid, collects in the subretinal space leading to retinal detachment.

Causes include inflammatory conditions like choroiditis, posterior scleritis choroidal tumours like melanoma, toxaemia of pregnancy, malignant hypertension, Coat's disease

Floaters due to vitreous but no photopsia and visual field defect is seen

The detached retina is convex in configuration. The surface is smooth. No break is seen. Shifting fluid is seen.

Treatment

  • Systemic steroids
  • Treatment of the cause

 The image below shows a fundus which reveals retinal detachment inferiorly from 3-9 o'clock with a tear at 3:30

Related Pearl: Causes of loss of vision

Features Cause
Sudden painless loss of vision
  • Central retinal artery occlusion
  • Massive vitreous hemorrhage
  • Retinal detachment involving macula
  • Ischemic central retinal vein occlusion
Sudden painless onset of diminution of vision
  • Central serous retinopathy
  • Optic neuritis
  • Methyl alcohol amblyopia
  • Non-ischemic central retinal vein occlusion
Sudden painful loss of vision
  • Acute congestive glaucoma
  • Acute iridocyclitis
  • Injury to eyeball

  • Corneal dystrophy
  • Senile cataract
  • Primary open angle glaucoma
  • Optic atrophy
  • ARMD
  • Refractive error
  • Diabetic retinopathy

  • Chronic iridocyclitis
  • Corneal ulceration

questions.text: In which of the following situations is ventouse delivery contraindicated?
questions.solution:
Ventouse delivery is contraindicated in preterm babies as it increases the risk of scalp avulsion or sub-aponeurotic haemorrhage.

Contraindications of vacuum delivery:

  • Any presentation other than vertex (such as face/breech)
  • Preterm fetus (less than 34 weeks)
  • Suspected fetal coagulation disorder
  • Fetal macrosomia (more than 4 kg estimated weight)

A vacuum extractor is an instrument used in operative vaginal delivery by creating a vacuum between it and the fetal scalp. 

The instrument consists of 

  • Suction cup
  • Vacuum generator
  • Traction tubing device.

The suction cup is placed on the fetal head at a point near the occiput called the flexion point, which is an imaginary point on the sagittal suture, located about 6 cm from the centre of the anterior fontanel or about 3 cm in front of the posterior fontanel. The flexion point is closer to the posterior fontanel as shown in the image below.

Related Pearl: Vacuum delivery- indications and contraindications

Indications of ventouse:    

Therapeutic-

  • Fetal distress in second stage
  • Maternal distress in second stage
  • Prolonged second stage
  • Deep transverse arrest and persistent occipitoposterior
  • High vacuum for second twin

Prophylactic-

  • Preeclampsia
  • VBAC
  • Cardiac defects
  • Anemia

Contraindications of ventouse:     

  • Preterm head
  • Face presentation         
  • Fetal coagulopathy
  • Fetal blood sampling

questions.text: A 50-year-old female presents with an acute painful red-eye. An image of her eye is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario and a red eye showing corneal edema and a mid-dilated and vertically oval pupil are suggestive of acute angle-closure glaucoma. The pupil is non-reactive to both light and accommodation.

Acute primary angle-closure glaucoma refers to the occlusion of the trabecular meshwork by the peripheral iris (iridotrabecular contact [ITC]), obstructing aqueous outflow. It can be primary when it occurs in an anatomically predisposed eye or secondary to another ocular or systemic factor.

Acute angle-closure glaucoma is an ocular emergency that causes acute red-eye and is associated with at least two of the following symptoms:

  • Acute onset ocular pain with nausea or vomiting
  • Intermittent blurring of vision with halos
  • Photophobia or
  • Loss of vision.

It is also associated with at least three of the following signs:

  • Ciliary congestion
  • Corneal edema and subsequent haziness
  • Fixed and mid-dilated, usually oval pupil
  • Shallow anterior chamber
  • Intraocular pressure elevated above 40 mmHg.

Immediate medical management mainly aims at lowering IOP using drugs such as oral acetazolamide or intravenous mannitol. The definitive treatment is laser peripheral iridotomy. This must be followed by prophylaxis of the fellow eye, long-term glaucoma surveillance and management of intraocular pressure in both eyes.

questions.text: An unconscious young man was rushed to the emergency department. On examination, his pulse rate was 190/min and his blood pressure was 70/40 mmHg. His electrocardiogram is given below. What is the next step in management?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the electrocardiogram (ECG) showing narrow QRS complexes without P waves and pseudo R waves in aVR lead suggest paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia (PSVT). As the patient is hemodynamically unstable, the next step in management is DC (direct current) cardioversion.

PSVT is a narrow QRS complex tachycardia with sudden onset and termination. They mainly present with dizziness and palpitations. Evaluation of these patients includes monitoring of vitals and ECG.

Management is as follows:

1) When the patient is hemodynamically stable:

  • Carotid sinus massage can be done. It is avoided if carotid bruit is present and if a prior history of stroke is seen
  • Valsalva maneuver is done if the patient is cooperative
  • Intravenous adenosine is useful in most cases. However, its usage is contraindicated in patients with prior cardiac transplantation. It can aggravate bronchospasm and atrial fibrillation, hence must be used with great caution in such patients.
  • Intravenous calcium channel blockers such as verapamil or diltiazem and beta-blockers are helpful but can cause hypotension.

2) When the patient is hemodynamically unstable, i.e. when the patient has hypotension with unconsciousness or respiratory distress QRS-synchronous direct current cardioversion is done.

questions.text: A 17-year-old male patient presents with dull aching pain over the back of his ankle. There is tenderness on firm palpation of the swelling. The following findings are seen on X-ray. What is the likely diagnosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
According to the clinical scenario and given X-ray, Exostosis of the bone is the most likely diagnosis.

Exostoses can cause chronic pain ranging from mild to debilitatingly severe, depending on the shape, size, and location of the lesion. It is most commonly found in places like the ribs, where small bone growths form, but sometimes larger growths can grow on places like the ankles, knees, shoulders, elbows and hips. Very rarely are they on the skull. Exostoses can be seen in different types: calcaneal spurs, osteomyelitis, Charcot foot, osteochondroma, and hereditary multiple exostoses.

In osteochondroma, the tumour stops enlarging in size once there is a cessation of growth at the epiphyseal plate. It appears as a small bony protrusion at metaphysis on X-ray. They are benign and rarely transform into chondrosarcomas. They are commonly seen around the knee joint (distal femur) or foot. 

Option A: Chondrosarcoma are the second most common primary malignant tumors that occurs in any site of the bone. It presents in 3rd to 7th decade of life and is slow growing, with deep pain and/or shows an enlarging mass. Most commonly involves proximal femur, pelvis and proximal humerus.

X-ray features: Large, intraosseous and osteolytic tumors. Irregular and granular calcifications present which shows a characteristic “honeycomb” or “popcorn”appearance.

Option B: Osteoclastoma has a soap bubble appearance on X-ray and typically affects individuals 20-40 years of age. Axial skeleton involvement is not common

Option D: X-ray features of osteosarcoma: Ill-defined, bone forming lesion showing characteristic Codman’s triangle due to periosteal reaction . Sunburst appearance when the periosteum does not have enough time to lay down a new layer.

questions.text: A 62-year-old male patient presents with right-sided weakness for the last 2 hours. NCCT head does not show any intracranial bleeding. His BP is 200/120 mmHg. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step?
questions.solution:
In a patient with ischemic stroke and who is otherwise a candidate for IV thrombolysis, the BP should be maintained <185/110 mmHg. If higher than this, then antihypertensive agents such as IV nicardipine are used to reduce the BP.

As soon as the diagnosis of stroke is made clinically, a non-contrast CT (NCCT) of the head is done to differentiate between hemorrhagic and ischemic stroke, because the management of the two is entirely different. Once an ischemic stroke is confirmed, the goal is to limit the size of the infarct by optimizing perfusion to the penumbra. Since the blood flow in the ischemic areas of the brain is dependent on high blood pressure, the target blood pressure is higher than normal in ischemic stroke. Antihypertensives should only be administered if:

  • BP is >220/120 mmHg
  • BP is >185/110 mmHg and the patient is planned for thrombolytic therapy

The antihypertensives preferred for this purpose are IV labetalol, nicardipine, and clevidipine. They allow rapid titration to the target blood pressure. After the BP is optimized, a thrombolytic agent is administered intravenously unless there are contraindications.

After this, CT angiography is done to find out if the occlusion is in the larger arteries of the brain, such as the internal carotid artery, middle cerebral artery, and basilar artery. Such occlusions involve large clots and fail to open with IV thrombolysis alone. For these patients, mechanical thrombectomy is done. Mechanical thrombectomy is also indicated in patients presenting after 6 hours but within 24 hours, with the CT showing good perfusion of the penumbra.

questions.text: A 57-year-old female patient complains of sudden onset shortness of breath and pain on inspiration on post-op day 5 following total knee replacement. Her BP is 124/70 mmHg and echocardiography is normal. Her chest radiograph is shown below. Which of the following treatment strategies is most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: Low molecular weight heparin plus alteplase

questions.solution:
The given history and the chest radiograph showing Hampton's hump point to a diagnosis of pulmonary embolism (PE). Since this patient is normotensive and there are no findings on echocardiography, it is a case of low-risk PE. The most appropriate management in this patient would be anticoagulation with low molecular weight heparin.

Depending on the clinical presentation, patients with PE can be stratified as:

  • High-risk (massive) PE is characterized by systemic hypotension. Patients can have dyspnea and syncope and may present in cardiogenic shock. 
  • Intermediate-risk (submassive) PE is characterized by right ventricle (RV) dysfunction but normal blood pressure. RV dysfunction can be diagnosed with echocardiography and ECG.
  • Low-risk PE is characterized by normal blood pressure and the absence of any RV dysfunction. 

The treatment strategy for a patient with pulmonary embolism will vary according to the risk stratification. A patient with high-risk PE will primarily be treated with anticoagulation and thrombolysis or catheter/surgical embolectomy. A patient with low-risk PE will be treated with anticoagulation alone, or an IVC filter as secondary prophylaxis. Patients with intermediate-risk PE require individualized treatment. 

Anticoagulation can be done with the classical strategy of low-molecular-weight heparin followed by warfarin, or by low-molecular-weight heparin for 5 days, switched to novel oral anticoagulant like Dabigatran after that. Fibrinolysis, if indicated, is done with recombinant TPA administered over 2 hours. It can be done up to 14 days after the PE has occurred.

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy presents with complaints of nocturnal pruritus. Examination shows burrows over intertriginous areas, axilla, umbilicus, and in between the digits. Which of the following vectors is responsible for transmitting this disease?
questions.solution:
The given clinical history of nocturnal pruritis and borrows over intertriginous areas, axilla, umbilicus, and in between digits is suggestive of scabies. It is caused by the itch mite also called Sarcoptes scabiei.

Scabies is caused by an infestation of Sarcoptes scabiei. It is transmitted by direct skin-to-skin contact and less frequently via contaminated clothes and bedding. They are seen more commonly in overcrowded areas, hostels, and schools, especially in unhygienic environments. 

Clinically, these patients present with superficial excoriated papules or vesicles that are intensely pruritic. They are usually present on the volar surface of the wrists, interdigital spaces, penis, scrotum, navel, and skin folds and creases in the axillae, buttocks, and thigh regions. Burrows may be visualized in the superficial dermis in the above mentioned regions. Pruritis is typically intense and increases after showers and during the night. 

Diagnosis is established considering the characteristic history and by dermatoscopic imaging or microscopy of the skin scrapings or cellophane tape lifted from lesions. 

Permethrin cream - 5% is the treatment of choice. It is preferred over 1% lindane preparation and ivermectin. These preparations are applied once, all over the body below the jawline, following a bath. It should be washed off with soap and water after 8-14 hours. 

It is imperative to treat close contacts simultaneously and wash bedding and clothing to prevent reinfestations.

The image given below shows itch mite.

Other options:

Option A: Crab louse infestation causes pediculosis pubis.

Option C: Rat fleas are vectors for endemic typhus, bubonic plague, and hymenolepis diminuta.

Option D: Ixodes ticks (hard ticks) transmit rocky mountain spotted fever, Russian spring-summer encephalitis, Colorado tick fever, tularemia, tick paralysis, and human babesiosis.

Morphology of Lesion Papules, pustules, excoriation, eczematization, burrow Vesicles, pustules, bullae, erosions, and ulcerations

questions.text: Identify the instrument.
questions.solution:
The image shown is of a wire speculum. 

Eye speculums are used to keep the lids apart during intraocular operations (e.g. cataract surgery, glaucoma surgery and keratoplasty), extraocular surgery (e.g. squint surgery, pterygium surgery), enucleation and evisceration operation, removal of conjunctival and corneal foreign bodies, cauterization of corneal ulcer, examination of the eye in a patient with blepharospasm. 

Other options:

Option A: Evisceration spatula consists of a small but stout rectangular blade with a slightly convex surface and blunt edges attached to a handle. It is used to separate the uveal tissue from the sclera during evisceration operation.

Option C: Chalazion clamp consists of two limbs like forceps, which can be clamped with the help of a screw. The tip of one limb is flattened in the
form of a round disc while the tip of the other arm has a small circular ring. It is used to fix the chalazion and achieve hemostasis during the incision and curettage operation.

Option D: Bone punch consists of a stout spring handle and two blades attached at a right angle. It is used to enlarge the bony opening during
dacryocystorhinostomy (DCR) operation by punching the bone from the margins of the opening.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman comes with complaints of fatigue which worsens towards the end of the day. She also complains of double vision while watching television. The physician suspects a case of myasthenia gravis. Which of the following tests has the highest sensitivity in diagnosing this condition?

choices.text: Acetylcholine receptor and muscle-specific receptor tyrosine kinase antibodies

questions.solution:
Single-fiber electromyography has the highest sensitivity in the clinical diagnosis of myasthenia gravis.

Single-fiber electromyography (SFEMG) simultaneously records action potentials of two muscle fibers innervated by the same motor axon. The variability in time of the second action potential relative to the first is called "jitter" and this is increased in myasthenia gravis. It is the most sensitive test used for the diagnosis of myasthenia gravis.

Myasthenia gravis is a neuromuscular junction (NMJ) disorder associated with a decrease in postsynaptic depolarization due to the blocking of acetylcholine receptors by autoantibodies. It is characterized by weakness and fatigability of skeletal muscles. Ocular features like ptosis and diplopia can also be seen. When it becomes generalized, the proximal muscles of the limbs are affected first. Despite the muscle weakness, the deep tendon reflexes remain normal. The snarling expression on smiling (facial weakness), nasal timbre of speech (weakness of palate and tongue), and difficulty swallowing may be seen. Bulbar weakness and respiratory depression are seen more frequently in MuSK antibody–positive myasthenia gravis. Treatment includes anticholinesterase drugs like pyridostigmine and immunosuppression.

Other options:

Option B: Testing for autoantibodies against the acetylcholine receptor (AChR-Ab) should be performed on all patients (most specific). If the AChR-Abs test is negative, an assay for antibodies against muscle-specific receptor tyrosine kinase (MuSK) should be performed.

Option C: Repetitive nerve stimulation (RNS) is considered abnormal if there is a decremental response of >10%. 

Option D: CT scan of the chest is likely to show thymic hyperplasia and thymoma which are frequently associated in patients with myasthenia gravis.

questions.text: Which of the following is given to prevent neural tube defects in pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Folic acid (Vitamin B9) is given to prevent the incidence of neural tube defects.

Folic acid deficiency is implicated in neural tube defects like spina bifida, encephalocele, and anencephaly.

  • Supplementation of folic acid, in doses of 400 μg/day, prior to conception has been shown to cause a significant reduction in the incidence of spina bifida and other neural tube defects.
  • Reduced activity of the enzyme 5,10-methylene-THF reductase (MTHFR) caused by a common C677T polymorphism in the MTHFR gene is one of the causes of Neural tube defects in Folate deficiency.

As per the Anemia Mukt Bharat Program, during the period of pre-conception up to the first trimester, women are advised to have 400 mcg of folic acid tablets daily to reduce the incidence of neural tube defects in the fetus.

Note that, non-pregnant, non-lactating women of reproductive age (20–49 years) who are not actively planning a pregnancy in the near term should receive 1 iron and folic acid tablet containing 60 mg elemental iron + 500 mcg folic acid.

questions.text: Which of the following is responsible for balance and equilibrium?
questions.solution:
The semicircular canals that are a part of the bony labyrinth are responsible for balance and equilibrium.

The semicircular canals are three loop-shaped structures filled with endolymph fluid and lined with hair cells that detect angular acceleration in three planes (horizontal, vertical, and oblique).

When the head moves, the fluid inside these canals shifts, causing the hair cells to bend. This bending generates nerve impulses that are transmitted to the brain via the vestibular nerve, informing the brain about the direction and speed of head movement. This mechanism is essential for maintaining posture, coordinating eye movements, and ensuring balance.

Other options:

Option A: The vestibule, which includes the utricle and saccule, also contributes to balance by detecting linear acceleration and the position of the head relative to gravity. However, the semicircular canals are primarily responsible for detecting rotational movements, making them key to the sensation of balance and equilibrium.

Option C: The organ of Corti is the sense organ of hearing and is situated on the basilar membrane of the cochlear duct. It detects sound vibrations and converts them into electrical signals for the auditory nerve. It is involved in hearing, not balance or equilibrium.

Option D: The cochlea is a spiral-shaped organ responsible for converting sound waves into electrical signals. It contains hair cells that detect sound vibrations and transmit them as nerve impulses to the auditory nerve, allowing us to perceive sound.

questions.text:
A young man presented with severe muscle weakness and ptosis. Chest X-ray revealed an anterior mediastinal mass. Further investigation reveals the presence of AchR antibodies. Which of the following is the likely diagnosis?

AchR -Acetylcholine receptor
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of weakness, ptosis, anterior mediastinal mass( thymoma), and the presence of AchR antibodies are suggestive of myasthenia gravis.

Myasthenia gravis is a neuromuscular junction (NMJ) disorder due to autoimmune damage to the postsynaptic acetylcholine receptors at the NMJ. It is characterized by weakness and muscle fatigue. Weakness increases with usage and muscle movement is difficult at the end of the day. It affects proximal muscles leading to weakness of the limbs. Ocular features like ptosis and diplopia can also be seen. Myasthenia gravis is often related to thymomas. Symptoms of myasthenia gravis improve after excision of the thymus gland even in the absence of a thymoma.  Treatment includes Anticholinesterase drugs like Pyridostigmine, immunosuppression, and even Thymectomy if the condition is associated with a Thymoma. Recently Rozanolixizumab has been approved for treating cases of generalized Myasthenia gravis.

Other options:

Option B: Lambert-Eaton myasthenic syndrome (LEMS) is an autoimmune disorder affecting the presynaptic membrane at the NMJ. Patients present with proximal muscle weakness of the lower limbs, ptosis, and diplopia.  Treatment involves plasmapheresis, immunotherapy, and drugs such as 3,4-diaminopyridine (3,4-DAP) and pyridostigmine.

Option C: Duchenne muscular dystrophy (DMD) is an X-linked muscular dystrophy due to mutations in the dystrophin gene. It most commonly affects boys in their childhood. Patients initially present with proximal muscle weakness predominantly in the lower limbs. Calf muscle hypertrophy is a cardinal feature. Other features include mental retardation, cardiac failure, and myoglobinuria. Treatment includes corticosteroids, Eteplirsen, and Casimersen. 

Option D: Myotonic dystrophy is an autosomal dominant disorder affecting multiple systems. It is associated with skeletal muscle weakness, cataracts, endocrinopathy, and cardiomyopathy. The treatment is mainly symptomatic however, mexiletine is indicated for reducing myotonia.

questions.text: A 5-year-old child was brought to OPD with a history of URTI. He also has features of mouth breathing, sleep apnoea and nasal obstruction. The mother has noticed that the child increases the volume while watching TV. What is the appropriate management?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a child with mouth breathing, sleep apnoea, nasal obstruction, and decreased hearing points towards the diagnosis of serous otitis media secondary to adenoid hypertrophy. Adenoidectomy with grommet insertion would be the most appropriate management.

Adenoid hypertrophy causes typical facies characterized by an elongated face with a dull expression, an open mouth, a hitched-up upper lip, prominent upper teeth causing crowding (malocclusion of teeth), a high arched hard palate (due to loss of tongue's molding action on the palate), and a pinched-in nose due to disuse atrophy of the alae nasi.

Enlarged adenoids in children can present as nasal obstruction, recurrent acute otitis media, and serous otitis media. Chronic nasal obstruction resulting in mouth breathing leads to this characteristic facial appearance in children. Patients can also present with a speech disorder, most probably, rhinolalia clausa (hypo-nasality) due to adenoid hypertrophy.

Serous otitis media also known as secretory otitis media, mucoid otitis media, or glue ear is characterized by the accumulation of nonpurulent, serous effusion in the middle ear cleft. Glue ear can occur either due to eustachian tube dysfunction (adenoid hyperplasia, chronic sinusitis or tonsillitis or rhinitis, cleft palate, tumours of nasopharynx) or due to increased secretory activity of the middle ear mucosa (allergy, unresolved otitis media, viral infections). Glue ear is commonly seen in children aged 5-8 years and is associated with insidious onset of hearing loss (not exceeding 40 dB), mild ear aches, and a history of upper respiratory tract infections. Delayed or defective speech may also result from hearing loss.

Otoscopy shows: 

  • Dull and opaque tympanic membrane with loss of light reflex
  • Thin leash of vessels along the handle of the malleus 
  • Fluid levels and air bubbles can be seen when the tympanic membrane is transparent. 

The otoscopy image of serous otitis media is shown below:

Enlarged adenoids in children can present as nasal obstruction, rhinolalia clausa, recurrent acute otitis media, and serous otitis media. Adenoid facies, characterized by an elongated face, open mouth, teeth crowding, high arched hard palate, and pinched-in nose, may also be present.

The tuning fork test reveals a conductive type of hearing loss and audiometry reveals hearing loss in the range of 20–40 dB. The fluid accumulation in glue ear causes decreased mobility (compliance) of the tympanic membrane leading to a flat or dome-shaped curve or type B curve on a tympanogram.

Treatment is mainly aimed at the removal of fluid and preventing recurrence. 

  • Medical management includes decongestants, antihistamines, and antibiotics.
  • Surgical management is done if the condition cannot be controlled with medications. It includes myringotomy and aspiration of fluid with grommet insertion. Adenoidectomy and tonsillectomy may be required and are usually done at the time of myringotomy.

Other options:

Option A: Grommet insertion alone will help resolve otitis media but the primary pathology of adenoid hypertrophy will not be addressed. 

Option C: Myringotomy with grommet insertion- Myringotomy will relieve the glue ear but will not address adenoids and lead to the recurrence of symptoms.

Option D: Myringotomy involves creating a small incision in the eardrum that will relieve the otitis media but symptoms will recur due to persistent adenoid hypertrophy.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common site for nasopharyngeal carcinoma?
questions.solution:
The most common site for nasopharyngeal carcinoma is the fossa of Rossenmuller which is marked 3 in the image.

Nasopharyngeal carcinoma is a malignant tumor of the nasopharynx. The theories for etiology include genetics, infection with Epstein-Barr virus, air pollution, and smoking.

The three types of nasopharyngeal carcinoma include - keratinizing carcinoma, nonkeratinizing differentiated carcinoma, and nonkeratinizing undifferentiated carcinoma. 

The most common site of origin of nasopharyngeal carcinoma is the fossa of Rosenmuller. From here, it can spread extensively in any direction locally. It also can spread lymphatically to the cervical, retropharyngeal, or parapharyngeal lymph nodes.

Trotter's triad consists of ipsilateral conductive hearing loss (eustachian tube blockage), trigeminal neuralgia of the mandibular division, and palatal asymmetry due to invasion of levator palatini muscles may be seen. This triad occurs in malignant tumors of the lateral nasopharyngeal wall due to extensive invasion. 

Diagnosis is made by high-resolution, contrast-enhanced CT of the neck. The treatment of choice is radiotherapy. Stage I and II can be treated with radiotherapy alone, while higher stages require combination treatment with radiotherapy and chemotherapy.

Given below is the labelled diagram showing the fossa of Rossenmuller, eustachian tube, and torus tubaris.

questions.text: A chronic alcoholic patient consuming alcohol for the last 20 years had his last drink 3 days back. He presents with altered sensorium, disorientation, tremors, and a feeling of insects crawling over his body. Which of the following should be given to this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of alcohol withdrawal with altered sensorium, and a feeling of insects crawling over his body points towards the diagnosis of delirium tremens. Lorazepam + thiamine should be given to this patient.

Delirium tremens is treated using benzodiazepines like lorazepam starting with a higher dosage which is gradually tapered as withdrawal symptoms disappear. In cases of chronic alcohol use, vitamin deficiency (especially thiamine) may be co-existing and hence bolus doses of thiamine are given to prevent/treat Wernicke encephalopathy.

Delirium tremens occurs after 2-4 days of abstinence in a heavy or chronic drinker. It is characterized by autonomic hyperactivity, tremors, delusions, and hallucinations. It usually resolves spontaneously in 7 days but may cause the death of the patient due to cardiovascular collapse, infections or self-injury.

Haloperidol is generally not the first-line drug in case of alcoholic withdrawal. It might be used as an add-on in agitated patients. It decreases the seizure threshold and its use would be appropriate in a case of co-existing psychotic disorder like schizophrenia.

questions.text: A 7-year-old child presented with complaints of headache and blurring of vision. On examination, there was a difference in visual acuity. In the right eye, it was  (+5D) and in the left, it was (+1D). After the best possible correction for vision, visual acuity in the right eye is 6/18 and in the left is  6/24. On fundoscopy, no pathology could be appreciated. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most probable diagnosis from the given scenario is Anisometric Amblyopia.

A young child with a difference of vision in both eyes that is not improved after correction for refractive error supports the diagnosis. Due to the difference in refractive power, vision in one eye gets suppressed which is not apparent on examination.

Amblyopia is an uncorrectable decrease in vision in one or both eyes with no apparent structural abnormality seen to explain it. It is a diagnosis of exclusion. Generally, a difference of two lines or more on Snellen's visual acuity chart between the two eyes would be defined as unilateral amblyopia. 

It may be of the following types:

  • Strabismic - monocular suppression of the deviating eye in case of abnormal binocular interaction may develop in children with an accommodative squint. It is the most common type. 
  • Refractory- Anisometropic, Isoametropic, Meridional - due to a difference in refractive error between the two eyes
  • Stimulus deprivation - in the case of vision deprivation
  • Organic
  • Reverse
  • Idiopathic

Clinical features:

  • Decreased contrast sensitivity
  • Diminution of vision
  • Sunglass effect- brightness is less compared to the normal eye
  • Crowding phenomenon- slipping of images

Treatment of choice:

  • Occlusion of the normal eye (4 to 6 hours/day) using patches.
  • Penalization: Blurring of vision using atropine.

Other options: 

Option A: Refractive error will be corrected after using visual corrections.

Option B: Astigmatism is a type of refractive error due to rotational asymmetry in the eye's refractive power. There is a difference in refractive power in the visual axis of the same eye. 

Option C: It cannot be a case of malingering as the differences in vision and refractory error have been documented.

questions.text: Early cord clamping is done in which of the following cases?
questions.solution:
Early cord clamping will be done in the case of a Rh-negative mother.

Early cord clamping is generally carried out in the first 60 seconds after birth. 

Rh isoimmunization occurs when an Rh-negative mother’s immune system produces antibodies against Rh-positive fetal blood cells, typically during a previous pregnancy or due to a blood transfusion. This can lead to hemolytic disease in subsequent pregnancies, where the mother's antibodies attack the fetus’s red blood cells. Early cord clamping in cases of Rh isoimmunization helps minimize fetal blood loss into the maternal circulation, reducing the risk of worsening anemia in the newborn and limiting potential bleeding complications. 

Early cord clamping is indicated in

  • Birth asphyxia
  • Rh isoimmunisation
  • Diabetic mother
  • The benefits of delayed cord clamping for up to 60 seconds is an increase in total body iron stores, expand blood volume and a decrease in anemia incidence in the neonate.

On the other hand, delayed cord clamping (for a minimum of 1-3 minutes) can lead to a higher hemoglobin concentration, which increases the risk of hyperbilirubinemia and extended hospitalisation for neonatal phototherapy. Delayed cord clamping can also hinder timely neonatal resuscitation.

According to AIIMS Protocols in Neonatology, in uncomplicated preterm birth, delayed cord clamping should be attempted. This is done for a minimum time of 60 seconds after delivery for preterm infants not requiring immediate resuscitation after birth. It states that DCC must be done even if the mother has an HIV infection. But as per the NACO guidelines, early cord clamping is advised.

questions.text: Which of the following anaesthetic agents is most suitable for cataract surgery?
questions.solution:
2% Lignocaine (Lidocaine) is the infiltrative anaesthetic suitable for this patient due to its moderate duration of action, which lasts for 30–60 minutes.

Lidocaine is a local anaesthetic that can be used for peripheral nerve blockade, and topical, infiltrative, spinal, and epidural anaesthesia. The duration of infiltration anaesthesia can be prolonged by the addition of epinephrine to lidocaine (up to 120 minutes). It is also used for intravenous regional anaesthesia (IVRA) in short surgical procedures (<90 minutes) on the limbs. 

It is metabolized by CYP enzymes in the liver. Large amounts of lidocaine can exacerbate symptoms of myasthenia gravis and cardiac toxicity, as well as transient neurological symptoms.

Bupivacaine, ropivacaine, and tetracaine are all long-acting drugs. (option B,C & D)

questions.text: A 15-year-old girl presented with the following findings on her face. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The age of the patient and the presence of papules and pustules with an erythematous base on the face are suggestive of acne vulgaris.

Acne vulgaris is a chronic inflammatory disease of the pilosebaceous unit. It is commonly seen in teenagers and young adults.

Comedonal lesions are the earliest lesions of acne. They represent the keratin plugs of the pilosebaceous duct and are non-inflammatory.

When the keratin plug is inside the follicle, it is called a closed comedone/whitehead.
When the keratin plug in the pilosebaceous unit is exposed to the environment, it gets oxidized by the air and turns black, known as open comedones/blackheads.
Inflammatory changes lead to the formation of papules, which may become pustules that rupture superficially or else spread deeper and form cystic lesions. 

Management is directed at minimizing inflammation, decreasing keratin production, antibiotics, and antiandrogens to diminish sebum production.

The FDA has recently approved the drug Clascoterone, an androgen receptor inhibitor for the topical treatment of acne vulgaris in patients aged 12 years and older.

Other options:

Option A: Acne rosacea or Rosacea is predominantly a disease with onset in middle‐aged adults (30–50 years old) and involves the convexities of the face.

Option C: Eczema presents more over the flexures and extremities from early adulthood. Features of pruritus and excoriations are predominant.

Option D: Tinea faciei is a fungal infection of the face and presents with a scaly lesion.

Related Pearl: Global Alliance Algorithm for Acne Treatment

Global Alliance Algorithm for Acne Treatment
