BPO - Benzoyl peroxide

questions.text: A 38-year-old lady, who was recently started on OCPs is referred to the dermatology OPD with hyperpigmented macules on the upper lip, malar region, and forehead as shown below. It is exacerbated by sun exposure. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a woman on OCPs, who has hyperpigmented macules on her face, exacerbated by sun exposure is suggestive of melasma.

Melasma is the most common cause of facial melanosis that manifests as hyperpigmented macules on the face. It is exacerbated by sun exposure and oral contraceptive pills. The condition is predominantly seen in females. Melasma presents as hypermelanosis of the upper lip, malar regions, forehead, and chin. There may also be darkening of the nipples, linea alba, and groin. The lesions are usually bilateral and symmetrical. 

In a pregnant woman, melasma is called chloasma (also known as mask of pregnancy). Chloasma is very common in the 3rd trimester of pregnancy. The pigmentation usually fades after parturition, but the course is variable.

Treatment for melasma: 

  • First-line - Sun protection, changing oral contraceptives to low estrogen formulation, or triple therapy with topical hydroquinone, tretinoin, and corticosteroid cream.
  • Second-line - Chemical peels, azelaic acid alone or in combination with tretinoin.
  • Third line - Laser therapy, pulsed light therapy, dermabrasion, topical liquiritin, topical rucinol, kojic acid, and hydroquinone.

Related Pearl: Key Chart to help differentiate lesions on face

Key Chart to help Differentiate Lesions on face

 

The following images show the findings in -

  • Melasma

 

  • Rosacea

 

  • Butterfly-shaped malar rash in SLE 

 

  • Acne

 

  • Nevus of Ota

 

  • Portwine stain

 

  • Infantile hemangioma

questions.text: Where is  Ovoid and tandem radiotherapy used?
questions.solution:
Ovoid and tandem radiotherapy is used for cervical cancer.

Ovoid and tandem brachytherapy is a combination technique where a tandem applicator and ovoid applicators are used for radiation treatment.
A tandem is a narrow tube, that is inserted through the cervix into the uterus, while the ovoids are placed in the upper part of the vagina. Once in place, a radioactive source is introduced into both the tandem and ovoids, ensuring precise radiation delivery to the cancerous tissues.

Both ovoid and tandem brachytherapy are designed to deliver targeted radiation therapy, maximising the dose to the tumor while minimizing side effects to adjacent healthy structures.

Brachytherapy is a form of radiation therapy in which the radiation source is placed close to the tumour. It can be either a low-dose or high-dose rate system. High-dose brachytherapy is safe and effective.
Dosage is calculated with respect to the amount of radiation received at two arbitrary points A and B (Image below).

Different techniques of brachytherapy:

 Techniques Device No. of application Duration
Stockholm

Intrauterine tandem

One vaginal plaque

 Three 24 hours each week
Paris

Intrauterine tandem

Three vaginal ovoids

 One  120 hours
Manchester

Intrauterine tandem

Two vaginal ovoids

 Two 72 hours each weekly

Radiation dose in surrounding normal tissue is less due to inverse square law (Inverse square law - the intensity of radiation is inversely proportional to squared distance from the source of radiation). This method is unsuitable for large tumours and has potential risks of radiation exposure to medical staff.

Note: After loading technique by remote control is the recent development of brachytherapy. It protects the staff from radiation exposure.

questions.text: Malampatti classification is used to:

choices.text: Anticipate a difficult airway for endotracheal intubation
Evaluate a patient for orogastric intubation
Evaluate the risk of blood loss during surgery
Evaluate the cardiovascular fitness of the patient

questions.solution:
The modified Mallampatti classification is used in the assessment of airway. It is a predictor of the difficulty of intubation or difficult airway.

The assessment is performed with the patient sitting up straight, mouth open and tongue maximally protruded, without saying "ahh."

Modified Mallampati classification:

  • Class 0: Ability to see any part of the epiglottis. 
  • Class I: Soft palate, fauces, uvula visible.
  • Class II: Soft palate and fauces seen, tip of uvula not visible.
  • Class III: Soft palate, base of uvula visible.
  • Class IV: Soft palate not visible at all. Only hard palate visible.

Classes 3 and 4 are difficult intubation situations.

*Note:
Initially, the Mallampatti scoring system (1985) had only 3 classes. This was modified by Samsoon and Young to include class 4. Later class 0 was also added.

questions.text: A patient underwent the following investigation for suspected malignancy. Which of the following compounds is used in this investigation?
questions.solution:
The image shows a positron-emission tomography (PET) scan. PET involves the use of a radiolabeled bio-compound such as 2-fluoro-2-deoxy-D-glucose (FDG), which is injected intravenously.

It is based on the principle that tumor cells have a high metabolic rate and can metabolize FDG. However, tumor cells can metabolize FDG only to FDG-6-phosphate, and no further. Hence, it accumulates in tumor cells and can be detected and quantified.

Applications of PET:

  • Oncologic:
    • Detection, staging, drug response
    • Differentiation between radiation necrosis and recurrence
  • Neurologic:
    • Early diagnosis of Alzheimer's disease
    • Localization of seizure focus in the interictal phase
    • Localizing eloquent areas (e.g. speech, motor function)
  • Cardiac:
    • Identification of hibernating myocardium

The combination of PET imaging with CT (PET-CT) combines the metabolic information (PET) with the cross-sectional anatomic information (CT). PET-CT is used in oncology imaging to detect malignant cells as they demonstrate increased glucose metabolism relative to normal tissues.

questions.text: A patient, who is a known case of HIV with a CD4 count of 200 cells/cu.mm, presents with a 5-day history of cough and high-grade fever without chills and rigors. There is no history of diarrhea, vomiting, or nuchal rigidity. Chest X-ray is normal. Which of the following will be the most appropriate treatment for this patient?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of an HIV-infected patient with a CD4 count of 200/mm3 with fever, cough, and a normal chest X-ray is indicative of underlying Pneumocystis pneumonia. Pneumocystis jirovecii pneumonia (PCP) is an opportunistic infection in immunocompromised patients. It is treated with co-trimoxazole.

Patients usually present with fever and nonproductive cough. It can also affect other organs like lymph nodes, spleen, and liver.

The classic radiographic appearance is likely normal or could consist of faint bilateral interstitial infiltrates. Perihilar infiltrates are less common in patients with AIDS. CT will show diffuse ground-glass opacities.

Histopathology of the tissue will show foamy alveolar infiltrate and mononuclear interstitial infiltrates, which is pathognomonic of PCP. Specific stains like methenamine silver, toluidine blue O, or Giemsa can show the cysts. Other tests that are used for the diagnosis of PCP are polymerase chain reaction, (1→3)-β-d-glucan, etc.

The treatment of PCP is with cotrimoxazole (trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole).

For patients with a PaO2 <70 mmHg or with an arterial-alveolar (a–A) gradient >35 mmHg, adjunct glucocorticoid therapy should be used in addition to cotrimoxazole. As the clinical stem does not indicate poor oxygenation, steroid therapy does not have to be initiated. (Option B)

Atovaquone, pentamidine, and primaquine + clindamycin are alternative agents for the treatment of PCP.

Other options:

Option A: Amoxicillin-clavulanic acid + azithromycin is used for the empirical management of bacterial pneumonia on an outpatient basis. Bacterial pneumonia, however, tends to present with consolidation on chest X-rays, which is not seen in this patient.

Below is an image of bacterial pneumonia showing consolidation on X-ray:

Option D: Antitubercular therapy would be indicated if tuberculosis was suspected in the patient. Tuberculosis in HIV-infected patients can be seen in relatively higher CD4 counts and typically presents with fever, cough, weight loss, night sweats, and an abnormal chest X-ray revealing upper lobe cavitary disease.

Related Pearl: Opportunistic Infections/HIV related conditions and ART initiation

Clinical scenario Action 
Any undiagnosed active infection with fever Diagnose and treat first; start Anti-Retroviral Therapy (ART) when stable
Tuberculosis (TB) Start TB treatment first; start ART as soon as possible after 2 weeks and before 2 months. For those with CD4 less than 50/cmm, start ART within 2 weeks Caution is needed for PLHIV with TB meningitis, since immediate ART is associated with more severe adverse events than initiating ART 2 months after the start of TB treatment

Pneumocystis pneumonia (PCP)

 Treat PCP first; start ART when PCP treatment is completed
Invasive fungal diseases: Oesophageal candidiasis, penicilliosis, histoplasmosis Start treatment for oesophageal candidiasis first; start ART as soon as the patient can swallow comfortably. Treat penicilliosis, and histoplasmosis first; start ART when the patient is stabilized or opportunistic infection treatment is completed.
Cryptococcal meningitis Treat cryptococcal meningitis. ART initiation should be deferred until there is evidence of sustained clinical response to anti-fungal therapy and after 4 weeks of induction and consolidation treatment with amphotericin B containing regimen.
Bacterial pneumonia Treat pneumonia first; start ART when treatment is completed
Malaria Treat malaria first; start ART when treatment is completed
Acute diarrhoea which may reduce absorption of ART Diagnose the cause and treat diarrhoea first; start ART when diarrhoea is stabilized or controlled
Non-severe anaemia (Hb< 9 g/dl) Start ART if no other causes for anaemia are found (HIV is often the cause of anaemia) 
Skin conditions such as PPE and seborrhoeic dermatitis, psoriasis, HIV-related exfoliative dermatitis Start ART (ART may resolve these problems) 
Suspected Mycobacterium Avium Complex (MAC), Cryptosporidiosis and Microsporidiosis Start ART (ART may resolve these problems)
Cytomegalovirus retinitis Start treatment for CMV urgently and start ART after 2 weeks of CMV treatment 
Toxoplasmosis Treat toxoplasmosis; start ART after 6 weeks of treatment and when the patient is stabilized

questions.text: A 6-week-old boy was brought by his parents with complaints of noisy breathing, present since a few days after birth. Inspiratory stridor is heard. It subsides with prone positioning and increases with crying. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario of a 6-week-old child with inspiratory stridor which is relieved in the prone position is suggestive of laryngomalacia. 

Laryngomalacia is the most common congenital abnormality of the larynx and the most common cause of stridor in children. It is characterized by excessive flaccidity of the supraglottic larynx which is sucked in during inspiration producing stridor and sometimes cyanosis. The presentation is just after birth and subsides by 2 years. Stridor improves(decreases) in the prone position, and worsens during feeding. The cry is normal. Laryngomalacia leads to the collapse of supraglottic structures during inspiration which results in airway obstruction.

The given image shows omega-shaped glottis on direct laryngoscopy.

Treatment of Laryngomalacia:
Mostly, it self-corrects by 2 years of age.
A tracheostomy may be required for some cases of severe respiratory obstruction.
Supraglottoplasty is required in cases of severe laryngomalacia.

Stridor is noisy respiration produced by turbulent airflow through narrowed air passages. Stridor may be heard during inspiration, expiration or both.

Inspiratory stridor is seen in supraglottic lesions. It is often produced in obstructive lesions of the supraglottis or pharynx, e.g. laryngomalacia or retropharyngeal abscess.
Expiratory stridor is produced in lesions of the thoracic trachea, primary and secondary bronchi, e.g. bronchial foreign body, and tracheal stenosis. (option B)
Biphasic stridor is seen in lesions of the glottis, subglottis, and cervical trachea, e.g. laryngeal papillomas, vocal cord paralysis, and subglottic stenosis. (options C & D)

questions.text: A 40-year-old male presented with diffuse abdominal pain. Physical examination revealed rigidity and guarding. Abdominal X-ray demonstrated free air under the diaphragm. The patient was taken up for surgery and intraoperatively, ileal perforation was noted with gross contamination of the abdomen with enteric and purulent content. What is the appropriate management of this patient?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette with Ileal perforation and physical examination findings of rigidity and guarding suggest peritonitis due to perforation. The next best step in the management of this patient is urgent surgical exploration with an ileostomy.

Perforation of a viscus is a life-threatening condition that occurs following the rupture of the alimentary tract. Common causes include iatrogenic (surgery, scopes) blunt or penetrating injury, bowel obstruction, infections( TB, typhoid) peptic ulcer disease, corrosive agents, or particular medications

This leads to the leakage of the enteric contents, thereby leading to acute bacterial peritonitis. Peritonitis is the generalized or localized inflammation of the peritoneum due to the free spillage of fluids into the peritoneal cavity or secondary bacterial infection.

Clinical features of hollow viscous perforation occur due to the developed peritonitis and the features include abdominal pain and distension, nausea, vomiting, tachycardia, tenderness, rebound tenderness, decreased or absent bowel sounds, and guarding on palpation. Fever may be present. Sometimes, features of septic shock can be seen at later stages.

Investigations include estimating the white blood cell count, urea, serum electrolytes, and an erect abdominal radiograph showing free gas under the diaphragm. A supine radiograph may show dilated gas-filled loops of the bowel, suggestive of paralytic ileus. The below image shows a hollow viscus perforation.

Management - Initial management includes intravenous (IV) fluid therapy, cessation of oral intake, and broad-spectrum antibiotics. Indications for immediate bowel exploration are

  1. Sepsis/diffuse peritonitis(as in this patient)
  2. Bowel ischemia
  3. Complete or closed-loop bowel obstruction

Other options:

Option A: Resection is considered in a patient with multiple perforation, suspected gangrene or malignancy. Anastomosis is avoided in patients in shock, peritonitis with gross contamination

Option B: Primary repair is usually taken for small perforation with minimal contamination and no sign of peritonitis. It is commonly done for traumatic enteric perforation

Option D: Duodenal perforations, on the other hand, are generally treated with omental patch repair without resection.

questions.text: A 15-year-old male patient presented to emergency with pain in the right lower quadrant. He was diagnosed with acute appendicitis. Which of the following is the most commonly used incision for appendectomy?
questions.solution:
The most commonly used incision for an appendectomy is McBurney's Gridiron incision.

The incision is made at McBurney’s point (two-thirds from the umbilicus to the anterior superior iliac spine). They involve passing through all of the abdominal muscles, transversalis fascia, and then the peritoneum, before entering the abdominal cavity.

Other options: 

Option A: Mildline laparotomy incision is commonly used when the diagnosis is uncertain and in cases where an appendicular perforation is suspected. It is for better abdominal exposure.

Option B: Pfannential incision is used for the lower segment caesarean section. 

Option D: Kocher's subcostal incision is used for open cholecystectomy. 

The major anterior abdominal incisions have been illustrated below:

  • 1 is Kocher incision - A subcostal incision used to gain access for gall bladder and/or biliary tree pathology.
  • 2 is midline incision - The most common incision for laparotomy, a vertical incision which follows the linea alba which is particularly favored in diagnostic laparotomy, as they allow wide access to most of the abdominal cavity.
  • 3 is McBurney's incision (also called gridiron incision) is an oblique incision (superolateral to inferomedial) passing along McBurney's point. It is popularly used for open appendicectomy.
  • 4 is battle incision a lower right paramedian incision but placed more laterally than the standard paramedian incision. It is suitable for dealing with acute appendicitis and pathologies in the right lower quadrant of the abdomen.
  • 5 is Lanz incision, a transverse or skin crease incision for appendicitis, 2 cm below the umbilicus, centered on the midclavicular–mid-inguinal line. Due to its continuation with Langer’s lines, the Lanz incision produces much more aesthetically pleasing results with reduced scarring.
  • 6 is paramedian incision - this incision runs 2-5 cm away from the midline used to access much of the lateral viscera, such as the kidneys, spleen, and the adrenal glands.
  • 7 is transverse incision - A supraumbilical transverse incision offers excellent exposure of the upper abdomen. A transverse incision may be superior to a midline incision in terms of recovery and complications postoperatively.
  • 8 is Rutherford Morrison incision, an oblique muscle cutting incision used for access to sigmoid colon and pelvis in patients where the midline is scarred due to previous surgery.
  • 9 is Pfannenstiel incision - An infraumbilical transverse incision in the lower abdomen, often used for gynecological and obstetric procedures.

questions.text:
Identify the procedure shown in the image:

ERCP- Endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography

CBD- Common bile duct
questions.solution:
The image shown is of ERCP and CBD stenting. 

This is an invasive procedure similar to Upper GI endoscopy. Ampulla of Vater is cannulated and then a contrast-filled dye is injected for evaluation of the biliary and pancreatic tree. After a pathology has been diagnosed in CBD, a CBD stent can be placed. 
CBD stenting is useful in indicated in cases of

  • CBD stones
  • CBD strictures
  • management of mild bile duct injury leaks 
  • palliative drainage of malignant bile duct obstructions. 
  • ERCP shows filling of the main pancreatic duct (MPD), and CBD. The MPD and CBD drain into the major papillary.
  • The most common significant complication is acute pancreatitis.

Other options:

(Option A) The pancreatic duct is seen below. 

Option B: PTBD is a form of external biliary drainage where either biliary ductal systems are drained outside percutaneously. It is not done endoscopically.

Option D: PEG is a minimally invasive procedure used for enteral feeding. Endoscopically, a light source is placed in the stomach and a percutaneous puncture is made. A tube is entered through the ostomy and secured to the skin. Enteral feeding can be through nasogastric and nasojejunal tubes. Surgically, tube gastrostomy and feeding jejunostomy can be done.

questions.text: A young woman with a previous history of dilatation and curettage for elective abortion presents with hypomenorrhea. Hysterosalpingography shows irregular, angulated filling defects. Which of the following investigations is used for the definitive diagnosis of this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Asherman syndrome. Hysteroscopy is used for the definitive diagnosis of Asherman syndrome.

Asherman syndrome refers to the presence of uterine synechiae, due to the destruction of the endometrium. It can occur as a result of trauma to the endometrium following vigorous curettages for elective abortion, tuberculous endometritis, and uterine surgeries.

Depending on the degree of scarring, patients may have amenorrhea, hypomenorrhea, or recurrent pregnancy loss because of inadequate placentation.

Hysterosalpingography is performed to assess the uterine cavity and tubal patency. Intrauterine adhesions are characteristically seen as irregular angulated filling defects in the uterine cavity with a classic 'moth-eaten' appearance. 

Definitive diagnosis (gold standard) and management are done by hysteroscopy. Hysteroscopic adhesiolysis is the surgical treatment of choice.

Hormonal assays also aid in the diagnosis of anatomical causes of amenorrhea such as Asherman syndrome. All women with amenorrhea in the reproductive age group are considered pregnant unless proven otherwise by negative urinary or serum β-HCG levels. Once negative for pregnancy, further testing is done by a progesterone challenge test.

This test is done by administering medroxyprogesterone acetate as a 10-mg daily oral dose for 10 days. If the woman bleeds, then she is assumed to produce estrogen and to have a developed endometrium, and the presence of a patent outflow tract is confirmed. If she does not bleed, then she is given estrogen followed by progesterone treatment in the form of combined OCPs. If she fails to bleed after completing the 21 hormone-containing pills, then an anatomic abnormality is diagnosed such as Asherman syndrome.

Given below is an algorithm for the evaluation of amenorrhea.

questions.text: A 20-year-old pregnant female presents with conductive hearing loss of 54db, not associated with tinnitus. Pure tone audiometry shows a notch at 2000 Hz. Which of the following is correct regarding the pathophysiology of the disease?

choices.text: Ossicular fixation with intact tympanic membrane
Ossicular fixation with perforated tympanic membrane
Erosion of stapes footplate with perforated tympanic membrane

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a young pregnant female with bilateral conducting hearing loss and notch at 2000Hz (Carhart's notch) is suggestive of otosclerosis where there is an ossicular fixation with the intact tympanic membrane.

Otosclerosis is the disease of the bony labyrinth in which a normally dense endochondral layer of the bony otic capsule is replaced by irregularly laid spongy bone. It has a positive family history with an autosomal dominant trait. It is more commonly seen in females between 20-30 years of age and the hearing loss is aggravated during pregnancy and menopause. It may be associated with osteogenesis imperfecta and a viral infection like measles. 

Stapedial otosclerosis is the most common type of otosclerosis. Here the lesion starts just in front of the oval window in an area called fissula ante fenestram. There is fixation of stapes footplate.

Patients present with a bilateral conductive type of hearing loss, tinnitus (commonly in cochlear type and active stage), paracusis willisii (better hearing in noisy surroundings than in a quiet place), vertigo, and a monotonous, well-modulated soft speech.

The tympanic membrane is quite normal and mobile. Eustachian tube function is also normal. Pure tone audiometry shows a dip at 2000 Hz in the bone conduction curve known as the Carhart's notch. Tympanometry shows an As type of tympanogram in which there is reduced compliance at or near the ambient air pressure.

On examination, Schwartz sign/flamingo flush showing a red blush of the tympanic membrane due to vascularity can be seen.

Treatment includes medical, surgical management, and hearing aids. Medical management with sodium fluoride is used in the active stage to speed up the maturity of the active focus and halt further cochlear loss. The treatment of choice is surgical management which includes stapedotomy/stapedectomy with the placement of a prosthesis. Hearing aids are used in patients who refuse or are unfit for the surgery.

questions.text: A 47-year-old chronic alcoholic was brought with complaints of confusion and agitation. Her husband reports that she had consumed excessive alcohol the previous day. On examination, she had difficulty in walking and horizontal nystagmus was noted. Which of the following is the best next step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
The given scenario of a chronic alcoholic presenting with confusion, agitation, horizontal nystagmus, and a history of recent heavy alcohol intake is suggestive of Wernicke's encephalopathy.

The current standard of treatment for patients with symptoms of Wernicke's encephalopathy is to give thiamine (vitamin B1) 100 mg intravenously before administering glucose-containing IV fluids.

Chronic alcoholics have thiamine (B1) deficiency, which gets exacerbated with recent excessive intake.

Thiamine deficiency leads to the following:

  • Wernicke’s encephalopathy: It is more commonly seen in alcoholics with chronic thiamine deficiency. It is characterized by :
    • Global confusion
    • Truncal ataxia
    • Ophthalmoplegia
    • Horizontal nystagmus 
  • Korsakoff psychosis: symptoms in addition to those of Wernicke's encephalopathy include:
    • Memory loss
    • Confabulation
  • Beriberi: It can present with sensorimotor peripheral neuropathy, and muscle weakness (dry beriberi) or tachycardia, cardiomegaly, and high-output cardiac failure (wet beriberi).

Hence, the initial treatment in a patient with high alcohol intake with new-onset ataxia should be an emergent IV thiamine infusion to prevent the progression of Wernicke encephalopathy.

Other Options:

Option B- IV glucose: It should be given after IV thiamine in an alcoholic patient to treat hypoglycemia. Because if given before, it will worsen thiamine deficiency and will deteriorate this patient's condition.

Option C- IV naltrexone: It is given to abstain from alcohol use, not for treatment of Wernicke encephalopathy

Option D- IV vitamin B12: Although this patient has macrocytosis and difficulty walking, nystagmus is not a feature of vitamin B12 deficiency. Hence, it is not given. Macrocytosis in this patient is due to chronic alcohol use.

Related Pearl: Vitamin Deficiency States (Water-soluble Vitamins)

questions.text: Until when can a postpartum intrauterine contraceptive device (IUCD) be inserted?
questions.solution:
Postpartum IUCD should be inserted within 48 hours.

An intrauterine contraceptive device (IUCD) prevents the implantation of a fertilized ovum. It does so by acting as a foreign body within the uterine cavity. This leads to increased contractility, tubal peristalsis, and promotes leukocytic infiltration in the endometrium so that the fertilized egg is unable to implant. 

Related Pearl: Hormonal contraceptives

Oral pills:

  • Combined oral contraceptive pills (COC)
    • Mala D - Levonorgestrel 0.15 mg + Ethinyl estradiol  0.03 mg + Ferrous fumarate
    • Mala N - Levonorgestrel 0.15 mg + Ethinyl estradiol  0.03 mg + Ferrous fumarate (Govt. supply, free of cost)
  • Progesterone only pills (POP) - suitable for lactating women
    • Norethisterone 350 μg
    • Norgestrel 75 μg
    • Levonorgestrel (LNG) 30 μg
  • Once a month or long-acting pills - highly disappointing results
    • Quinestrol (long-acting estrogen) + short-acting progesterone
  • Gossypol - male pill : Cottonseed derivative and causes azoospermia and severe oligospermia
  • Post-coital pills or interceptive
    • Levonorgestrel 0.75 mg, 2 doses, 12 hours apart
    • Mifepristone 10-600 mg
    • Ulipristal 30 mg, within 5 days of intercourse
    • Centchroman 60 mg, 2 tablets, within 24 hrs of intercourse
    • GnRH agonists  
    • CuT IUCD, inserted within 5 days

Injectable contraceptives

  • Progesterone only injectables
    • DMPA 150 mg IM every 3 months
    • NET-EN 200 mg IM every 2 months
  • Combined injectables
    • Cyclofem - DMPA 25 mg + Estradiol cypionate 5 mg
    • Mesigyna - NET-EN 50 mg  + Estradiol valerate 5 mg

Subdermal implants

  • Norplant I - Levonorgestrel 35 mg
  • Norplant II or Jadelle - 2 rods with levonorgestrel 70 mg in each and released at a rate of 50 μg/day  

Others

  • Hormonal IUCD - Mirena which contains LNG 52 mg with release rate of 20 μg/day
  • Orthoevra patch - Norelgestomin + Ethinyl estradiol weekly for 3 weeks, then patch free for 1 week
  • Vaginal ring or Nuvaring - Etonogestrel + ethinyl estradiol daily release, use for 3 weeks with withdrawal for 1 week

Related Pearl: Classification Of Contraceptives Based On Effectiveness

Classification Of Contraceptives Based On Effectiveness

Category Failure rate in first year   Example
First tier  < 2 % IUD, Implants, Sterilization
Second tier  3-9 % Hormonal (oral, injected, transdermal patches, transvaginal rings)
Third tier  10-20 % Barrier, Fertility awareness method
Fourth tier  21-30 % Spermicidal preparations

questions.text: Identify the condition shown in the given image below.
questions.solution:
The above radiograph depicts the miliary pattern seen in tuberculosis.

Miliary tuberculosis is a form of disseminated pulmonary tuberculosis that occurs when organisms draining through the lymphatics enter the venous blood and circulate back to the lung. It can result from progressive primary disease, reactivation of latent foci, and iatrogenic exposure (lithotripsy, urethral catheterization, cardiac valve homograft placement, and solid organ transplantation).

The risk factors for the development of miliary TB include extremes of age, alcohol use, malignancy, HIV, corticosteroid use, connective tissue disease, renal failure, diabetes, and pregnancy.

The clinicopathological patterns of this condition include acute miliary TB (which may present as multi-organ dysfunction syndrome (MODS) and ARDS, as in this patient), late generalized TB, and anergic TB (defined histologically by the absence of granulomata). Individual lesions either microscopic or small <2 mm foci of yellow-white consolidation scattered throughout the lung parenchyma. The lesions may coalesce resulting in large areas of consolidation. Serous pleural effusions, tuberculous emyema or obliterative fibrous pleuritis may occur

Laboratory tests may show pancytopenia due to bone marrow infiltration. Other findings could include anemia, thrombocytopenia/cytosis, hyponatremia, and sterile pyuria.

Chest radiography shows a faint reticulonodular pattern distributed fairly uniformly throughout the lungs. 

Histopathology shows granulomas of tuberculosis characteristically contain epithelioid macrophages, Langhans giant cells, and lymphocytes with central caseation necrosis.

Other options: 

Option B: Chest x-ray appearance of acute respiratory distress syndrome varies depending on the severity and typically appears as bilateral diffuse alveolar opacities with dependent atelectasis in some cases. The opacities may have a patchy ground-glass appearance.

Option C: Allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis is a hypersensitivity reaction involving the major airways. Radiographic findings in ABPA include lobar collapse, non-segmental areas of opacities commonly involving the upper lobe, and branching thick tubular opacities due to distended bronchi filled with fungus and mucus - Finger-in-glove appearance 

Option D: Pulmonary metastasis typically appears as peripheral, rounded nodules of variable size, scattered throughout both lungs (cannon-ball lesions).
The most common primaries to result in pulmonary metastases in adults include:

  • Breast carcinoma
  • Colorectal carcinoma
  • Renal cell carcinoma
  • Uterine leiomyosarcoma
  • Head and neck squamous cell carcinoma

The chest radiograph given below shows cannon-ball lesions of metastatic lung cancer.

Related Pearl: Causes of miliary shadow in Chest X-ray

  • Miliary tuberculosis
  • Histoplasmosis
  • Sarcoidosis
  • Pneumoconiosis – coal workers pneumoconiosis and silicosis
  • Healed varicella
  • Long-standing MS – can lead to pulmonary hemosiderosis
  • Alveolar microlithiasis

questions.text: Which of the following staging systems is used in Juvenile Nasopharyngeal Angiofibroma?
questions.solution:
The Fisch staging system is used in the case of Juvenile Nasopharyngeal Angiofibromas. 

Type Details
1 Tumour limited to the nasopharyngeal cavity; bone destruction negligible or limited to the sphenopalatine foramen
2 Tumour invading the pterygopalatine fossa or the maxillary, ethmoid, or sphenoid sinus with bone destruction
3 A: Tumour invading the infratemporal fossa or orbital region without intracranial involvement
B: Tumour invading the infratemporal fossa or orbital region with intracranial extradural (parasellar) involvement
4 A: Intracranial intradural tumor without infiltration of the cavernous sinus, pituitary fossa, or optic chiasm
B: Intracranial intradural tumor with infiltration of the cavernous sinus, pituitary fossa, or optic chiasm

Juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma (JNA) is a highly vascular and locally aggressive tumor seen almost exclusively in adolescent males, associated with significant morbidity and occasional mortality. 

Other options:

Option A: Duke staging system is done in cases of colorectal cancer

Option C: Ann arbor staging system is used in Hodgkin and non-Hodgkin lymphomas.

Option D: TNM staging system is used to classify malignancies. It is most commonly utilized in solid tumors and can help with prognostic cancer staging. The system evaluates the tumor size, regional lymph nodes, and distant metastases.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man presents with decreased hearing. The skull radiograph shows the following appearance. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and cotton wool skull appearance on the radiograph are suggestive of Paget's disease.

Paget's disease is a disease of bone remodelling. Normally, osteoclasts remove the old bones while osteoblasts form new bones. In this disease,  osteoclasts are more active than osteoblasts. leading to more bone absorption than normal. The osteoblasts try to keep up by making new bone, but they overreact and make excess bone that is abnormally large, deformed and fits together haphazardly.

Increased bone formation in Paget's disease may lead to the narrowing of the foramina of the skull. This causes compression of the cranial nerves which may lead to deafness, as seen in this patient. Deafness due to the narrowing of cranial nerve foramina is also seen in osteopetrosis. It can be differentiated from Paget's disease by the absence of lytic lesions of the bone.

Other skull radiological findings in Paget's disease:

  • Osteoporosis circumscripta - Large well-defined lytic lesions involving the inner part of the outer table of the skull with an intact inner table
  • Diploic widening
  • Tam o' Shanter sign

Option A: In thalassemia, X-ray of the skull will show crew cut appearance. 

Option C: In the skull X-ray, Multiple myeloma shows multiple well-defined, punched-out lytic lesions of various sizes scattered throughout the skull, giving the raindrop skull appearance, which is seen in multiple myeloma. 

Option D: In Eosinophilic granuloma, the characteristic skull finding is the geographic skull and solitary or multiple lytic lesions, with a bevelled-edge appearance.

questions.text:
A woman presents to the outpatient department with spotting following IUD insertion. No pain or fever was reported. What is the next best step in this scenario?

IUD - Intrauterine device
questions.solution:
In this scenario of a woman presenting to the outpatient department with spotting following an IUD insertion with no complaints of fever or pain, the next best step would be to give iron tablets and observe.

Spotting is a common side effect after IUD insertion and often resolves on its own without intervention. Since no other complications are present in this patient, there is no need to remove the IUD or prescribe any medications. The patient just needs to be under observation.

It's important to monitor the woman for any signs of heavy bleeding, severe pain, fever, or other unusual symptoms that could indicate complications such as infection or perforation. 

Complications following an IUD insertion : 

  • Pain accounts for 15–40% of IUD removal, hence, it is the most common cause of IUD removal.
  • However, bleeding is the most common side-effect reported after IUD insertion.
  • Disturbances in menstrual bleeding are very commonly reported in the form of increased blood loss or irregular bleeding.
  • Studies have shown that larger non-medicated IUDs cause greater incidences of bleeding than copper devices and hormone-releasing devices.
  • Other side effects and complications are pain, pelvic infection, uterine perforation, and ectopic pregnancies.

Contraindications for IUD usage include:

Absolute contraindications Relative contraindications
  • Suspected pregnancy
  • PID
  • Vaginal bleeding of unknown etiology
  • Carcinoma cervix/uterus/adnexa /other pelvic tumours
  • Anemia
  • Menorrhagia
  • History of PID since the last pregnancy
  • Purulent cervical discharge
  • Distortions of the uterine cavity due to fibroids
  • Uterine malformations
  • An unmotivated person
 

Related Pearl: Methods of contraceptions

  • The incidence of Ca cervix reduced

questions.text: Match the auscultatory areas of the heart from image given below
questions.solution:
The image shows the auscultation areas of the heart and option B is correctly matched. 

The auscultation areas correspond to the areas where the sounds and murmurs of the heart valves can be best heard.

  • Tricuspid area- Lower left sternal edge in the left 4th intercoastal space.
  • Pulmonic area-Upper left sternal edge in the left 2nd intercoastal space
  • Aortic area- Upper right sternal edge in the right 2nd intercoastal space.

questions.text: A woman with a non-recurring indication of a previous lower segment cesarean section now presents with an occipitoposterior fetal position. What is the best next step in management?
questions.solution:
In a woman with a non-recurring indication of lower segment cesarean sections who now presents with an occipitoposterior fetal position, the next step of management would be to try to attempt a vaginal delivery.

Occipitoposterior position is an abnormal position of the vertex and can undergo normal labor in favorable circumstances.

In a majority of cases, the occiput rotates through 3/8th of the circle, and the baby is born in the occipitoanterior position. Hence, when the diagnosis of occipitoposterior position is made, labor is allowed to proceed normally when there are good uterine contractions and a favorable pelvis.

The occipitoposterior (OP) position of the fetus is when the occiput is situated posteriorly over the sacroiliac joint or directly over the sacrum. It is the most common fetal malposition. It is an abnormal position seen in the vertex presentation, not an abnormal presentation. 

  • Occipitoposterior position is commonly seen in the android pelvis/deflexed head.
  • The engaging diameter of this position is sub-occipitofrontal.
  • The most common type in the occipitoposterior position is right OP.
  • A persistent occipitoposterior position results from a failure of internal rotation prior to birth.

Examination findings of OP position:

  • Inspection: The abdomen appears flattened below the umbilicus (infra-umbilical flattening).
  • Pelvic grips:
    • The head is not engaged.
    • The sinciput (cephalic prominence) is not prominently felt.
  • Auscultation: Fetal heart sounds are heard maximally over the flanks. However, in direct OP position, they are heard in the midline.

Features of occipitoposterior position include infra-umbilical flattening and fetal heart sounds localized to the flank. The fetal parts are more prominently felt near the midline. 

Other options 

Option A: Indications of cesarean section in occipitoposterior position:

  • Arrest of labor
  • Inadequate uterine contraction
  • Fetal distress
  • Other obstetrical indications

Option C: External cephalic version (ECV) is done in non-cephalic presentations like breech and transverse lie, to bring the favorable cephalic pole to the lower pole of the uterus. The ideal time to do the external cephalic version is 37 weeks.

Option D: Vaccum-assisted delivery is used to help with prolonged labor, fetal distress, maternal exhaustion, or ineffective pushing and fetal malposition.

Related Pearl: Fetal Skull Dimensions

Note: 

Shortest diameters of fetal skull: Bimastoid - 7.5 cm (doesn't engage) < Bitemporal - 8 cm

Longest diameter of fetal skull: Mentovertical 14 cm > Submentovertical / occipitofrontal - 11.5cm

questions.text: A young woman came to the clinic requesting a post-coital pill. Which of the following would you prescribe?
questions.solution:
Levonorgestrel can be prescribed to a young woman requesting a post-coital pill.

Levonorgestrel 1.5 mg single dose within 72 hours of unprotected intercourse, can be used for emergency contraception. Alternatively, it can also be administered in two doses of 0.75 mg. The first dose is taken within 72 hours of unprotected intercourse, and the 2nd dose is taken 12 hours apart. The tablets can be offered up to 120 hours but the efficacy decreases with the longer coital-drug interval.

Advantages of LNG tablets: 

  • It has no estrogen and its associated side effects.
  • It can be offered to hypertensive, cardiac and diabetic women.
  • It can be offered to a lactating woman.
  • It can be given as late as 120 hours after unprotected intercourse (but efficacy decreases).
  • Single-dose therapy is an advantage.

Combined oral pills consisting of both estrogen and progesterone act on the hypothalamic-pituitary axis to inhibit the release of GnRH (and thus subsequently LH and FSH) and thus inhibit ovulation.

Emergency contraception refers to backup methods for contraceptive emergencies that women can use within the first few days after unprotected intercourse to prevent an unwanted pregnancy. Administration of postcoital contraceptive agents that interfere with postovulatory events that can lead to pregnancy. 

The various emergency contraceptive methods, along with their mechanism of action have been described below:

  • Ethinyl estradiol 50 μg + norgestrel 0.25 mg is administered as two tablets within 72 hours of coitus, followed by the 2 tablets after 12 hours. The hormone may delay ovulation if taken soon after intercourse. 
  • Ulipristal is given as a 30 mg tablet and should be taken within 5 days. It is a synthetic progesterone hormone receptor modulator. The drug attaches to the progesterone receptor, delays ovulation, and suppresses endometrium, thereby preventing implantation.
  • IUCD (intrauterine contraceptive device) prevents the implantation of a fertilized ovum. It does so by acting as a foreign body within the uterine cavity. This leads to increased contractility, tubal peristalsis, and leukocytic infiltration in the endometrium. 
  • Centchroman is administered as two tablets of 60 mg, taken twice over a duration of 24 hours and within 24 hours of intercourse. It acts by preventing the implantation of the blastocyst in the endometrium. 

Related Pearl: Hormonal contraceptives

Oral pills:

  • Combined oral contraceptive pills (COC)
    • Mala D - Levonorgestrel 0.15 mg + Ethinyl estradiol  0.03 mg + Ferrous fumarate
    • Mala N - Levonorgestrel 0.15 mg + Ethinyl estradiol  0.03 mg + Ferrous fumarate (Govt. supply, free of cost)
  • Progesterone only pills (POP) - suitable for lactating women
    • Norethisterone 350 μg
    • Norgestrel 75 μg
    • Levonorgestrel (LNG) 30 μg
  • Once a month or long-acting pills - highly disappointing results
    • Quinestrol (long-acting estrogen) + short-acting progesterone
  • Gossypol - male pill : Cottonseed derivative and causes azoospermia and severe oligospermia
  • Post-coital pills or interceptive
    • Levonorgestrel 0.75 mg, 2 doses, 12 hours apart
    • Mifepristone 10-600 mg
    • Ulipristal 30 mg, within 5 days of intercourse
    • Centchroman 60 mg, 2 tablets, within 24 hrs of intercourse
    • GnRH agonists  
    • CuT IUCD, inserted within 5 days

Injectable contraceptives

  • Progesterone only injectables
    • DMPA 150 mg IM every 3 months
    • NET-EN 200 mg IM every 2 months
  • Combined injectables
    • Cyclofem - DMPA 25 mg + Estradiol cypionate 5 mg
    • Mesigyna - NET-EN 50 mg  + Estradiol valerate 5 mg

Subdermal implants

  • Norplant I - Levonorgestrel 35 mg
  • Norplant II or Jadelle - 2 rods with levonorgestrel 70 mg in each and released at a rate of 50 μg/day  

Others

  • Hormonal IUCD - Mirena which contains LNG 52 mg with release rate of 20 μg/day
  • Orthoevra patch - Norelgestomin + Ethinyl estradiol weekly for 3 weeks, then patch free for 1 week
  • Vaginal ring or Nuvaring - Etonogestrel + ethinyl estradiol daily release, use for 3 weeks with withdrawal for 1 week

questions.text: Which of the following is the most radiosensitive organ?
questions.solution:
Among the given options, testes is the most radiosensitive organ. 

The radiosensitivity is higher in cases where the proliferation is high. In the case of the testes, it contains a high number of clonal cells since it is a reproductive organ. Thus, among the given options testes is the most radiosensitive organ.

The radiosensitivity of various tissues is summed up in the table given below: 

  Most radiosensitive Least radiosensitive

 

Tissue



 Bone marrow, Gonads Nervous tissue, Muscle fibers
Blood cells Lymphocytes Platelets
Stages of cell cycle G2M interphase S phase
Cell types Rapidly dividing Quiescent
Ocular structure Lens Sclera
Layer of retina Rods Ganglion cell layer

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman presented with a thin white vaginal discharge. Which of the following options does not belong to Amsel's criteria for diagnosing bacterial vaginosis?

choices.text: Presence of epithelial cells with bacteria adhered around them.
White milky non viscous discharge adherent to vaginal wall.
Fishy odour when mixed with 10% KOH

questions.solution:
The pH of discharge more than 4.5 is included in Amsel's criteria for diagnosing bacterial vaginosis.

Bacterial vaginosis occurs due to an alteration in the normal vaginal flora, specifically the lactobacilli. Lactobacilli are responsible for maintaining vaginal pH and reducing the growth of other pathogenic bacteria. In this condition, the number of lactobacilli is reduced, resulting in an increase in the number of pathogenic organisms like Gardnerella vaginalis, Haemophilus vaginalis, Mobiluncus, and Mycoplasma hominins.

It is diagnosed using Amsel's criteria:

  • White milky non-viscous discharge adherent to the vaginal wall.
  • Vaginal pH > 4.5
  • Amine-like odor on adding KOH - Potassium hydroxide (whiff test positive)
  • Presence of clue cells (>20% of cells) which are epithelial cells with bacteria adhered around them.

Metronidazole 500 mg twice daily for 7 days or clindamycin cream (2%) applied intravaginally daily at bedtime for 7 days can be used to treat bacterial vaginosis.

questions.text: A 65-year-old chronic smoker presented with a bright red velvety plaque on the floor of the mouth.  Which of the following statements is correct about the diagnosis and management of this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a chronic smoker presenting with a bright red velvety plaque on the floor of the mouth is suggestive of erythroplakia and the next best step is to do an excision biopsy of the lesion. 

Erythroplakia is a pre-malignant oral lesion that presents as a bright red velvety patch or plaque commonly at the lower alveolar mucosa, gingivobuccal sulcus and the floor of the mouth. The red colour is due to decreased keratinization and as a result, the red vascular connective tissue of the submucosa shines through.  Grossly, the lesion may be of three varieties—homogenous, speckled or granular, and erythroplakia, interspersed with areas of leukoplakia. Malignant potential is 17 times higher than in leukoplakia, hence excision biopsy and follow-up are indicated in such cases.

Other options:
Option A, B, D:  Leukoplakia is a premalignant condition of the oral cavity characterized by whitish patches or plaques that cannot be rubbed off. Management includes smoking cessation and reduction in alcohol consumption. A biopsy should be done and a photographic record of the lesion is used for follow-up. Both erythroplakia and leukoplakia have malignant potential. Hence, only observation will not be appropriate.

Leukoplakia image:

questions.text: A 55-year-old man presents with pain abdomen. Contrast-enhanced CT scan of the abdomen was done. What is the likely source of pain in this patient?
questions.solution:
The history of an elderly male presenting with pain abdomen and an axial CECT image showing renal lesions with irregular enhancement is suggestive of renal origin of pain likely renal cell carcinoma (RCC).

It is the most common malignant tumour of the kidney. It usually occurs in the age group 50–70 years and macroscopic hematuria is seen in about 60% of the cases. It usually presents with painless gross hematuria, flank pain, or painless flank mass.

Contrast-enhanced CT is the investigation of choice for RCC. On CT, small lesions enhance homogeneously, whereas larger lesions have irregular enhancement due to areas of necrosis. The clear cell subtype may show much stronger enhancement is a differential for angiomyolipoma. Still, it is essential to note that macroscopic fat is almost always associated with ossification or calcification.

Surgeries done for RCC: 

Partial nephrectomy, the goal is the complete removal of the primary tumor while preserving healthy renal parenchyma. It is used for renal tumors <7cm in size. 
Classic radical nephrectomy involves the removal of the kidney, perirenal fat, adrenal gland, and regional lymph nodes. 
Targeted therapies for RCC include tyrosine kinase inhibitors (sorafenib, sunitinib), anti-vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF) monoclonal antibodies (bevacizumab), and mammalian target of rapamycin (mTOR) inhibitors (everolimus and temsirolimus).

Given below is the image showing the anatomy in the axial section of the CT scan

1- Liver, 2-Spleen, 3-Pancreas, 4-Gallbladder, 5-Right Adrenal Gland, 6-Left Adrenal Gland, 7-Inferior Vena Cava, 8-Aorta, 9-Portal Vein, 11- Ascending Colon, 12-Descending Colon, 14- Stomach.

questions.text: A male patient following an accident presented with complex injuries including degloving injuries of the foot and leg. What type of flap/graft was used during surgery?
questions.solution:
The image given shows a Thiersch graft which is also known as a split-thickness skin graft. 

Skin grafts can be broadly divided into two categories:

Split-thickness skin graft (Thiersch graft): Partial-thickness skin grafts consisting of the epidermis and a portion of the dermis are called split-thickness skin grafts. Less dermis in the split-thickness skin graft translates into less primary contraction (the degree to which a graft shrinks in surface area after harvesting and before grafting) and more secondary contraction (the degree to which a graft shrinks during healing).

Full-thickness skin grafts (Wolfe graft- Option A) include the epidermis and entire dermis, with portions of the sweat glands, sebaceous glands, and hair follicles. More dermis in the full-thickness skin graft translates into more primary contraction and less secondary contraction.

Advantages of split skin graft over full-thickness skin graft:

  • Large grafts can be harvested.
  • In the case of thinner split-thickness grafts, the donor site heals more rapidly and can be reused in severe cases such as burns.
  • Uptake is good. Meshing can be done i.e. small splits are made in graft and any exudates collected can come out through this and this improves graft takeup. 
  • Meshing also allows the graft to expand.

Advantages of full-thickness skin graft over split skin graft:

  • It has a lesser degree of post-graft contraction.
  • Best cosmetic appearance as they include the highest number of skin appendage elements.Other options: 

Grafts derive their blood supply from the target bed while flaps carry their own blood supply.

Option B: Free flaps - A flap where its blood vessel is disconnected and the vessel is reconnected using microsurgery at the new site.

Option C: Pedicled/islanded flaps - They are the repositioned flaps which maintain their original blood supply even after the transfer.
 

Related Pearl: Skin graft : phases of uptake of the graft

The take of skin graft occurs in three phases:

  1. Imbibition (Plasmatic circulation): during the first 48 hours, the graft is nourished with plasma exudate from host bed capillaries.
  2. Inosculation, in which cut vessels from the host bed line up with the cut ends of the vessels of the graft to form anastomoses
  3. Neovascularization, in which blood vessels grow from the recipient bed into the graft

Sensibility returns to the graft over time, with reinnervation beginning at approximately 4 to 5 weeks and being completed by 12 to 24 months. Pain returns first, with light touch and temperature returning later.

Note: some books give that the 3 phases are imbibition,revascularisation (inosculation+neovascularisation) and organisation (fibrin layer holds the graft in place and this is replaced by postgraft day 7 with fibroblasts)

questions.text: A patient fell from a train onto the railway tracks and injured both his legs severely. He was urgently taken to the hospital and the following procedure was done as shown in the image below. What is the rationale for performing this procedure?
questions.solution:
The above patient shown in the image had undergone a below-knee amputation. In the background of trauma with a severely injured, crushed or septic limb amputation is a life-saving procedure. 

Major amputations can be done for,

  • Dead limb -Gangrene
  • Deadly limb- Wet gangrene, spreading infection (gas gangrene), malignancy
  • Dead loss limb- Severe critical rest pain which cannot be revascularized, paralysis, trauma etc

Even though, the below-knee amputations provide a better fit for a prosthesis(Option A), it is not the main rationale behind this procedure. 

Mangled extremity score system (MESS) is commonly used to decide whether the limb should undergo amputation. Components of the score: Shock, Ischemia, Soft tissue injury and age.

Other options:

Option C: Amputation can be used for the treatment of cancer but it does not reduce the risk of cancer.

Option D: Good cosmetic outcomes are not the indications for amputation in a trauma patient. 

Related Pearl: List of Names of Amputations and Their Levels

TYPE 

LEVEL OF AMPUTATION 

Lisfranc

Tarsometatarsal joint 

Chopart 

Transverse tarsal joints (articulation of calcaneus with cuboid and talus with navicular)

Pirogoff

Calcaneum is rotated forward to be fused with tibia after vertical section through its middle 

Syme 

Distal tibia & fibula 0.6 cm proximal to the periphery of ankle joint passing through the dome of the ankle. Involves removal of both medial and lateral malleoli.

Boyd 

Talectomy, forward shift of the calcaneus and calcaneo-tibial arthrodesis 

Sarmiento 

Distal tibia and fibula: 1.3 cm proximal to the ankle joint and excision of medial and lateral malleoli

questions.text: A 45-year-old male patient with past history of tuberculosis was brought to the emergency department with complaints of breathing difficulty. On examination, there is shortness of breath, and prominent neck veins. While recording the patient's blood pressure, a significant drop in systolic pressure during inspiration was noted from 80mmHg to 60mmHg. The X-ray is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of breathing difficulty, prominent neck veins, pulsus paradoxus (significant drop in blood pressure >10 mm Hg), and X-ray image showing cardiomegaly (cardiothoracic ratio more than 0.5) in a patient with a past history of tuberculosis is suggestive of cardiac tamponade.

Cardiac tamponade is characterized by the accumulation of fluid in the pericardial space leading to impairment of diastolic relaxation of the cardiac chambers. This leads to a decline in cardiac output. The characteristic signs of cardiac tamponade are:

  • Tachycardia and hypotension
  • Pericardial rub
  • Pulsus paradoxus - paradoxical reduction in the systemic blood pressure (>10 mm Hg) on inspiration.
  • Beck's triad - hypotension, muffled heart sounds, and elevated jugular venous pressure with prominent x descent and absent y descent. The sensitivity of jugular venous distention in detecting tamponade is 100%.

ECG shows reduced voltage and electrical alternans; an Echocardiogram shows a swinging heart sign.

Other options:

Option A: While constrictive pericarditis can also lead to elevated jugular venous pressure, it typically does not cause the classic physical findings associated with cardiac tamponade, such as pulsus paradoxus (significant drop in systolic blood pressure during inspiration) and the absence of heart sounds. Patients with constrictive pericarditis demonstrate a prominent y descent.

Option C: Pleural effusion refers to the pathological accumulation of fluid in the pleural space. It may present with dyspnea, pleuritic pain, dry cough, and associated symptoms like fever, weight loss, edema, and ascites depending on the etiology. On examination, there may be tachypnea, dullness on percussion and decreased/absent breath sounds at the base(s). X-ray shows a classical meniscus sign.

Option D: Acute pericarditis is an inflammation of the pericardium characterized by retrosternal chest pain that is aggravated by deep inspiration and a supine position and relieved by sitting and leaning forward. .On auscultation, 85% of patients have a pericardial friction rub. This appears as a rough scratching sound at end of expiration when the patient is sitting and leaning forward. On ECG There is widespread elevation of ST segments; depression of PR segment below the TP segment

Related Pearl: Causes of Pulsus Paradoxus

Physiological causes

Obesity

Pregnancy

Cardiovascular causes

Cardiac tamponade – most common cause

Constrictive pericarditis ( in 1/3rd cases )

Massive pulmonary embolism

Severe CCF

Hypovolemic shock

Respiratory causes

Severe obstructive lung disease

Acute severe asthma

Severe emphysema

Tension pneumothorax

Related Pearl: JVP waveform and the abnormalities

1) The a-wave corresponds to atrial contraction.

Abnormality Conditions
Prominent a-waves Pulmonary hypertension, right atrial thrombus/ mass, and tricuspid stenosis
Cannon a-waves

Complete AV block, ventricular tachycardia, and premature atrial/ junctional/ ventricular beats
Absent a-waves Atrial fibrillation

 

2) The c-wave corresponds to the bulging of tricuspid valve into right atrium during ventricular contraction.

 

3) The x-descent corresponds to atrial relaxation during atrial diastole.

Abnormality Conditions
Absent x-descent Severe tricuspid regurgitation
Rapid x-descent Cardiac tamponade

 

4) The v-wave corresponds to the venous filling of right atrium.

Abnormality Conditions
Dominant v-waves Tricuspid regurgitation

 

5) The y-descent corresponds to the passive emptying of the right atrium into right ventricle.

Abnormality Conditions
Prolonged y-descent Tricuspid stenosis
Rapid y-descent

Constrictive pericarditis and isolated severe tricuspid regurgitation
Absent y-descent Cardiac tamponade

questions.text: A 24-year old male stated that he had fallen with his thumb extended and presented with a painful, swollen thumb. The X-ray image is shown below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The X-ray shows an intra-articular, two-part fracture of the base of the first metacarpal bone known as Bennett fracture. 

Option A: Rolando fracture is an intraarticular comminuted fracture of the base of the first metacarpal bone, with a ‘T’ or ‘Y’ configuration.

Option B: Avulsion fracture of the ulnar base of the proximal phalanx of the thumb is known as Gamekeeper’s fracture.

A gamekeeper thumb, also known as a skier’s thumb is an injury to the ulnar collateral ligament (UCL) of the first metacarpophalangeal joint. The UCL may get ruptured or avulsed from its site of insertion on the base of the proximal phalanx. Injury is usually caused by a fall on an outstretched hand with radial and palmar abduction. Patients present with pain, swelling, and ecchymosis around the first metacarpophalangeal joint.

Option D: Epibasal fracture of thumb, also known as pseudo Bennett’s fracture is a two-part extra-articular fracture of the proximal first metacarpal bone. These fractures are stable and do not usually require surgical correction.

Related Pearl: Important injuries of the hand

Gamekeeper's thumb: It is an injury of the thumb leading to avulsion, rupture or damage of the Ulnar collateral ligament. It is commonly seen in gamekeepers and also following a fall on an outstretched hand.

 
Mallet finger/baseball finger: It is a disruption to the extensor tendon over the DIP joint. It occurs when a collision with a hard object (e.g., a ball) forces it to flex more than its normal range of motion.
 

 

Jersey finger: It is an avulsion injury of the flexor digitorum profundus at the insertion of the base of the distal phalanx. The ring finger most commonly involved.

 

Trigger finger: A nodule on the flexor tendon prevents it to move along the A1 pulley. This causes the finger to be stuck in a flexed position.

 

Boxer's fracture: It is a break in the neck of the metacarpal. It is caused by striking an object with a closed fist, as seen in boxing. The little finger is the most commonly affected.

questions.text: A patient with a history of recurrent pilonidal sinus underwent surgery as shown in the image.  What kind of flap procedure is used here?
questions.solution:
The following image shows a rhomboid flap done in pilonidal sinus surgery.

A pilonidal sinus is defined as a blind track lined by granulation tissue leading from an epithelial surface to surrounding tissue. Pilonidal sinus disease, also called jeep/driver’s bottom, is commonly seen in the natal cleft, more in men, usually after puberty.

Buttock friction and shearing forces (drivers are commonly affected) in this area allow broken hairs to enter the skin and create a subcutaneous, chronically infected midline track. An infected hair follicle can also form such a track. Secondary tracks can also form and are lined with granulation tissue and discharge. 

Patients complain of intermittent pain, swelling, and discharge at the base of the spine. A foreign-body-type reaction may then lead to the formation of an abscess.

Treatment includes non-surgical and surgical approaches:

Non-surgical approaches include conservative treatment with proper hygiene and regular shaving of hair in the area. In case of an abscess- adequate rest, baths, local antiseptic dressings, and broad-spectrum antibiotics are advised.

Surgical approaches for the management of pilonidal sinus disease include:

Incision and drainage- for pilonidal abscess refractory to medical treatment.
Bascom's procedure- is a cleft lift procedure in which hair follicles parallel to the natal cleft are removed under local anesthesia
Others- VY advancement flaps, and Z-plasty.

A rhomboid flap is an example of a transposition flap that are rectangular or square and turn laterally to reach the defect . They rely on the looseness of adjacent skin to transfer a rhomboid-shaped flap into a defect that has been converted into a similar rhomboid shape.

questions.text: A 20-year-old male presented to the trauma centre after suffering a road traffic accident.  He is tachypneic with cold extremities. His BP on arrival is 90/50 mm Hg. Which of the following is true about the pathophysiology of his condition?
questions.solution:
The above described patient with cold extremities, tachypnea and low blood pressure in a background of trauma has hypovolemic shock. In a patient with hypovolemic shock, there is increased systemic vascular resistance, decreased venous return(preload) and low mixed venous oxygen saturation.

     Hypovolemic    Cardiogenic    Obstructive  Distributive
Cardiac output Low Low Low       High
Vascular resistance High High  High  Low
Venous pressure Low High  High   Low
Mixed venous saturation Low Low Low High 
Base deficit High  High  High  High 

The most common shock in a road traffic accident patient is hypovolemic shock. The most common cause of hypovolemia is hemorrhage.

Blood pressure Normal Normal Decreased Greatly decreased
Pulse pressure Normal or increased Decreased Decreased Decreased
Respiratory rate 14–20 20–30 30–40 >35
Mental status Slightly anxious Mildly anxious Anxious, confused Confused, lethargic
Urine output (mL/hr) >30 20–30 5–15 Minimal

questions.text: Ga-68PSMA is used to diagnose which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
Radio-labeled ligands- Gallium (Ga68) attached to the prostate-specific membrane antigen (PSMA)can be helpful in identifying prostatic cancer.

Prostate-specific membrane antigen (PSMA) is a specific prostate epithelial cell membrane antigen, showing increased expression in prostate cancers, which is also a potential target for monoclonal antibody therapy.

questions.text: A 21-year-old female presented to OPD with complaints of recurrent lesions on her lips as shown below. Which of the following characteristic feature is seen on Tzanck smear?
questions.solution:
The above image shows multiple vesicles & crusts clustered on an inflamed base around the lips which is characteristic of herpes labialis or cold sore caused by HSV-1 virus. Tzanck smear of this patient will show multinucleated giant cells.

Herpes labialis is commonly caused by herpes simplex virus type 1(HSV-1) and rarely by herpes simplex virus type 2 (HSV-2). It begins with a prodrome of pain, burning, and tingling followed by the appearance of erythematous papules. The papules then become vesicular and may ulcerate. 

Tzanck cells or multinucleated giant cells are seen in microscopy. Multinucleated giant cells with faceted nuclei and homogeneously stained ground glass chromatin-Tzanck cells are seen.

It is treated with oral acyclovir 200 mg and 5% topical acyclovir.

 

Other options:

Option B: Molluscum bodies or Henderson–Patterson bodies are large, eosinophilic, hyaline, intracytoplasmic inclusion bodies caused by Molluscum contagiosum. These bodies are composed of a large number of virus particles embedded in a protein matrix.

Option C: Owl’s eye inclusion bodies are intranuclear basophilic inclusion bodies seen in cytomegalovirus infection.

Option D: Donovan bodies are seen in granuloma inguinale, which is caused by Klebsiella granulomatis. They are seen inside large, mononuclear cells (pund cells) as gram-negative intracytoplasmic cysts filled with deeply staining bodies. They can have a characteristic safety pin appearance due to bipolar staining of the chromatin material.

questions.text: A patient presents with polyuria, polydipsia, lethargy and abdominal pain. She also gives a history of mood disorders and recurrent kidney stones. Which of the following investigations would not be useful in arriving at a diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of recurrent kidney stones, mood disorder and features of hypercalcemia (polyuria, polydipsia) is suggestive of primary hyperparathyroidism. Angiography of renal arteries is not a useful investigation for hyperparathyroidism.  

Investigations in primary hyperparathyroidism: Ultrasonography of the neck is a safe and widely used technique for localising abnormal parathyroid glands.

Dual-energy radiographic absorptiometry (DEXA) is useful for demonstrating skeletal involvement in primary hyperparathyroidism. Nuclear medicine scanning with radiolabelled Sestamibi is also a widely used technique. Sestamibi accumulates in parathyroid adenomas. This radionuclide is concentrated in the thyroid and parathyroid tissue but usually washes out of normal thyroid tissue in under an hour. It persists in abnormal parathyroid tissue. The image given below shows a radiolabeled Sestamibi scan. 

Clinical features of hyperparathyroidism:

  • Bones:
    • Pathological fractures Subperiosteal bone resorption - 2nd and 3rd digits, most common in radial aspect.
    • Salt and pepper skull
    • Osteitis fibrosa cystica or VonReckling Hausen’s disease
  • Stones:
    • Multiple and recurrent renal stones - most common
    • Nephrocalcinosis
  • Abdominal groans - colicky due to pancreatitis
    Psychiatric overtones - raised PTH causing CNS depression and psychiatric symptoms
    Band keratopathy
    Features of hypercalcemia - vomiting, confusion, ECG changes: increased PR interval, shortened QT interval

The image given below shows a salt and pepper skull seen in hyperparathyroidism.

questions.text: Puerperal pyrexia can be diagnosed if a woman has :

choices.text: A temperature of >100.4 F, 12 hours after delivery
A temperature of >100.4 F, 6 hours after delivery
A temperature of >100.4 F, 24 hours after delivery
A temperature of >100.4 F, 3 hours after delivery

questions.solution:
Puerperal fever is defined as a temperature of >100.4 °F (38 °C or higher) on 2 separate occasions at 24 hours apart (excluding the first 24 hours) within the first 10 days following delivery.

In the first 24 hours, a slight rise in temperature is not uncommon and hence the first 24 hours are excluded to define puerperal pyrexia.

Note: Generally, fever in an adult is defined as an oral temperature of >37.5 °C.

questions.text: An elderly man with a chronic history of IV drug use presented with a progressively increasing swelling in the groin on the right side. It is is non fluctuant but pulsatile on  examination. He has diminished pulses on the same side distal to the swelling. What is the next step in the management of this patient?

choices.text: CT angiography followed by surgical intervention

questions.solution:
The patient most likely has a pseudoaneurysm of the femoral artery, caused by repeated penetrating injuries during intravenous drug administration. The recommended approach includes conducting a CT angiography for diagnosis, followed by surgical intervention.

In pseudoaneurysm, the intimal and medial layers are disrupted and the dilated segment is lined by adventitia only compared to a true aneurysm where all three layers are involved. It usually occurs secondary to trauma- arterial samples, arterial catheterization and IV drug users. It is usually pulsatile and systolic bruit can be heard on auscultation.

Doppler ultrasound reveals a bidirectional, 'to-and-fro' flow of blood which is known as the yin-yang sign. Management includes the delineation of anatomy using CT-Angiography. Treatment options include open or endovascular surgery. 

Other options

Option B: Antibiotics are used when the local wound appears infected with pus discharge or systemic symptoms of malaise and fever. However, imaging and surgical intervention will be needed. 

Option C: Compression stockings are used in the management of chronic venous insufficiency.

Option D: Incision and drainage are required for the management of abscesses.  It should be avoided in the case of a pseudoaneurysm.

questions.text: A 62-year-old female presented to the OPD with complaints of a gradually progressive swelling over his abdomen for 1.5 years. She had a history of midline surgery done as a child. On examination, the swelling was 4 cm and was reducible with a palpable cough impulse. She is planned to undergo fascial closure with a mesh repair. What is the likely location of the mesh as shown in image?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario of a reducible swelling with cough impulse and palpable defect in a patient with a previous surgery points toward a diagnosis of incisional hernia.  Incisional hernias are repaired by fascial closure augmented with a mesh. It is an onlay type of mesh repair.
 
An incisional hernia refers to a ventral abdominal wall hernia at the site of a previous surgical incision.  Incisional hernias are usually asymptomatic, but can occasionally present with pain. Strangulation and bowel obstruction are rare due to the large neck of the defect. In general, incisional hernias are repaired by fascial closure augmented with a mesh. There are different options for mesh placement:
  • Onlay (above the anterior fascia, over the defect)
  • Inlay (between the fascial edges without overlap)
  • Sublay (below the fascial components) - this includes retrorectus, preperitoneal, and intraperitoneal (IPOM) mesh placements 

Primary suture repair using Mayo’s technique is reserved only for very small hernias with < 2cm defect. This involves closing the fascial edges with a 2 cm overlap using an interrupted suture and then reinforcing it with a continuous running suture (double-breasting).
